def:
A cell complex $X$ is \emph{acyclic in positive codimension} , or APC for
short, if $\betti_j(X)=0$ for all $j<\dim X$.
plain_text_def:
A cell complex X is acyclic in positive codimension , or APC for
short, if _j(X)=0 for all j< X.

def:
A simplicial complex $\Delta^d$ is \emph{acyclic in positive codimension} , or APC for short,
if $\betti_j(\Delta) = 0$ for all $j < d$.
plain_text_def:
A simplicial complex Δ^d is acyclic in positive codimension , or APC for short,
if _j(Δ) = 0 for all j < d.

def: \cite{DKM1}\rm  A CW complex $K$ of dimension $k$ is called \emph{acyclic in positive codimension} (APC) if $\rbetti{j}=0$ for all $j<k$.
plain_text_def: <cit.>A CW complex K of dimension k is called acyclic in positive codimension (APC) if j=0 for all j<k.

def:
\label{definition:adaptabilityOfASequenceToAPartition}
We say that a sequence of indices $(i_1, \ldots, i_n)$ is \emph{adapted} to a labeled partition $(\pi, \mathfrak{i})$ if all legs of a given block $B$ have the same label $\mathfrak{i}(B)$.
plain_text_def: We say that a sequence of indices (i_1, …, i_n) is adapted to a labeled partition (π, 𝔦) if all legs of a given block B have the same label 𝔦(B).

def:
\label{definition:*-cellularity}
Suppose that $(\Lambda, \T, c)$ is a cellular datum for $\H_{p, [\alpha]}^\kappa$. We say that $(\Lambda, \T, c)$ is an \emph{adapted} cellular datum if for all $[\tuple{\lambda}] \in \PP_n^\kappa$, there exist $\lambda_{[\tuple{\lambda}], 1}, \dots, \lambda_{[\tuple{\lambda}], \frac{p}{\#[\tuple{\lambda}]}} \in \Lambda$ such that the conditions~\eqref{subequations:adapted_cellularity} are satisfied, together with $\bigl(c^\lambda_\mathfrak{st}\bigr)^* = c^\lambda_\mathfrak{ts}$ for all $\lambda \in \Lambda$ and $\mathfrak{s}, \mathfrak{t} \in \T(\lambda)$.
plain_text_def: Suppose that (Λ, , c) is a cellular datum for _̋p, [α]^κ. We say that (Λ, , c) is an adapted cellular datum if for all [λ] ∈_n^κ, there exist λ_[λ], 1, …, λ_[λ], p/#[λ]∈Λ such that the conditions (<ref>) are satisfied, together with (c^λ_𝔰𝔱)^* = c^λ_𝔱𝔰 for all λ∈Λ and 𝔰, 𝔱∈(λ).

def:
Let $A, B \subseteq F_q$ and $\xi \in\F_q^*$. The \emph{additive energy} of $A$ and $\xi B$ is defined in the following equivalent ways.
\begin{align*}
E(A, \xi B) 
& = \sum_{x \in\F_q} r_{A \pm \xi B}^2(x) \\
& = | \{ (a_1, a_2 , b_1, b_2) \in A \times A \times B \times B : (a_1-a_2) = \xi (b_1-b_2) \}.
%& = |A|^2 + \text{number of solutions to $\frac{a_1-a_2}{a_3-a_4} = \xi$ with the $a_i \in A$}.
\end{align*}
plain_text_def:
Let A, B ⊆ F_q and ξ∈_q^*. The additive energy of A and ξ B is defined in the following equivalent ways.

    E(A, ξ B) 
        = ∑_x ∈_q r_A ±ξ B^2(x) 
        = | { (a_1, a_2 , b_1, b_2) ∈ A × A × B × B : (a_1-a_2) = ξ (b_1-b_2) }.

def:
Let $0 \neq \xi \in \F$. The \emph{additive energy} of $A$ and $\xi A$ is defined in the following equivalent ways
\begin{align*}
E_+(A, \xi A) 
& = \sum_{x \in \F} r_{A \pm \xi A}^2(x) \\
& = \text{number of solutions to $(a_1-a_2) = \xi (a_3-a_4)$ with the $a_i \in A$}\\
& = |A|^2 + \text{number of solutions to $\frac{a_1-a_2}{a_3-a_4} = \xi$ with the $a_i \in A$}.
\end{align*}
plain_text_def:
Let 0 ≠ξ∈. The additive energy of A and ξ A is defined in the following equivalent ways

    E_+(A, ξ A) 
        = ∑_x ∈ r_A ±ξ A^2(x) 
        = number of solutions to (a_1-a_2) = ξ (a_3-a_4) with the a_i ∈ A
        = |A|^2 + number of solutions to a_1-a_2/a_3-a_4 = ξ with the a_i ∈ A.

def:
Given an $\vtcs$-vertex graph $G = (V,E)$, we identify the vertices with an orthonormal basis of $\C^\vtcs$; the vector for vertex~$v$ is denoted $\ket{v}$.\footnote{We are using the Dirac bra-ket notation, in which $\ket{v}$ denotes a column vector and $\bra{v}$ denotes its conjugate-transpose $\ket{v}^\dagger$.}  A directed edge $(u,v) \in \vec{E}$ may be associated with the matrix $\ketbra{v}{u}$. The \emph{adjacency matrix} of $G$ is the Hermitian matrix $\Adj(G) = \C^{\vtcs \times \vtcs}$  defined by
    \[
        \Adj(G) = \sum_{(u,v) \in \vec{E}} \ketbra{v}{u}.
    \]
plain_text_def:
Given an -vertex graph G = (V,E), we identify the vertices with an orthonormal basis of ^; the vector for vertex v is denoted |v⟩.[We are using the Dirac bra-ket notation, in which |v⟩ denotes a column vector and ⟨v| denotes its conjugate-transpose |v⟩^†.]  A directed edge (u,v) ∈E⃗ may be associated with the matrix |v⟩⟨u|. The adjacency matrix of G is the Hermitian matrix (G) = ^×  defined by
    
    (G) = ∑_(u,v) ∈E⃗|v⟩⟨u|.

def: The \textit{adjacency matrix} $A$ (alternatively $A(G)$) of a graph $G$ is the $n$ by $n$ matrix which has a $1$ in the $i$th row and $j$th column if there is an edge connecting vertices $i$ and $j$ and a $0$ otherwise.
plain_text_def: The adjacency matrix A (alternatively A(G)) of a graph G is the n by n matrix which has a 1 in the ith row and jth column if there is an edge connecting vertices i and j and a 0 otherwise.

def:
\label{def laplacian}
Let $\ga$ be a metrized graph with $e$ edges and an adequate vertex set
$\vv{\ga}$ containing $v$ vertices. Fix an ordering of the vertices
in $\vv{\ga}$. Let $\{L_1, L_2, \cdots, L_e\}$ be a labeling of the
edge lengths. The matrix $\am=(a_{pq})_{v \times v}$ given by
\[
a_{pq}=\begin{cases} 0, & \quad \text{if $p = q$, or $p$ and $q$ are
not adjacent}.\\
\frac{1}{L_k}, & \quad \text{if $p \not= q$, and an edge of length $L_k$ connects $p$ and $q$.}\\
%$p$ and $q$ are connected by} \text{ an edge of length $L_k$}\\
\end{cases}
\]
is called the \textit{adjacency matrix} of $\ga$. Let $\dm=\diag(d_{pp})$ be
the $v \times v$ diagonal matrix given by $d_{pp}=\sum_{s \in
\vv{\ga}}a_{ps}$. Then $\lm:=\dm-\am$ is called the \textit{discrete
Laplacian matrix} of $\ga$. That is, $ \lm =(l_{pq})_{v \times v}$ where
\[
l_{pq}=\begin{cases} 0, & \; \, \text{if $p \not= q$, and $p$ and $q$
are not adjacent}.\\
-\frac{1}{L_k}, & \; \, \text{if $p \not= q$, and $p$ and $q$ are
connected by} \text{ an edge of length $L_k$}\\
-\sum_{s \in \vv{\ga}-\{p\}}l_{ps}, & \; \, \text{if $p=q$}
\end{cases}.
\]
%
plain_text_def:
Let  be a metrized graph with e edges and an adequate vertex set
 containing v vertices. Fix an ordering of the vertices
in . Let {L_1, L_2, ⋯, L_e} be a labeling of the
edge lengths. The matrix =(a_pq)_v × v given by

    a_pq= 0,      if p = q, or p and q are
    not adjacent.
    1/L_k,      if p ≠ q, and an edge of length L_k connects p and q.

is called the adjacency matrix of . Let =(d_pp) be
the v × v diagonal matrix given by d_pp=∑_s ∈a_ps. Then :=- is called the discrete
Laplacian matrix of . That is, =(l_pq)_v × v where

    l_pq= 0,      if p ≠ q, and p and q
    are not adjacent.
    
    -1/L_k,      if p ≠ q, and p and q are
    connected by an edge of length L_k
    
    -∑_s ∈-{p}l_ps,      if p=q.

def:
Let $G$ be a directed graph.
The \emph{adjacency matrix} , \(A_G\), of $G$
is the 
square matrix indexed on the vertices, $V_G$, whose \( (v_1, v_2) \)
entry is the number of directed edges whose tail is the vertex \(v_1\) and
whose 
head is the vertex \(v_2\). 
The {\em indegree} (respectively {\em outdegree}) of a vertex, $v$,
of $G$ is the number
of edges whose head (respectively tail) is $v$.

The adjacency matrix of an undirected graph, $G$, is
simply the adjacency matrix of its underlying directed graph. 
For an undirected graph, the indegree of any vertex equals its outdegree,
and is just called its {\em degree}.
The {\em degree matrix} of $G$ is the diagonal matrix, 
$D_G$, indexed on $V_G$
whose $(v,v)$ entry is the degree of $v$.
We say that $G$ is {\em $d$-regular} if $D_G$ is $d$ times the identity
matrix, i.e., if each vertex of $G$ has degree $d$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a directed graph.
The adjacency matrix , A_G, of G
is the 
square matrix indexed on the vertices, V_G, whose (v_1, v_2)
entry is the number of directed edges whose tail is the vertex v_1 and
whose 
head is the vertex v_2. 
The indegree (respectively outdegree) of a vertex, v,
of G is the number
of edges whose head (respectively tail) is v.

The adjacency matrix of an undirected graph, G, is
simply the adjacency matrix of its underlying directed graph. 
For an undirected graph, the indegree of any vertex equals its outdegree,
and is just called its degree.
The degree matrix of G is the diagonal matrix, 
D_G, indexed on V_G
whose (v,v) entry is the degree of v.
We say that G is d-regular if D_G is d times the identity
matrix, i.e., if each vertex of G has degree d.

def:
\label{def laplacian}
Let $\ga$ be a metrized graph with $e$ edges and with an optimal vertex set
$\vv{\ga}$ containing $v$ vertices. Fix an ordering of the vertices
in $\vv{\ga}$. Let $\{L_1, L_2, \cdots, L_e\}$ be a labeling of the
edge lengths. The matrix $\am=(a_{pq})_{v \times v}$ given by
\[
a_{pq}=\begin{cases} 0 & \quad \text{if $p = q$, or $p$ and $q$ are
not adjacent}.\\
\frac{1}{L_k} & \quad \text{if $p \not= q$, and $p$ and $q$ are
connected
by} \text{ an edge of length $L_k$}\\
\end{cases}
\]
is called the \textit{adjacency matrix} of $\ga$. Let $\dm=\diag(d_{pp})$ be
the $v \times v$ diagonal matrix given by $d_{pp}=\sum_{s \in
\vv{\ga}}a_{ps}$. Then $\lm:=\dm-\am$ is called the \textit{discrete
Laplacian matrix} of $\ga$. That is, $ \lm =(l_{pq})_{v \times v}$ where
\[
l_{pq}=\begin{cases} 0 & \; \, \text{if $p \not= q$, and $p$ and $q$
are not adjacent}.\\
-\frac{1}{L_k} & \; \, \text{if $p \not= q$, and $p$ and $q$ are
connected by} \text{ an edge of length $L_k$}\\
-\sum_{s \in \vv{\ga}-\{p\}}l_{ps} & \; \, \text{if $p=q$}
\end{cases}.
\]
%
plain_text_def:
Let  be a metrized graph with e edges and with an optimal vertex set
 containing v vertices. Fix an ordering of the vertices
in . Let {L_1, L_2, ⋯, L_e} be a labeling of the
edge lengths. The matrix =(a_pq)_v × v given by

    a_pq= 0      if p = q, or p and q are
    not adjacent.
    1/L_k     if p ≠ q, and p and q are
    connected
    by an edge of length L_k

is called the adjacency matrix of . Let =(d_pp) be
the v × v diagonal matrix given by d_pp=∑_s ∈a_ps. Then :=- is called the discrete
Laplacian matrix of . That is, =(l_pq)_v × v where

    l_pq= 0      if p ≠ q, and p and q
    are not adjacent.
    
    -1/L_k     if p ≠ q, and p and q are
    connected by an edge of length L_k
    
    -∑_s ∈-{p}l_ps     if p=q.

Let 𝒢 be a graph with vertex set V(𝒢)={v_1,…, v_n}. We call adjacency matrix A={a_ij},   i,j=1,…, n, associated to 𝒢 the n× n matrix such that:



  * a_ij = 1, if {v_i,v_j}∈  E(𝒢)


  * a_ij = 0, if {v_i,v_j}∉  E(𝒢).

The adjacency tensor of a k-uniform hypergraph H, denoted by 𝒜_H, is an order k dimension |V(H)| tensor with entries

    a_i_1i_2⋯ i_k=1/(k-1)!        i_1i_2⋯ i_k∈ E(H),
    
    0             .

Let 𝒟_H be an order k dimension |V(H)| diagonal tensor whose diagonal entries are vertex degrees of H. The tensors ℒ_H=𝒟_H-𝒜_H and 𝒬_H=𝒟_H+𝒜_H are the Laplacian tensor and the signless Laplacian tensor of H, respectively. Eigenvalues of 𝒜_H, ℒ_H and 𝒬_H are called eigenvalues, Laplacian eigenvalues and signless Laplacian eigenvalues of H, respectively. Characteristic polynomials of ℒ_H and 𝒬_H are called Laplacian polynomial and signless Laplacian polynomial of H, respectively.

The adjacency tensor of a hypergraph H with r(H)=k, denoted by 𝒜_H, is an order k dimension |V(H)| symmetric tensor with entries

    a_i_1i_2⋯ i_k=1/(k-1)!     {i_1,…,i_k}∈ E(H),
    (k-s+1)!/k!  {i_1,…,i_k}={j_1^(k-s+1),j_2,…,j_s}, {j_1,…,j_s}∈ E(H),
    
    0           ,

where s<k and j_1^(k-s+1) means that the multiplicity of j_1 is k-s+1. Let 𝒟_H denote the order k dimension |V(H)| diagonal tensor whose diagonal entries are vertex degrees of H. The tensors ℒ_H=𝒟_H-𝒜_H and 𝒬_H=𝒟_H+𝒜_H are the Laplacian tensor and the signless Laplacian tensor of H, respectively.

def:
\label{dfn:compatible}
We say that two compatible trees $T,T'$ are \emph{adjacent} if $\LDm(T)+e_i=\LDm(T')+e_{i'}$ for some $i,i'\in[m]$.
plain_text_def: We say that two compatible trees T,T' are adjacent if (T)+e_i=(T')+e_i' for some i,i'∈[m].

def:
Two vertices in a graph are \emph{adjacent} if an edge connects them.  A
  {\it clique} in a graph is a set of pairwise adjacent vertices.  An
  {\it independent set} in a graph is a set of pairwise nonadjacent
  vertices.
plain_text_def:
Two vertices in a graph are adjacent if an edge connects them.  A
  clique in a graph is a set of pairwise adjacent vertices.  An
  independent set in a graph is a set of pairwise nonadjacent
  vertices.

def:
\textbf{Edge relation, on~${\mathfrak {ST}}$}\\

\noindent Given a natural integer~$m$, two points~$X$ and~$Y$ of~${\mathfrak {ST}}_m$ will be said to be \textbf{adjacent} if and only if~$X$ and~$Y$ are two consecutive vertices of~${\mathfrak {ST}}_m$. We will write:


$$X \underset{m }{\sim}  Y$$


\noindent This edge relation ensures the existence of a word~{${\cal W}=\left ( {\cal W}_1, \hdots, {\cal W}_m\right)$} of length~$ m$, such that~$X$ and~$Y$ both belong to the iterate:

$$f_{\cal W} \,V_0=\left (f_{{\cal W}_1} \circ \hdots \circ  f_{{\cal W}_m} \right) \,V_0$$



 \noindent Given two points~$X$ and~$Y$ of the graph~$\mathfrak {ST}$, we will say that~$X$ and~$Y$ are \textbf{\emph{adjacent}} if and only if there exists a natural integer~$m$ such that:
$$X  \underset{m }{\sim}  Y$$
plain_text_def:
Edge relation, on 𝔖𝔗


Given a natural integer m, two points X and Y of 𝔖𝔗_m will be said to be adjacent if and only if X and Y are two consecutive vertices of 𝔖𝔗_m. We will write:



    X m ∼  Y



This edge relation ensures the existence of a word W= (  W_1, ,  W_m) of length m, such that X and Y both belong to the iterate:


    f_ W V_0= (f_ W_1∘∘  f_ W_m)  V_0




 Given two points X and Y of the graph 𝔖𝔗, we will say that X and Y are adjacent if and only if there exists a natural integer m such that:

    X  m ∼  Y

def: Let $G$ be a graph. Two vertices are \textit{adjacent} if they share an edge.
plain_text_def: Let G be a graph. Two vertices are adjacent if they share an edge.

def:
Let $\pi=\pi_1|\pi_2|\dots|\pi_k$ be a partition.  A proper
  subset $M$ of some part $\pi_j$ in $\pi$ with $j<k$ is
  \emph{admissible} with respect to a partition
  $\mu=\mu_1|\mu_2|\dots|\mu_r$ if $\min
  M>\max\pi_{j+1}$ and, supposing that $\min M$ occurs in $\mu_k$,
  then $\pi_{j+1}\cap\bigcup_{t=k}^r \mu_r=\emptyset$.

  An $M$-shift of a partition $\pi$ with respect to a partition
  $\mu$, with $M$ an admissible subset of $\pi_j$ with respect to
  $\mu$, is the operation that returns the new partition
  $\pi_1|\dots|\pi_j\setminus M|\pi_{j+1}\cup M|\dots|\pi_k$.
plain_text_def:
Let π=π_1|π_2|…|π_k be a partition.  A proper
  subset M of some part π_j in π with j<k is
  admissible with respect to a partition
  μ=μ_1|μ_2|…|μ_r if min
  M>maxπ_j+1 and, supposing that min M occurs in μ_k,
  then π_j+1∩⋃_t=k^r μ_r=∅.

  An M-shift of a partition π with respect to a partition
  μ, with M an admissible subset of π_j with respect to
  μ, is the operation that returns the new partition
  π_1|…|π_j∖ M|π_j+1∪ M|…|π_k.

def:
Let a subset $S$ of the six colors $\{$red, blue, green, orange, yellow, silver$\}$ (abbreviated $\{r,b,g,o,y,s\}$) be called \emph{admissible} if all of the following are true:
\begin{itemize}
\item If $\{r,b\}\subseteq S$ then $g\in S$ 
\item If $\{o,s\}\subseteq S$ then $b\in S$ 
\item If $\{s,y\}\subseteq S$ then $g\in S$ 
\item If $\{r,o\}\subseteq S$ then $y\in S$
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Let a subset S of the six colors {red, blue, green, orange, yellow, silver} (abbreviated {r,b,g,o,y,s}) be called admissible if all of the following are true:


  * If {r,b}⊆ S then g∈ S 

  * If {o,s}⊆ S then b∈ S 

  * If {s,y}⊆ S then g∈ S 

  * If {r,o}⊆ S then y∈ S

We call a triple of pairs

    {.  (p_i,q_i)∈ℤ^2| 1≤
    i≤3}  , 0≤ p_i<q_i, with (p_i,q_i)=1,∀
    i∈{1,2,3},

admissible whenever it satisfies both divisibility conditions

    q_1q_2|p_1q_2+p_2q_1+q_3

and

    q_1q_3| p_1q_3+p_3q_1+q_2

A Wilson loop diagram  is admissible if the following hold:


  (i) for all ⊆, | ⋃_Q ∈ Q' | ≥ || + 3, and

  (ii) if P = (i_P, j_P), Q = (i_Q, j_Q) ∈ are two propagators, then i_P < i_Q < j_Q < j_P in the cyclic ordering of [n].

def:
\label{admissible}
Given the unit square $D$ and a boundary condition $h^{\partial}$ defined on $\partial D$, a function $h$ is called \emph{admissible} if it is horizontally $\frac{1}{2}$-Lipschitz, vertically non decreasing, and when restricted on $\partial D$ it is equal to $h^{\partial}$. Denote by $\mathcal{H}$ the space of admissible functions.
plain_text_def: Given the unit square D and a boundary condition h^∂ defined on ∂ D, a function h is called admissible if it is horizontally 1/2-Lipschitz, vertically non decreasing, and when restricted on ∂ D it is equal to h^∂. Denote by ℋ the space of admissible functions.

def:
A path $i=i_0,\ldots,i_r=j$ with $i<j$ in a simple graph on $[n]$ is called \textit{admissible} , if \begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item $i_l \neq i_k$ for $k \neq l$
\item for each $k=1,\ldots,r-1$ one has either $i_k<i$ or $i_k>j$
\item for any proper subset $\{j_1,\ldots,j_s\}$ of $\{i_1,\ldots,i_{r-1}\}$, the sequence $i,j_1,\ldots,j_s,j$ is not a path.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A path i=i_0,…,i_r=j with i<j in a simple graph on [n] is called admissible , if 

  * i_l ≠ i_k for k ≠ l

  * for each k=1,…,r-1 one has either i_k<i or i_k>j

  * for any proper subset {j_1,…,j_s} of {i_1,…,i_r-1}, the sequence i,j_1,…,j_s,j is not a path.

def:
Let $w = l_1 \cdots l_n$ be a word and $\pi$ a non-crossing half-pairing of $[n]$. We say
that $\pi$ is $w$-\textit{admissible} if it is a $w$-pairing and we have for all $i$ and
$j$, $l_i \not = l_j^{-1}$ whenever $i$ covers $j$.
plain_text_def:
Let w = l_1 ⋯ l_n be a word and π a non-crossing half-pairing of [n]. We say
that π is w-admissible if it is a w-pairing and we have for all i and
j, l_i ≠ l_j^-1 whenever i covers j.

Let a subset S of the six colors {red, blue, green, orange, yellow, silver} (abbreviated {r,b,g,o,y,s}) be  admissible if all of the following are true: 


If {r,b}⊆ S then g∈ S, if  {o,s}⊆ S then b∈ S, if {s,y}⊆ S then g∈ S, and if {r,o}⊆ S then y∈ S.

def:
Let $Q$ be a lattice polytope in $\Q^3$. A lattice
  Minkowski decomposition $Q = Q_1 + \cdots + Q_r$ of $Q$ is called
  \emph{admissible} if each $Q_i$ is either a length-one line segment
  or an $A_n$~triangle. Given an admissible Minkowski decomposition $Q
  = Q_1 + \cdots + Q_r$ of $Q$, we set
  \[
  f_{Q : Q_1,\ldots,Q_r} = \prod_{i=1}^{r} f_{Q_i}.
  \]
  Observe that the Newton polytope of $f_{Q : Q_1,\ldots,Q_r}$ is
  $Q$. Observe also that if
  \begin{gather*}
    Q = Q_1 + \cdots + Q_r, \qquad Q = Q'_1 + \cdots + Q'_s
  \end{gather*}
  are equivalent lattice Minkowski decompositions of $Q$, then $f_{Q
    : Q_1,\ldots,Q_r} = f_{Q : Q'_1,\ldots,Q'_s}$.
plain_text_def:
Let Q be a lattice polytope in ^3. A lattice
  Minkowski decomposition Q = Q_1 + ⋯ + Q_r of Q is called
  admissible if each Q_i is either a length-one line segment
  or an A_n triangle. Given an admissible Minkowski decomposition Q
  = Q_1 + ⋯ + Q_r of Q, we set
  
    f_Q : Q_1,…,Q_r = ∏_i=1^r f_Q_i.

  Observe that the Newton polytope of f_Q : Q_1,…,Q_r is
  Q. Observe also that if
  
    Q = Q_1 + ⋯ + Q_r,      Q = Q'_1 + ⋯ + Q'_s

  are equivalent lattice Minkowski decompositions of Q, then f_Q
    : Q_1,…,Q_r = f_Q : Q'_1,…,Q'_s.

We call values for a parameter (or a set of parameters) admissible , if there exists at least one graph 
  satisfying these values for the corresponding parameters.

def:
\label{def:admissible}
An inversion $(i,j)\in\Inv\,\pi$ is \emph{admissible} if either $\pi(j)<\pi(j+1)$ or $\pi(j)>\pi(k)$ for some $i<k<j$. Let $\Ai\,\pi$ be the set of admissible inversions of $\pi$, and let
\[
\ai\,\pi=|\Ai\,\pi|, \qquad \aid\,\pi=\ai\,\pi+\des\,\pi.
\]
plain_text_def:
An inversion (i,j)∈ π is admissible if either π(j)<π(j+1) or π(j)>π(k) for some i<k<j. Let π be the set of admissible inversions of π, and let

    π=| π|,      π= π+ π.

A word z ∈^* is admissible if either |z| ≤ 1
    or we have z_1 - 1 ≤ z_2, and the word obtained by applying the
    substitution
    
    z_1 . z_2 ⟶max{z_1, z_2} + 1    if z_1 - 1 ≤ z_2 ≤ z_1 + 1,
    
                z_2    otherwise

    to z is admissible. Let us denote by  the set of
    admissible words.

[<cit.>] 

The following identities hold.

    T(G; k/b+1 ,kb+1)    =  ∑   (b+1)^(ϕ)     b^(ϕ),
    
    
     k^κ(G)  R(G;k+1,k,1/k,1)    = ∑ 2^(ϕ),
    
         k^κ(G)  b^r(G)   R(G;  (k+b)/b, bk, 1/k)       = ∑   (b+1)^(ϕ)     b^(ϕ),
    
    
    P(G;k)    =  #Admissible k-valuations of  G_m,
    
    
    P(G;k)    = ∑  (-1)^(ϕ),
    
    
    P(G;-k)    = (-1)^f(G)∑  2^(ϕ),
    
    
      Q(G; ( α, β , γ ), k)    = ∑   (α+β+γ)^(ϕ)α^(ϕ)β^(ϕ)γ^(ϕ).

Here the sums in (<ref>)–(<ref>) are over all k-valuations ϕ of G_m that contain no crossing configurations. An admissible k-valuation is one that contains no black configurations, and the sums in (<ref>) and (<ref>) are over all admissible k-valuations of G_m. The sum in (<ref>) is over all k-valuations ϕ of G_m. Furthermore,  in (<ref>) and (<ref>) G must be plane, and in (<ref>) the Petrie dual (defined in Section <ref>) of the geometric dual of G must be orientable for the identity to hold.

def: We say that a $\{1,2\}$-composition of $n$ is \emph{admissible} if it is in the image of $\phi$.
plain_text_def: We say that a {1,2}-composition of n is admissible if it is in the image of ϕ.

def: Let $\tilde{B} = (b_{ij})$ be a $2n \times n$ matrix with automorphism group $G$.  We say that $\tilde{B}$ is \emph{admissible} if $b_{ij} = 0$ whenever $i, j$ are in the same $G$-orbit of $I$.  (Equivalently, if $B$ is the principal part of $\tilde{B}$, then admissibility means that there is no arrow between $i$ and $j$ in $Q(B)$ whenever $i, j$ are in the same $G$-orbit.)
plain_text_def: Let B̃ = (b_ij) be a 2n × n matrix with automorphism group G.  We say that B̃ is admissible if b_ij = 0 whenever i, j are in the same G-orbit of I.  (Equivalently, if B is the principal part of B̃, then admissibility means that there is no arrow between i and j in Q(B) whenever i, j are in the same G-orbit.)

Let =(u_0,…,u_N+M-1) be a sequence of 0's and 1's. We set

    I_:={Δ∈ I_M,N: ∀  0≤ i< N+M, i∈Δ⇔ u_i=1}.

We say that a sequence  is admissible if I_≠∅. Note that we number the entries of  starting at 0.

def:
\label{def:admissible} 
Suppose that $B$ is a skew-symmetrizable matrix and let $A$ be a quasi-Cartan companion of $B$. We say that $A$ is \emph{admissible} if it satisfies the following sign condition: for any cycle $Z$ in $\Gamma$, the product $\prod _{\{i,j\}\in Z}(-A_{i,j})$ over all edges of $Z$ is negative if $Z$ is oriented and positive if $Z$ is non-oriented.
plain_text_def: Suppose that B is a skew-symmetrizable matrix and let A be a quasi-Cartan companion of B. We say that A is admissible if it satisfies the following sign condition: for any cycle Z in Γ, the product ∏ _{i,j}∈ Z(-A_i,j) over all edges of Z is negative if Z is oriented and positive if Z is non-oriented.

def:
Necessary conditions for a $(v, g, k, \lambda)_q$-GDD are
\begin{enumerate}
\item $g$ divides $v$,
\item $k\leq v - g$,
\item the cardinalities in
(\ref{eq:nec}), (\ref{eq:nec2}) are integer numbers,
\item if $2 \leq g \leq k$ then $q^{k-g}$ divides $\lambda$.
\end{enumerate}
If these conditions are fulfilled,
the parameters $(v, g, k, \lambda)_q$ are called \emph{admissible} .
plain_text_def:
Necessary conditions for a (v, g, k, λ)_q-GDD are


  * g divides v,

  * k≤ v - g,

  * the cardinalities in
(<ref>), (<ref>) are integer numbers,

  * if 2 ≤ g ≤ k then q^k-g divides λ.

If these conditions are fulfilled,
the parameters (v, g, k, λ)_q are called admissible .

We call a monomial
 
    e_h,𝐩,𝐢=v_h e_p_1[i_1]… e_p_s[i_s]

admissible , if the following conditions are satisfied:

 
  * i_1≤-(h,f_p_1);
 
  * i_m+1≤ i_m+1 for all m=1,…,s-1;
 
  * if i_m+1=i_m+1, then p_m≤ p_m+1.

Clearly, 
 
    v_h e_p_1[-(h,f_1)]e_p_2[i_2]… e_p_s[i_s]=v_h+f_1 e_p_2[i_2]… e_p_s[i_s],

and in this case we think of these monomials as of the same monomial. Throughout this paper we mean by an admissible monomial the class of pairwise equal admissible monomials; we hope it will not lead to a confusion.

def: Given two reals $\alpha \in [\frac{1}{4},1)$ and $\beta > 0$, we say that $(\alpha, \beta)$ is an \emph{admissible pair} if every 2-connected non-bipartite graph $G = (V,E)$ with $|V|=n$ and \[ \delta(G) \ge \alpha n + \beta \] contains every cycle $C_t$, for every $t$ such that $6 \leq t \leq c(G)$.
plain_text_def:
Given two reals α∈ [1/4,1) and β > 0, we say that (α, β) is an admissible pair if every 2-connected non-bipartite graph G = (V,E) with |V|=n and 
    δ(G) ≥α n + β
 contains every cycle C_t, for every t such that 6 ≤ t ≤ c(G).

def:
Let $p$ be an odd prime.  Let $n$ and $s$ be positive integers such that $s < 2n$ and $\frac{2n}{s}$ is an odd integer.  
Let $d = p^s$ and $q= p^n$.  We call the pair $\{q,d \}$ an 
\emph{admissible pair} .
plain_text_def:
Let p be an odd prime.  Let n and s be positive integers such that s < 2n and 2n/s is an odd integer.  
Let d = p^s and q= p^n.  We call the pair {q,d } an 
admissible pair .

[Kwon]
For a single column C, let C(i) be the ith entry from the bottom and ht(C) its length.

Let T and U be two two-column skew semistandard tableaux with tails of length μ_T and μ_U such that μ_T≥μ_U>0 and residuum r_T≤ 1 and r_U≤ 1, respectively. The pair  (T,U) is admissible , if the following conditions are met: 

    ht(T^R) ≤ht(U^L)-μ_U+2r_Tr_U H


    T^R(i)≤^LU(i)      if   r_T· r_U=0A1
    
    T^R^*(i)≤^LU(i)      if   r_T· r_U=1


    ^RT(i+μ_T -μ_U)≤ U^L(i)       if  r_T· r_U=0A2
    ^RT(i+μ_T -μ_U)≤ U^L^*(i)       if  r_T· r_U=1


Let T be a two-column skew semistandard tableaux with tail of length μ_T>0 and residuum r_T≤ 1. Let S be a skew semistandard tableau of rectangular outer shape with first column S^L and columns with lengths of the same parity. The pair (T,S) is admissible , if the following conditions are met:

    ht(T^R) ≤ht(S^L)       if  S  is evenH'
    ht(T^R) ≤ht(S^L)-1+2r_T       otherwise


    T^R(i)≤S^L(i)      if S is even or   r_T=0 A1'
    
    T^R^*(i)≤S^L(i)      otherwise


    ^RT(i+μ_T-1)≤ S^L(i)       if S is odd and   r_T=0A2'
    ^RT(i+μ_T)≤ S^L(i)       otherwise

For a connected graph H, a subset A of _H is admissible to H if the following hold:


  (1) |A∩ V(H)|≡ 02 and each vertex incident to only simple edges of H is contained in A,

  (2) B∩ A≠∅ and |B∩ A|≡ 02 for each bundle B of H.

For a disconnected graph H, A⊂_H is admissible to H if  𝒞_H'∩ A  is admissible to  each component H' of H.

def: [\cite{Operads}] \label{defcog}An \emph{algebra} over an operad $\A$ is a vector space $A$ equipped with a $\mathfrak{S}_n$-equivariant morphism $m^n_A: \A(n) \otimes A^{\otimes n} \rightarrow A $. We denote the free algebra over an operad $\A$ whose vector space of generators is $V$ by $\A(V)$.
plain_text_def: [<cit.>] An algebra over an operad  is a vector space A equipped with a 𝔖_n-equivariant morphism m^n_A: (n) ⊗ A^⊗ n→ A. We denote the free algebra over an operad  whose vector space of generators is V by (V).

An (associative[There are also non-associative algebras, in which only the second and third conditions hold. Often, some alternative property is imposed: Lie algebras, in which the Jacobi identity is enforced, have a structure theory analogous to what we discuss in this section.]) algebra over the field k is a vector space 𝒜 over k together with a binary operation (multiplication) which satisfies the following conditions:

    
  * Associativity: A(BC) = (AB)C for all A, B, C ∈𝒜.
    
  * Distributivity: A(B+C) = AB + AC and (A+B)C = AC + BC for all A, B, C ∈𝒜.
    
  * Scalar compatibility: (cA)(dB) = cdAB for all c, d ∈ k and all A, B ∈𝒜.

def:
Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a finite set called the \emph{alphabet} . By a
language $L$ over $\mathcal{A}$ we always mean a factorial
extendable language: a language is a collection of sets
$(L_n)_{n\geq 0}$ where the only element of $L_0$ is the empty
word, and each $L_n$ consists of words of the form $a_1a_2\dots
a_n$ where $a_i\in\mathcal{A}$ and such that for each $v\in L_n$
there exist $a,b\in\mathcal{A}$ with $av,vb\in L_{n+1}$, and for
all $v\in L_{n+1}$ if $v=au=u'b$ with $a,b\in\mathcal{A}$ then
$u,u'\in L_n$.
plain_text_def:
Let 𝒜 be a finite set called the alphabet . By a
language L over 𝒜 we always mean a factorial
extendable language: a language is a collection of sets
(L_n)_n≥ 0 where the only element of L_0 is the empty
word, and each L_n consists of words of the form a_1a_2…
a_n where a_i∈𝒜 and such that for each v∈ L_n
there exist a,b∈𝒜 with av,vb∈ L_n+1, and for
all v∈ L_n+1 if v=au=u'b with a,b∈𝒜 then
u,u'∈ L_n.

A finite word w with alphabet (w) :=, || ≥ 2, is said to be a generalized trapezoidal word (or GT-word for short) if there exist positive integers m, M with m ≤ M such that the factor complexity funtion C_w(n) of w increases by 1 for each n in the interval [1,m], is constant for each n in the interval [m,M], and decreases by 1 for each n in the interval [M,|w|]. That is, w is a GT-word if there exist positive integers m, M with m ≤ M such that C_w satisfies the following:



C_w(0)=1,      
 
C_w(i) = || + i - 1      for 1 ≤ i ≤ m, 

C_w(i+1)=C_w(i)          for m ≤ i ≤ M-1, 

C_w(i+1)=C_w(i)-1        for M ≤ i ≤ |w|.

def:
[Alternating elements]
The element $h_0\tens\cdots\tens h_r$ of~$S_r$
is \emph{alternating} if $h_{i+1}\ne h_i$ for all $0\le i<r$.
plain_text_def:
[Alternating elements]
The element h_0⋯ h_r of S_r
is alternating if h_i+1 h_i for all 0≤ i<r.

def:
For a path or cycle $H$ and a matching $M$ in a bipartite graph $\Gamma$, we say $H$ is $M$-\emph{alternating} if $E(H) \setminus M$ is a matching.
%and $|E(H) \setminus M| \geq |E(H) \cap M|$.
plain_text_def: For a path or cycle H and a matching M in a bipartite graph Γ, we say H is M-alternating if E(H) ∖ M is a matching.

def:
\cite{GolHiLew}\label{th9} A matching $M$ in a graph $G$ is uniquely
restricted if and only if $G$ contains no alternating cycle with respect to
$M$, i.e., $M$ is \textit{alternating} cycle-free.
plain_text_def:
<cit.> A matching M in a graph G is uniquely
restricted if and only if G contains no alternating cycle with respect to
M, i.e., M is alternating cycle-free.

def:
\cite{GolHiLew}\label{th9} A matching is uniquely restricted if and only if it
is \textit{alternating} cycle-free.
plain_text_def:
<cit.> A matching is uniquely restricted if and only if it
is alternating cycle-free.

def:
Let $W$ be a complex reflection group acting on a complex vector space of dimension $n$. We call a polynomial $p \in \mathbb{C}[\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}]$ \emph{alternating} if
		$$ \det(\omega) \omega(p) = p \hspace{10pt} \text{for all } \omega \in W.$$
plain_text_def:
Let W be a complex reflection group acting on a complex vector space of dimension n. We call a polynomial p ∈ℂ[𝐱,𝐲] alternating if
		
    (ω) ω(p) = p for all ω∈ W.

def: The \emph{alternating cycle} $\cC_{2k}^{\text{alt}}$ is a interval 2-chromatic ordering of $C_{2k}$ such that $I_1=\{a_1,...,a_k\}$, $I_2=\{b_k,...,b_1\}$, and $E(C_{2k}^{\text{alt}})=\{a_ib_j:|i-j|= 1\}\cup\{a_1b_1,a_kb_k\}$.
plain_text_def: The alternating cycle _2k^alt is a interval 2-chromatic ordering of C_2k such that I_1={a_1,...,a_k}, I_2={b_k,...,b_1}, and E(C_2k^alt)={a_ib_j:|i-j|= 1}∪{a_1b_1,a_kb_k}.

def: An \emph{alternating cycle} is a cycle in a graph which has been coloured such that each vertex of the cycle is incident with two edges in the cycle of opposite colour.
plain_text_def: An alternating cycle is a cycle in a graph which has been coloured such that each vertex of the cycle is incident with two edges in the cycle of opposite colour.

def: An \emph{alternating sign matrix} (ASM) is a square matrix with entries 0, 1, or $-1$ whose rows and columns each sum to 1 and such that the nonzero entries in each row and column alternate in sign.
plain_text_def: An alternating sign matrix (ASM) is a square matrix with entries 0, 1, or -1 whose rows and columns each sum to 1 and such that the nonzero entries in each row and column alternate in sign.
An alternating sign matrix (ASM) of order n is an n× n matrix with entries 0, 1, or -1 whose rows and columns sum to 1 and whose nonzero entries in each row and column alternate in sign.

def:
[\cite{MRRASMDPP}]
An \emph{alternating sign matrix (ASM)} is a square matrix with entries in $\{0, 1, -1\}$ whose rows and columns each sum to one and such that the nonzero entries along each row or column alternate in sign.
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
An alternating sign matrix (ASM) is a square matrix with entries in {0, 1, -1} whose rows and columns each sum to one and such that the nonzero entries along each row or column alternate in sign.

def: An \emph{alternating sign matrix (ASM)} is a ${(0,1,-1)}$-matrix in which all row and column sums are $1$, and the non-zero elements in each row and column alternate in sign.
plain_text_def: An alternating sign matrix (ASM) is a (0,1,-1)-matrix in which all row and column sums are 1, and the non-zero elements in each row and column alternate in sign.

Let φ,ψ:{0,1}^*→{0,1}^* be two morphisms.
  We say that φ is amicable to ψ, and denote it by
  φ∝ψ, if the three following
  relations hold
  
    φ(0)   ∝ψ(0) ,
    φ(1)   ∝ψ(1) ,
    φ(01)   ∝ψ(10) .

  The morphism η:{A,B,C}^*→{A,B,C}^* given by

    η(A)     :=ter(φ(0),ψ(0)) , 
    η(B)     :=ter(φ(01),ψ(10)) , 
    η(C)     :=ter(φ(1),ψ(1)) ,

is called the ternarization of φ and ψ and denoted by
η:=ter(φ,ψ).

def: Two complex matrices $A$ and $B$ are called \textit{amicable} if $AB^* = BA^*$.
plain_text_def: Two complex matrices A and B are called amicable if AB^* = BA^*.

def:
[\cite{BGH}]
If $A$ is a real-symmetric matrix with nonzero off-diagonal entries corresponding to the edges of $G$ \emph{and} $A$ has at most $q$ negative eigenvalues, then $\nullity(A)\le Z_q(G)$.
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
If A is a real-symmetric matrix with nonzero off-diagonal entries corresponding to the edges of G and A has at most q negative eigenvalues, then (A)≤ Z_q(G).

def: \label{cor:ogf}If $\bc Y=\bc H({\mathcal Z},\bc Y)$ is  well founded, where ${\bc H}$ is a constructible species, then it defines a species whose exponential \emph{and} ordinary generating series are analytic in the neighborhood of the origin.
plain_text_def: If Y= H(𝒵, Y) is  well founded, where H is a constructible species, then it defines a species whose exponential and ordinary generating series are analytic in the neighborhood of the origin.

def:
\label{ThLengthDivisible}
{\bf a)} Let $r\geq 3$ be an integer. For every $k \geq 1$, there
exists a minimum integer $f_r(k)$ such that every graph of minimum
degree at least $f_r(k)$ contains $k$ vertex-disjoint cycles of
different lengths all divisible by $r$. \newline {\bf b)} We have
$f_r(k)\leq\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
k(k+1)r-1,      & \mbox{if } r \mbox{ is even};\\
(k^2+2k-1)r-1,  & \mbox{if both } k \mbox{ and } r \mbox{ are odd};\\
k(k+2)r-1,      & \mbox{if } k \mbox{ is even and } r \mbox{ is
odd},
\end{array}\right.$ \\
${\rm ~ ~  ~  ~ ~~~~~~\textit{and}}~f_r(k)\geq\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\dfrac{k(k+1)r}{2}-1,      & \mbox{if } r \mbox{ is even};\\
\dfrac{k(k+1)r}{2},      & \mbox{if } r \mbox{ is odd}.
\end{array}\right.$
plain_text_def:
a) Let r≥ 3 be an integer. For every k ≥ 1, there
exists a minimum integer f_r(k) such that every graph of minimum
degree at least f_r(k) contains k vertex-disjoint cycles of
different lengths all divisible by r. b) We have
f_r(k)≤{[     k(k+1)r-1,            r ;; (k^2+2k-1)r-1,         k  r ;;     k(k+2)r-1,         k  r , ]. 

and f_r(k)≥{[ k(k+1)r2-1,         r ;;   k(k+1)r2,         r . ].

def:
A monoid $M$ is \emph{aperiodic} if there is an integer $N>0$ such that for each $x\in M$,
$x^N=x^{N+1}$.
plain_text_def:
A monoid M is aperiodic if there is an integer N>0 such that for each x∈ M,
x^N=x^N+1.

def:
[Definition IV.5 from \cite{FS09}]
  Let $B(z)$ be a function analytic at 0. Then $B$ \emph{admits a
    span} of $d$ if for some $r\in\Nat$,
$$\{n\in \Nat: [z^n] B(z) \neq 0 \} \subseteq r+ d \Nat\enspace.$$
If the largest span that $B(z)$ admits is 1, then $B$ is
\emph{aperiodic} .
plain_text_def:
[Definition IV.5 from <cit.>]
  Let B(z) be a function analytic at 0. Then B admits a
    span of d if for some r∈,

    {n∈: [z^n] B(z) ≠ 0 }⊆ r+ d .

If the largest span that B(z) admits is 1, then B is
aperiodic .

For clarity purposes – we define inductively when a symbol appears in a formula: for an -formula ϕ, we say a symbol  (relation symbol in  or equality symbol) appears in ϕ if one of the following holds:
	
		
  * ϕ is atomic, of the form (a_1,…, a_n) for a_i terms in the language .
		
  * ϕ is of the form ψ,  ∃ x ψ or ∀ x ψ and  appears in ψ.
		
  * ϕ is of the form ψ_1 ψ_2, ψ_1 ψ_2 or ψ_1 →ψ_2 and   appears in one of ψ_1, ψ_2.

def:
\label{appearsdef}
A configuration $K$ \emph{appears} in a triangulation $T$ if $G(K)$ is spherically homeomorphic to an induced subgraph of $T$ such that the image of every vertex $v \in V(G(K))$ has degree $\gm_K(v)$ in $T$.
plain_text_def: A configuration K appears in a triangulation T if G(K) is spherically homeomorphic to an induced subgraph of T such that the image of every vertex v ∈ V(G(K)) has degree _K(v) in T.

def: An \emph{arc} $\gamma$ of a marked surface $S$ is a curve whose endpoints are marked points of $S$, and which does not intersect itself in the interior of $S$. The interior of the arc is disjoint from the boundary of $S$ and it does not cut out an unpunctured monogon or digon.
plain_text_def: An arc γ of a marked surface S is a curve whose endpoints are marked points of S, and which does not intersect itself in the interior of S. The interior of the arc is disjoint from the boundary of S and it does not cut out an unpunctured monogon or digon.

An arc  in (S,M) is a curve in S, considered up
to isotopy, such that: 


  (a) 
the endpoints of  are in M;

  (b) 
 does not cross itself, except that its endpoints may coincide;

  (c) 
except for the endpoints,  is disjoint from   the boundary of S; and

  (d) 
 does not cut out a monogon or a bigon.

def: Let $D$ be a (partially labelled) Dyck path of size $n+m$. We define its \emph{area word} to be the string of integers $a(D) = a_1(D) \cdots a_{n+m}(D)$ where $a_i(D)$ is the number of whole squares in the $i$-th row (counting from the bottom) between the path and the main diagonal.
plain_text_def: Let D be a (partially labelled) Dyck path of size n+m. We define its area word to be the string of integers a(D) = a_1(D) ⋯ a_n+m(D) where a_i(D) is the number of whole squares in the i-th row (counting from the bottom) between the path and the main diagonal.

def: Let $\pi$ be a square path ending east of size $m+n$. We define its \emph{area word} to be the sequence of integers $a(\pi) = (a_1(\pi),a_2(\pi), \cdots, a_{m+n}(\pi))$ such that the $i$-th vertical step of the path starts from the diagonal $y=x+a_i(\pi)$. For example the path in Figure~\ref{fig: labelled square} has area word $(0, \, -\!3, \, -\!3, \, -\!2, \, -\!2, \, -\!1, \, 0, \, 0)$.
plain_text_def: Let π be a square path ending east of size m+n. We define its area word to be the sequence of integers a(π) = (a_1(π),a_2(π), ⋯, a_m+n(π)) such that the i-th vertical step of the path starts from the diagonal y=x+a_i(π). For example the path in Figure <ref> has area word (0,   -3,   -3,   -2,   -2,   -1,   0,   0).

def:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
                  			\item If $p\in\mathcal{P}^{\circ\bullet}$ is a bracket, the projective partition $\Arg(p)$ which is obtained from $p$ by erasing in every row the left- and the rightmost point, is called the \emph{argument} of $p$. 
			\item Conversely, for each projective $a\in\mathcal P^{\circ\bullet}_{2,\mathrm{nb}}$ and every color $c\in\{\circ,\bullet\}$, denote by $\mathrm{Br}\left(c\mid a\mid \overline{c}\right)$ the bracket whose leftmost lower point is of color $c$ and which has the argument $a$. 
		\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
* If p∈𝒫^∘∙ is a bracket, the projective partition (p) which is obtained from p by erasing in every row the left- and the rightmost point, is called the argument of p. 
			
  * Conversely, for each projective a∈𝒫^∘∙_2,nb and every color c∈{∘,∙}, denote by Br(c| a|c) the bracket whose leftmost lower point is of color c and which has the argument a.

<cit.>
		
                  			
  * If p∈𝒫^∘∙ is a bracket, the projective partition which is obtained from p by erasing in every row the left- and the rightmost point, is called the argument of p. 
			
  * Conversely, for each projective a∈𝒫^∘∙_2,nb and every color c∈{∘,∙}, denote by Br(c| a|c) the bracket whose leftmost lower point is of color c and which has the argument a.

An arithmetic matroid is a triple M = (E,,m), such that (E,) is a matroid and m (E) →_+= 1,2,… is a function satisfying:
  
  
  (A1) for every X ⊆ E and e ∈ E, if (X∪{e}) = (X) then m(X ∪{e}) | m(X), otherwise m(X) | m(X ∪{e});
  
  
  (A2)  if (X,Y) is a molecule, with Y = X ⊔ T ⊔ F as in <Ref>, then
  
    m(X)   m(Y) = m(X ∪ T)   m(X ∪ F);

  
  
  (P) if (X,Y) is a molecule, then
  
    ∑_X ⊆ S ⊆ Y (-1)^|X ∪ F |-|S|  m(S) ≥ 0.

  
  We call m the multiplicity function .
  If M=(E,,m) only satisfies axioms (A1) and (A2), we say that M is a quasi-arithmetic matroid .
  If M satisfies only axiom (P), we say that it is a pseudo-arithmetic matroid .

def: If $P$ is a positroid and $\mathcal{I}$ is the Grassmann necklace associated to $P$, then we call $\pi_{\mathcal{I}}$ the decorated permutation \emph{associated} to $P$.
plain_text_def: If P is a positroid and ℐ is the Grassmann necklace associated to P, then we call π_ℐ the decorated permutation associated to P.

def:
\label{def:Pgraph}
Let $\mmG=(\mmN,\mmE)$ be a multidigraph with labeling $\pi\colon \mmE\rightarrow R$. Let $\mu\colon \mmE^-\rightarrow \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{E}^+)$ be a map. The pair $(\mmG,\mu)$ is an  \textbf{edge partition} if  
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item \label{cond1Pgraph} $\mmE=\mmE^+\sqcup \mmE^-$.
\item\label{cond2Pgraph} All cycles in $\mmG$ contain at most one edge in $\mmE^-$.
\item The map $\mu$ is such that for every $e\in\mmE^-$
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item\label{cond3aPgraph} if $e'\in\mu(e)$, then $s(e)=s(e')$,
\item\label{cond3bPgraph}  if $e'\in\mu(e)$, then every cycle containing $e'$ contains $t(e)$,
\item\label{cond3cPgraph} if $e\neq e'$, then $\mu(e)\cap\mu(e')=\emptyset$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{enumerate} 

\medskip
We say $\mmG$  a \textbf{P-graph} if there is an edge partition $(\mmG,\mu)$ such that  for every $e\in\mmE^-$,
\begin{enumerate}[(iv)]
\item \label{cond4Pgraph} $\pi(e)+\sum\limits_{e'\in\mu(e)}\pi(e')\in\Rnng$. 
\end{enumerate} 
In this case we say that the map $\mu$ is \emph{associated} with the P-graph $\mmG$.
plain_text_def:
Let =(,) be a multidigraph with labeling π→ R. Let μ^-→𝒫(ℰ^+) be a map. The pair (,μ) is an  edge partition if  


  *  =^+⊔^-.

  *  All cycles in  contain at most one edge in ^-.

  * The map μ is such that for every e∈^-


  *  if e'∈μ(e), then s(e)=s(e'),

  *   if e'∈μ(e), then every cycle containing e' contains t(e),

  *  if e≠ e', then μ(e)∩μ(e')=∅. 

 

We say   a P-graph if there is an edge partition (,μ) such that  for every e∈^-,


  *  π(e)+∑_e'∈μ(e)π(e')∈. 
 
In this case we say that the map μ is associated with the P-graph .

[Algebra]
  A unital associative algebra A over a field 𝕂 is a 𝕂-linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a product m :⊗→ satisfying the associativity condition:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(m⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   m∘(𝕀⊗ m)(Γ),

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(u⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   Γ=m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(Γ).

[Algebra]
  A unital associative algebra 𝒜 over a field 𝕂 is a 𝕂-linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a product m :⊗→ satisfying the associativity condition
    
    m∘(m⊗𝕀)(Γ)=m∘(𝕀⊗ m)(Γ), 
      for all
    Γ∈^⊗  3;

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying
    
    m∘(u⊗𝕀)(1⊗Γ)=Γ=m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(Γ⊗ 1),  for all Γ∈.

[Algebra]
  A unital associative algebra A over a field 𝕂 is a 𝕂-linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a product m :⊗→ satisfying the associativity condition:
    
    m∘(m⊗𝕀)()=   m∘(𝕀⊗ m)(),
     ∀∈^⊗  3,

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying:
    
    m∘(u⊗𝕀)(1⊗)=   =m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(⊗ 1), ∀∈.

def: Every Nullstellensatz certificate of a non-3-colorable graph has degree \emph{at least} four.
plain_text_def: Every Nullstellensatz certificate of a non-3-colorable graph has degree at least four.

def:
\label{mpiethm}
Let $S$ be an $n$-set and $E_1,E_2,...E_d$ not necessarily distinct subsets
of $S$. For any subset $M$ of $[d]$, define $N(M)$ to be the number of
elements of $S$ in $\cap_{i\in M} E_i$ and for $0\leq j \leq d$, define
$N_j := \sum_{|M|=j} N(M)$. Then the number $N_{\geq a}$ of elements of $S$ in
\emph{at least} $a$, $0\leq a\leq d$ of the sets $E_i$, $1\leq i\leq d$, is
$$ N_{\geq a} = \sum_{i=0}^{d-a} (-1)^i {{a+i-1}\choose i}N_{i+a} \;\;\;\; ...  \;\;\;\; (MPIE)$$
plain_text_def:
Let S be an n-set and E_1,E_2,...E_d not necessarily distinct subsets
of S. For any subset M of [d], define N(M) to be the number of
elements of S in ∩_i∈ M E_i and for 0≤ j ≤ d, define
N_j := ∑_|M|=j N(M). Then the number N_≥ a of elements of S in
at least a, 0≤ a≤ d of the sets E_i, 1≤ i≤ d, is

    N_≥ a = ∑_i=0^d-a (-1)^i a+i-1 iN_i+a     ...       (MPIE)

def:
\label{def:sym} \textbf{(Graph Automorphism)}
    An \emph{automorphism} $\phi$ of graph $G=(V,E,\omega)$ is a permutation of the graph's vertex set $V$ such that the graph's weighted adjacency matrix $M=M(G)$ satisfies $M_{ij} = M_{\phi(i) \phi(j)}$ for each pair of vertices $i$ and $j$. We let $Aut(G)$ denote the the graph's group of automorphisms.
plain_text_def:
(Graph Automorphism)
    An automorphism ϕ of graph G=(V,E,ω) is a permutation of the graph's vertex set V such that the graph's weighted adjacency matrix M=M(G) satisfies M_ij = M_ϕ(i) ϕ(j) for each pair of vertices i and j. We let Aut(G) denote the the graph's group of automorphisms.

def: A partial-field \emph{automorphism} is an isomorphism $\phi:\parf\rightarrow\parf$.\index{partial field!automorphism|defi}
plain_text_def: A partial-field automorphism is an isomorphism ϕ:→.partial field!automorphism|defi

def: A function $\sigma$ is said to be an \textit{automorphism} of a graph $G$ if $\sigma$ permutes the vertices of $G$ while preserving incidence. The group (under composition) of all the automorphisms of $G$ is denoted $Aut(G)$.
plain_text_def: A function σ is said to be an automorphism of a graph G if σ permutes the vertices of G while preserving incidence. The group (under composition) of all the automorphisms of G is denoted Aut(G).

def: An \emph{automorphism} of a molecular graph $\gamma$ is a permutation of the vertices preserving adjacency, taking atoms of a given type to atoms of the same type (e.g., carbons go to carbons, oxygens go to oxygens, and so on).  $\mathrm{Aut}(\gamma)$ is defined as the group of automorphisms of $\gamma$.
plain_text_def: An automorphism of a molecular graph γ is a permutation of the vertices preserving adjacency, taking atoms of a given type to atoms of the same type (e.g., carbons go to carbons, oxygens go to oxygens, and so on).  Aut(γ) is defined as the group of automorphisms of γ.

def:
Suppose that $\mathcal{D} = (X,\B)$ is a $t$-$(v,k,\lambda)$-design.
An \emph{automorphism} of $\mathcal{D}$ is a permutation $\pi$ of $X$ such that
$\pi$ fixes the multiset $\B$. We denote the collection of all automorphisms of $\mathcal{D}$
by $\mathsf{Aut}(\mathcal{D})$.
plain_text_def:
Suppose that 𝒟 = (X,) is a t-(v,k,λ)-design.
An automorphism of 𝒟 is a permutation π of X such that
π fixes the multiset . We denote the collection of all automorphisms of 𝒟
by 𝖠𝗎𝗍(𝒟).

def:
Let $\fB$ be a $(K_n,\Gamma)$--design and let $\fB'$ be a
  $(K_n,\Gamma')$-design, with $\Gamma'\leq \Gamma$,
  and suppose $\xi:\fB\to\fB'$ to be a sampling.
  An \emph{automorphism} $\alpha$ of $\xi$
  is an automorphism of $\fB'$ and $\fB$ such that for any
  $B\in\fB$,
  \[ \xi(\alpha(B))=\alpha(\xi(B)). \]
plain_text_def:
Let  be a (K_n,Γ)–design and let ' be a
  (K_n,Γ')-design, with Γ'≤Γ,
  and suppose ξ:→' to be a sampling.
  An automorphism α of ξ
  is an automorphism of ' and  such that for any
  B∈,
  
    ξ(α(B))=α(ξ(B)).

def: Given an ordered 2-coloring $G$ and a $k$-coloring $H$, we say that $G$ \emph{avoids} $H$ if $G$ does not contain $H$.
plain_text_def: Given an ordered 2-coloring G and a k-coloring H, we say that G avoids H if G does not contain H.

def:
\label{avoidingDef}
A word $w$ \emph{avoids} a pattern if it does not contain it.
plain_text_def: A word w avoids a pattern if it does not contain it.

A full rook placement (R,F) avoids τ∈_k if and only if for every vertex V on the border of F, the permutation given by R ∩ Γ(V) avoids τ. Let _F(τ) be the set of full rook placements on F that avoid τ. Similarly, let

    _n(τ)= ⋃_F∈_n_F(τ).

def:
\label{badelement}
We say an element of a semiorder is \emph{bad} if the following two
conditions hold. 
\\$\bullet$ It is on the first level, or it is smaller than all
elements on the level immediately above it,  
\\and
\\$\bullet$ it is on the last level, or it is not larger than any
element on the level immediately below it.
plain_text_def:
We say an element of a semiorder is bad if the following two
conditions hold. 

∙ It is on the first level, or it is smaller than all
elements on the level immediately above it,  

and

∙ it is on the last level, or it is not larger than any
element on the level immediately below it.

def:
\label{def:bad}
Let~$F$,~$B$,~$Z$ be graphs with $Z\subseteq K_n$. An embedding $h\in \Psi_{B,n}$ is \textit{bad} (with respect to~$F$
and~$Z$) if one of the following holds
\begin{enumerate}[label=\Blabel]
\item\label{it:bad1} either there is a copy~$F_1$ of~$F$ in $Z \cup h(B)$ that contains at least one edge of 
$E(Z)\setminus E(h(B))$ and at least two edges of~$E(h(B))$,
\item\label{it:bad2} or there are distinct copies~$F_1$ and~$F_2$ of~$F$ in $Z\cup h(B)$ and edges $e$, $f_1\neq f_2$ with $e\in E(Z)\setminus E(h(B))$ and $e\in E(F_1)\cap E(F_2)$, $f_1, f_2\in E(h(B))$ such that $f_1\in E(F_1)$ and $f_2\in E(F_2)$
\item\label{it:bad3} or there are distinct copies~$F_1$ and~$F_2$ of~$F$ in $Z\cup h(B)$ and edges~$e,f$ with $e\in E(Z)\setminus E(h(B))$ and $e\in E(F_1)\cap E(F_2)$, $f\in E(h(B))$ and $f\in E(F_1)\cap E(F_2)$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let F, B, Z be graphs with Z⊆ K_n. An embedding h∈Ψ_B,n is bad (with respect to F
and Z) if one of the following holds


  *  either there is a copy F_1 of F in Z ∪ h(B) that contains at least one edge of 
E(Z)∖ E(h(B)) and at least two edges of E(h(B)),

  *  or there are distinct copies F_1 and F_2 of F in Z∪ h(B) and edges e, f_1≠ f_2 with e∈ E(Z)∖ E(h(B)) and e∈ E(F_1)∩ E(F_2), f_1, f_2∈ E(h(B)) such that f_1∈ E(F_1) and f_2∈ E(F_2)

  *  or there are distinct copies F_1 and F_2 of F in Z∪ h(B) and edges e,f with e∈ E(Z)∖ E(h(B)) and e∈ E(F_1)∩ E(F_2), f∈ E(h(B)) and f∈ E(F_1)∩ E(F_2).

def: A pair of distinct vertices $(x,y)$ in $G$ is said to be $(\ell,L)$-\emph{bad} for some $2 \leq \ell \leq 2k$ and some $L$ if there is an $L$-admissible, but not $L$-good, path of length $\ell$ from $x$ to $y$.
plain_text_def: A pair of distinct vertices (x,y) in G is said to be (ℓ,L)-bad for some 2 ≤ℓ≤ 2k and some L if there is an L-admissible, but not L-good, path of length ℓ from x to y.

def:
[Bad element]  Let $K \geq 1$, $x \in G$, and let $Q$ be a symmetric GAP in $G$.  We say that $x$ is \emph{bad} with respect to a symmetric GAP $Q$ if
$$|Q  + [-k,k] x | \ge K |Q|$$
and \emph{good} otherwise.
plain_text_def:
[Bad element]  Let K ≥ 1, x ∈ G, and let Q be a symmetric GAP in G.  We say that x is bad with respect to a symmetric GAP Q if

    |Q  + [-k,k] x | ≥ K |Q|

and good otherwise.

def: A $2$-path in $\partial H$ is called \emph{bad} if both of its edges are contained in a triangle of $\partial H$, otherwise it is called \emph{good} .
plain_text_def: A 2-path in ∂ H is called bad if both of its edges are contained in a triangle of ∂ H, otherwise it is called good .

def: Let $\Delta$ be a $(d-1)$-dimensional simplicial complex.  We say that $\Delta$ is \textit{balanced} if the vertices of $\Delta$ can be partitioned as $V(\Delta) = V_1 \amalg V_2 \amalg \cdots \amalg V_d$ in such a way that $|F \cap V_i|\leq 1$ for all faces $F \in \Delta$. (Here, $\amalg$ denotes the disjoint union.)
plain_text_def: Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex.  We say that Δ is balanced if the vertices of Δ can be partitioned as V(Δ) = V_1 ⨿ V_2 ⨿⋯⨿ V_d in such a way that |F ∩ V_i|≤ 1 for all faces F ∈Δ. (Here, ⨿ denotes the disjoint union.)

def:
[Balanced signature]
%  A signature $\sigma:E^{or}\to H$ is said to be \emph{balanced} if the
%  signature of every cycle of $G$ is (the conjugacy class of the) identity
%  element $id\in H$.
%
plain_text_def: [Balanced signature]

def:
[Balanced graph]\label{d:balanced graph}
A signed graph $\Gamma=(G,\eta)$ is called
\emph{balanced} if every cycle in
$\Gamma$  has positive sign.
%
plain_text_def:
[Balanced graph]
A signed graph Γ=(G,η) is called
balanced if every cycle in
Γ  has positive sign.

def: A set $T \subset \mathcal{C}(A)$ is called \textit{balanced} if it is possible to divide the set of orbits of elements of $T$ into disjoint sets $S_1,S_2,\ldots,S_{|A|}$ such that all orbits in $S_i$ have the same size and each element of $S_i$ overlaps with at least one other element of $S_i$. We will denote the size of the orbits in $S_i$ by $a_i$.
plain_text_def: A set T ⊂𝒞(A) is called balanced if it is possible to divide the set of orbits of elements of T into disjoint sets S_1,S_2,…,S_|A| such that all orbits in S_i have the same size and each element of S_i overlaps with at least one other element of S_i. We will denote the size of the orbits in S_i by a_i.

def:
\label{def:balanced}
Let $Q = (Q_0,Q_1)$ be an arbitrary quiver with no loops or $2$-cycles,
where $Q_0$ denotes the set of vertices of $Q$ and $Q_1$ the set of arrows.  
Given  $v\in\Z^{Q_0}$ and mutable vertex $\nu$, we define the quantity
\begin{equation}\label{e:excess}
	\overset{\circ}v_\nu := \sum_{\mu\to \nu} v_{\mu} - 
	\sum_{v\leftarrow \mu'} v_{\mu'},
\end{equation}
where the summands correspond to arrows in $Q$ 
to and from the vertex $\nu$, respectively. 
We say that $\nu$ is \emph{balanced} with respect to the pair $(v,Q)$
if $\overset{\circ}v_\nu = 0$.
plain_text_def:
Let Q = (Q_0,Q_1) be an arbitrary quiver with no loops or 2-cycles,
where Q_0 denotes the set of vertices of Q and Q_1 the set of arrows.  
Given  v∈^Q_0 and mutable vertex ν, we define the quantity

    ∘v_ν := ∑_μ→ν v_μ - 
    	∑_v←μ' v_μ',

where the summands correspond to arrows in Q 
to and from the vertex ν, respectively. 
We say that ν is balanced with respect to the pair (v,Q)
if ∘v_ν = 0.

def: A $d$-dimensional simplicial complex $\Delta$ on $[n]$ is \emph{balanced} if there is a map $\kappa:[n]\longrightarrow[d+1]$, such that $\kappa(i)\neq\kappa(j)$ for every $\left\lbrace i,j \right\rbrace\in\Delta$.
plain_text_def: A d-dimensional simplicial complex Δ on [n] is balanced if there is a map κ:[n]⟶[d+1], such that κ(i)≠κ(j) for every { i,j }∈Δ.

def:
[Balanced multisets of $\ZZ{m}$]
A multiset of $\ZZ{m}$ is said to be \textit{balanced} if it contains all the elements of $\ZZ{m}$ with the same multiplicity, i.e., if its associated multiplicity function $\m_M$ is constant on $\ZZ{m}$, equal to $\frac{1}{m}|M|$.
plain_text_def:
[Balanced multisets of m]
A multiset of m is said to be balanced if it contains all the elements of m with the same multiplicity, i.e., if its associated multiplicity function _M is constant on m, equal to 1/m|M|.

def: A set of dice is \emph{balanced} if $P(A \succ B) = P(B \succ C) = P(C \succ A)$.
plain_text_def: A set of dice is balanced if P(A ≻ B) = P(B ≻ C) = P(C ≻ A).

def: A graph is \textit{balanced} , if  it does not have any anchor. A graph $G$ is quasi-balanced, if for any anchor $H$ of $G$, $\vert V(H) \vert =\vert V(G) \vert -1$.
plain_text_def: A graph is balanced , if  it does not have any anchor. A graph G is quasi-balanced, if for any anchor H of G, | V(H) | =| V(G) | -1.

A tree T is balanced if for all node x of T, we have
    
    _T(x) ∈{-1, 0, 1}.

def:
A length-$n$ vector with alphabet size $g$ is  $ \textit{balanced} $ if each symbol occurs $ \lfloor n/g \rfloor $
or $ \lceil n/g \rceil $ times.
plain_text_def:
A length-n vector with alphabet size g is  balanced if each symbol occurs ⌊ n/g ⌋
or ⌈ n/g ⌉ times.

def:
\cite[Section III.4]{Sta3} A $(d+1)$-coloring of an  $(n,d)$-complex $\Gamma$
  is a map $\gamma:[n]\rightarrow [d+1]$ 
  such that $\gamma(w_1)\neq \gamma(w_2)$ for every
  edge $\{w_1,w_2\}$ of $\Gamma$. 
 If such a coloring exists, $\Gamma$ is called \emph{balanced} .
plain_text_def:
<cit.> A (d+1)-coloring of an  (n,d)-complex Γ
  is a map γ:[n]→ [d+1] 
  such that γ(w_1)≠γ(w_2) for every
  edge {w_1,w_2} of Γ. 
 If such a coloring exists, Γ is called balanced .

(Balanced Partitions)
Let M be an integer and suppose we have a sequence (A_i, B_i)_i=1^m
of (not necessarily distinct) partitions of [M]. We call this sequence of partitions balanced
if for any distinct j, j' ∈ [M], the number of 1 ≤ i ≤ m for which j and j'
lie in the same set of the partition (A_i, B_i) is at most 3m/4.

def:
A word $w$ (finite or infinite) over an alphabet $A$ is
\emph{balanced} if for every $a \in A$ and every pair $u, v$ of
factors of $w$ with $|u|=|v|$ we have
\[
|\,|u|_a - |v|_a\,| \leq 1.
\]
plain_text_def:
A word w (finite or infinite) over an alphabet A is
balanced if for every a ∈ A and every pair u, v of
factors of w with |u|=|v| we have

    | |u|_a - |v|_a | ≤ 1.

def:
\label{defbalanced}
	A $(d-1)$-dimensional simplicial complex $\Delta$ is \emph{balanced} if there is a partition of its vertex set $V(\Delta)=\displaystyle\bigcupdot_{i=1}^d V_i$ such that $\left| F\cap V_i\right|\leq 1$, for every $i=1,\dots,d$.
plain_text_def: A (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex Δ is balanced if there is a partition of its vertex set V(Δ)=_i=1^d V_i such that | F∩ V_i|≤ 1, for every i=1,…,d.

def:
A line~$\ell$ determined by two points of~$S$ is
\emph{balanced} if the two halfplanes it defines have weight
$\delta$. Observe that this implies that the two points of $S$
spanning $\ell$ have different 
colors.
plain_text_def:
A line ℓ determined by two points of S is
balanced if the two halfplanes it defines have weight
δ. Observe that this implies that the two points of S
spanning ℓ have different 
colors.

def:
\label{thm:fraction-cut discrete}
	Let $S$ be a set of $(d+1)n$ points in $\mathbb{R}^d$ in general position colored in colors $0, 1, \dots, d$ so that:\\
	(i) the number of points of each color is $n$;\\
	(ii) for any directed line $\ell$ there exist two colors $i$ and $j$, $i<j$ such that the farthest in the direction of $\ell$ point of color $i$ is not closer (in the direction of $\ell$) than any point of color~$j$. \\
	Then there exists a \emph{balanced} hyperplane $h$, in other words, the hyperplane such that each half-space bounded by $h$ contains precisely the same number of points of each color.
plain_text_def:
Let S be a set of (d+1)n points in ℝ^d in general position colored in colors 0, 1, …, d so that:

	(i) the number of points of each color is n;

	(ii) for any directed line ℓ there exist two colors i and j, i<j such that the farthest in the direction of ℓ point of color i is not closer (in the direction of ℓ) than any point of color j. 

	Then there exists a balanced hyperplane h, in other words, the hyperplane such that each half-space bounded by h contains precisely the same number of points of each color.

def:
\label{de:c(a)}
For a matrix $A\in \T^{\nxn}$, define:
\begin{equation}\label{eq:gamma}
\rho(A) = \bigvee_{ j\leq n} \bigvee_{i_1,\dots, i_j } \frac{ A_{i_1 i_2} +
  A_{i_2i_3} +\cdots + A_{i_j i_1}}{j} \:,
\end{equation}
Observe that
%$\rho(A)=-\infty$ if ${\cG}(A)$ is acyclic, and, otherwise,
$\rho(A)$ is the maximal mean weight of the (simple) circuits of
${\cG}(A)$.

A circuit of ${\cG}(A)$ is called {\em critical} if its mean weight is
$\rho(A)$.
The {\em critical graph} of $A$, denoted by ${\cG}_c(A)$, is the union of
all the critical circuits of ${\cG}(A)$.
%A matrix $A$ is called \emph{balanced} if all the scc of $\G(A)$ have a
%circuit with mean weight equal to $\rho(A)$.
plain_text_def:
For a matrix A∈^, define:

    ρ(A) = ⋁_ j≤ n⋁_i_1,…, i_j  A_i_1 i_2 +
      A_i_2i_3 +⋯ + A_i_j i_1/j ,

Observe that

ρ(A) is the maximal mean weight of the (simple) circuits of
(A).

A circuit of (A) is called critical if its mean weight is
ρ(A).
The critical graph of A, denoted by _c(A), is the union of
all the critical circuits of (A).

def: A \emph{base} of $\mathcal M$ is an admissible $n$-subset $B$ of $E\cup E^*$ such that $S\setminus B$ is connected.
plain_text_def: A base of ℳ is an admissible n-subset B of E∪ E^* such that S∖ B is connected.

<cit.>
Let 𝒳 be a coherent configuration. A point set Δ is called a base of 𝒳 if the smallest fission of 𝒳 in which all points of Δ are fibers, is the complete coherent configuration. Here, the complete configuration is coherent configuration whose relation sets are all binary relations on Ω×Ω.

And, b(𝒳)=minimum size of |Δ| for Δ⊂Ω such that S_Δ-fission is a complete configuration of 𝒳.

def:
\label{def:basic-tuple}
A tuple $\gamma$ of $\underline{\New} f$ is referred to as \emph{basic} if all its members belong to the same coordinate hyperplane of $\R^n$.
plain_text_def: A tuple γ of f is referred to as basic if all its members belong to the same coordinate hyperplane of ^n.

def: A $(p, q)$-leaper $L$ is \emph{basic} if $p + q$ is odd and $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime.
plain_text_def: A (p, q)-leaper L is basic if p + q is odd and p and q are relatively prime.

For every function f∈^n, let f be
the function defined by the formula

    f(x)=_a,b,cf(x+a)f(x+b)f(x+c)f(x+a+b)f(x+a+c)f(x+b+c)
    f(x+a+b+c).

Let X be a subset of ^n. A basic anti-uniform function 
(with respect to X) is a function of the form f with f∈ X.

def:
Let $X$ be a finite set and let $S$ be a homogeneous collection of ordered 
subsets of $X$ of size $k$. Let $\mu = (\mu_1,\dots,\mu_m)$ and $
u=(
u_1,\dots,
u_m)$ be 
two sequences of measures on $X$. A $(\mu,
u)$-\emph{basic anti-uniform function}
is a function of the form $\circ_j(g_{i_1}, \dots, g_{i_{j-1}}, f_{i_{j+1}}, 
\dots, f_{i_k})$, where $1\leq j\leq k$, $i_1,\dots,i_k$ are distinct and 
$0\leq g_{i_h}\leq 
u_{i_h}$ and $0\leq f_{i_h}\leq\mu_{i_h}$ for 
every $h$ between $1$ and $k$. Let $\Phi_{\mu, 
u}$ be the set of all 
$(\mu,
u)$-basic anti-uniform functions 
and define the norm $\|.\|_{\mu,
u}$ by taking $\|h\|_{\mu,
u}$ to be 
$\max\{|\sp{h,\phi}|:\phi\in\Phi_{\mu,
u}\}$.
plain_text_def:
Let X be a finite set and let S be a homogeneous collection of ordered 
subsets of X of size k. Let μ = (μ_1,…,μ_m) and ν=(ν_1,…,ν_m) be 
two sequences of measures on X. A (μ,ν)-basic anti-uniform function
is a function of the form ∘_j(g_i_1, …, g_i_j-1, f_i_j+1, 
…, f_i_k), where 1≤ j≤ k, i_1,…,i_k are distinct and 
0≤ g_i_h≤ν_i_h and 0≤ f_i_h≤μ_i_h for 
every h between 1 and k. Let Φ_μ, ν be the set of all 
(μ,ν)-basic anti-uniform functions 
and define the norm ._μ,ν by taking h_μ,ν to be 
max{|h,ϕ|:ϕ∈Φ_μ,ν}.

def:
\TheoremName{isotropic}
There is a polynomial time algorithm (either randomized or deterministic)
to compute a subset $S \subseteq [m]$ such that $\setst{ w_i }{ i \in S }$ forms a
\emph{basis} of\/ $\bR^n$,
and for which $ \norm{ \sum_{i \in S} w_i w_i \transpose } \leq \alpha $,
where $\alpha =  O(\log n / \log \log n)$.
plain_text_def:
isotropic
There is a polynomial time algorithm (either randomized or deterministic)
to compute a subset S ⊆ [m] such that w_i  i ∈ S forms a
basis of ^n,
and for which ∑_i ∈ S w_i w_i ≤α,
where α =  O(log n / loglog n).

A basis 
B⊆ is a subset such that ω(B - h) < ω(B) holds for all h ∈ B. 
For G⊆, a basis of G  is a minimal subset B of G with ω(B)=ω(G).

def:
Let $\Gamma$ be a set of graphs.
A set $S$ of graphs is a \textit{basis} for $\Gamma$, if
 any graph in $\Gamma$ has a unique  coordinates with respect to $S$.
plain_text_def:
Let Γ be a set of graphs.
A set S of graphs is a basis for Γ, if
 any graph in Γ has a unique  coordinates with respect to S.

<cit.>.

A Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent
if its Hada­mard transform has constant magnitude.
Specifically:

 
  * The Sylvester Hada­mard matrix H_m, of order 2^m,
is defined by

    H_1    :=
    [
    [ 1 1; 1 - ]],
    
    
    H_m    := H_m-1⊗ H_1,   for   m > 1.



  * For a Boolean function f : _2^m _2,
define the vector f by

    f   := [(-1)^f[0], (-1)^f[1], …, (-1)^f[2^m-1]]^T,

where the value of f[i], i ∈_2^m is given by the value of f on the binary digits of i.

  * In terms of these two definitions, the Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent if

    H_m f   = C [1, …, 1]^T.

for some constant C.

A Boolean function f on _2^n is bent if 

    f(u) ∈{2^n/2, - 2^n/2}   for all  u ∈_2^n.

def:
\label{Def:Bent}
Let $n\in \mathbb{N}$ be even. A Boolean function $f$ on $\mathbb{F}_{2^n}$ is called \emph{bent} if its Walsh-Hadamard transform satisfies $ \widehat{\chi_f}(z)=\pm 2^{n/2}$ for all $z \in \mathbb{F}_{2^n}$.
plain_text_def: Let n∈ℕ be even. A Boolean function f on 𝔽_2^n is called bent if its Walsh-Hadamard transform satisfies χ_f(z)=± 2^n/2 for all z ∈𝔽_2^n.

We define the graph G_n with V(G_n)= V(H_n) and E(G_n) = (E(H_n) ∪{k,k+3})∖({k+1,k+3}) to be a bent linear 2-tree with bend at vertex k.
 See Figure <ref>.

def:
\label{def:lin2treestb}
We define the graph $H_n$ with $V(H_n)= V(G_n)$ and $E(H_n) = (E(G_n) \cup \{k,k+3\})\setminus(\{k+1,k+3\}$ to be a bent linear 2-tree with bend at vertex $k$.
%A bent linear 2-tree is a graph with $n$ such that for some $k \in \{3,4, \ldots, n-3\}$, its adjacency matrix is
%\[a_{ij} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if $j = i+1$}\\
%1 & \text{if $j = i-1$}\\
%1 & \text{if $j = i+2$ and $ i \neq k+1$}\\
%1 & \text{if $j = i-2$ and $i \neq k+3$}\\
%1 & \text{if $j = i+3$ and $i = k$}\\
%1 & \text{if $j = i-3$ and $i = k+3$}\\
%0 & \text{otherwise.}\end{cases}\]
 See Figure~\ref{fig:bent}.
plain_text_def:
We define the graph H_n with V(H_n)= V(G_n) and E(H_n) = (E(G_n) ∪{k,k+3})∖({k+1,k+3} to be a bent linear 2-tree with bend at vertex k.








 See Figure <ref>.

def:
\label{def:lin2treestb}
A bent linear 2-tree is a graph with $n$ vertices such that for some $k \in \{3,4, \ldots, n-3\}$, its adjacency matrix is
\[a_{ij} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if $j = i+1$}\\
1 & \text{if $j = i-1$}\\
1 & \text{if $j = i+2$ and $ i \neq k+1$}\\
1 & \text{if $j = i-2$ and $i \neq k+3$}\\
1 & \text{if $j = i+3$ and $i = k$}\\
1 & \text{if $j = i-3$ and $i = k+3$}\\
0 & \text{otherwise.}\end{cases}\]
 See Figure~\ref{fig:bent}.
plain_text_def:
A bent linear 2-tree is a graph with n vertices such that for some k ∈{3,4, …, n-3}, its adjacency matrix is

    a_ij =  1    if j = i+1
    
    1    if j = i-1
    
    1    if j = i+2 and i ≠ k+1
    
    1    if j = i-2 and i ≠ k+3
    
    1    if j = i+3 and i = k
    
    1    if j = i-3 and i = k+3
    
    0    otherwise.

 See Figure <ref>.

  of (<ref>)
  and (<ref>):
  
    := (W) :=
        ⟨π_1, π_2, …, π_n, _1, _2, …, _n ⟩ .

Let W
  be a finite Coxeter group. The biHecke monoid is the
  submonoid of functions from W to W generated simultaneously by
  the elementary bubble sorting and antisorting operators
  of (<ref>)
  and (<ref>):

A bicolored graph is a graph, each vertex of which has been assigned one of two colors (here, black and white) such that each edge connects vertices of different colors.
 A bipartite graph (sometimes called bicolorable ) is a graph which admits such a coloring.

A bicolored graph is a graph Γ each vertex of which has been assigned one of two colors (here, black and white) such that each edge connects vertices of different colors.
  A bipartite graph (sometimes called bicolorable ) is a graph Γ which admits such a coloring.

def:
Let us recall that a poset $P$ is \emph{bipartite} if its
comparability graph $G(P)$ is bipartite; equivalently $P$ is the union
of the set $\min (P)$ of minimal elements and the set $\max (P)$ of
maximal elements.
plain_text_def:
Let us recall that a poset P is bipartite if its
comparability graph G(P) is bipartite; equivalently P is the union
of the set min (P) of minimal elements and the set max (P) of
maximal elements.

def: We say that a hypergraph $\Gamma$ is \emph{bipartite} if one can decompose the vertex set as a disjoint union $V=V_1\sqcup V_2$ such that, for every hyperedge $h$ of $\Gamma$, either $h$ has all its inputs in $V_1$ and all its outputs in $V_2$, or vice versa.
plain_text_def: We say that a hypergraph Γ is bipartite if one can decompose the vertex set as a disjoint union V=V_1⊔ V_2 such that, for every hyperedge h of Γ, either h has all its inputs in V_1 and all its outputs in V_2, or vice versa.

def:
[Bipartite swapping target] \label{def:target}
We say that a graph $H$ (not necessarily simple) is a \emph{bipartite swapping target} if $\Hom^{\bsp}(G \sqcup G, H) = \Hom(G \sqcup G, H)$ for every graph $G$, i.e., every homomorphism from $G \sqcup G$ to $H$ has the bipartite swapping property.
plain_text_def:
[Bipartite swapping target] 
We say that a graph H (not necessarily simple) is a bipartite swapping target if ^(G ⊔ G, H) = (G ⊔ G, H) for every graph G, i.e., every homomorphism from G ⊔ G to H has the bipartite swapping property.

def:
A loop-graph $H$ is a \emph{bipartite swapping target} if $H^\bst$ is bipartite, where $H^\bst$ is the auxiliary graph defined by taking $V(H^\bst) = V(H) \x V(H)$ and an edge between $(u,v)$ and $(u',v')$ if and only if
\[
  uu',vv' \in E(H) \quad \text{and} \quad \{uv' \notin E(H) \text{ or } u'v \notin E(H)\}.
\]
plain_text_def:
A loop-graph H is a bipartite swapping target if H^ is bipartite, where H^ is the auxiliary graph defined by taking V(H^) = V(H)  V(H) and an edge between (u,v) and (u',v') if and only if

    uu',vv' ∈ E(H)   and  {uv' ∉ E(H)  or  u'v ∉ E(H)}.

def:
\label{def:S}
The games born on Day 0 are
$S_0=\{\langle \, \emptyset^{\ell}\mid \emptyset^r \, \rangle : \ell,r\in \mathbb{R} \}$.
For $i=0,1,2,\ldots$, let $S_{i+1}$, the games born by Day $i+1$, be the set of games of the form
$\langle \,  {\cal G}\mid {\cal H} \, \rangle$, where ${\cal G}$ and
${\cal H} $ are non-empty finite subsets of $S_{i}$, or where either or both can be a single atom. The games in
$S_{i+1}\setminus S_{i}$ are said to have \textit{birthday}
$i+1$. Let $\mathbb{S}=\cup_{i\geqslant 0}S_i$.
plain_text_def:
The games born on Day 0 are
S_0={⟨ ∅^ℓ|∅^r  ⟩ : ℓ,r∈ℝ}.
For i=0,1,2,…, let S_i+1, the games born by Day i+1, be the set of games of the form
⟨  G| H ⟩, where G and
H are non-empty finite subsets of S_i, or where either or both can be a single atom. The games in
S_i+1∖ S_i are said to have birthday
i+1. Let 𝕊=∪_i⩾ 0S_i.

def:
\label{def:recgua}   
Let $\GS_0$ be the set of birthday 0 guaranteed games. These are of the form 
$\{\langle \, \emptyset^{\ell}\mid \emptyset^r \, \rangle : \ell,r\in \mathbb{R}, \ell\leq r \}$. Suppose that $\cal G$ and $\cal H$ are sets of 
guaranteed games of birthday less than $i$. 
The set of non-atomic games of the form $\langle \,  {\cal G}\mid {\cal H} \, \rangle$ together with atomic games of the forms 
$\pura{\ell}{r}$, $\langle \emptyset^\ell\mid {\cal H} \rangle$ and 
$\langle {\cal G}\mid \emptyset^r\rangle$ are the games in $\GS_{i}$. For $i>0$, if $G\in \GS_{i}\setminus \GS_{i-1}$ 
then $G$ is said to have \textit{birthday} $i$ and we write $b(G)=i$.
plain_text_def:
Let _0 be the set of birthday 0 guaranteed games. These are of the form 
{⟨ ∅^ℓ|∅^r  ⟩ : ℓ,r∈ℝ, ℓ≤ r }. Suppose that G and H are sets of 
guaranteed games of birthday less than i. 
The set of non-atomic games of the form ⟨  G| H ⟩ together with atomic games of the forms 
ℓr, ⟨∅^ℓ| H⟩ and 
⟨ G|∅^r⟩ are the games in _i. For i>0, if G∈_i∖_i-1 
then G is said to have birthday i and we write b(G)=i.

def: A \emph{block} of indices is a set of numbers $S$ where every term $SG_{a,b}(s)$ depends on the same value via division, for all $s\in S$.
plain_text_def: A block of indices is a set of numbers S where every term SG_a,b(s) depends on the same value via division, for all s∈ S.

def:
A \emph{block} in  $H$ is a maximal set of tightly-connected hyperedges.
%\{$h_1$,$h_2$ ... $h_k$\} of hyperedges of $H$,  such that for each $2\leq i \leq k$ there exists $1\leq j < i$ with $|h_i \cap h_j|=2$
plain_text_def: A block in  H is a maximal set of tightly-connected hyperedges.

def:
\label{define-Alexander-dual}
Let $(S,\alpha)$ be a self-dual $d$-ball and $T\subseteq S$ a subcomplex.
The {\it Alexander dual} (or \emph{blocker} ) of $T$ in $S$ is
$$
T^\vee:= \{ \text{cells }\sigma\text{ of }S: \alpha(\sigma) \not\in T\}.
$$
plain_text_def:
Let (S,α) be a self-dual d-ball and T⊆ S a subcomplex.
The Alexander dual (or blocker ) of T in S is

    T^∨:= {cells σ of S: α(σ) ∉T}.

For each K∈ there is an associated blocking
  polyhedron , or blocker ,

    (K) := {η∈ℝ_≥ 0^E : 
        η^Tρ≥ 1,  ∀ρ∈ K }.

def:
A set of edges in a geometric graph $G$ is called a blocking set for $\F$
if it intersects (i.e., contains an edge of) every element of $\F$. A \emph{blocker} for $\F$ is a blocking set of smallest possible size. The family of blockers for $\F$ is denoted $\B(\F)$.
plain_text_def:
A set of edges in a geometric graph G is called a blocking set for 
if it intersects (i.e., contains an edge of) every element of . A blocker for  is a blocking set of smallest possible size. The family of blockers for  is denoted ().

def: A set of edges in $E(G)$ is called a blocking set for $\F$ if it intersects (i.e., contains an edge of) every element of $\F$. A \emph{blocker} for $\F$ is a blocking set of smallest possible size. The family of blockers for $\F$ is denoted $\B(\F)$.
plain_text_def: A set of edges in E(G) is called a blocking set for  if it intersects (i.e., contains an edge of) every element of . A blocker for  is a blocking set of smallest possible size. The family of blockers for  is denoted ().

def: Suppose $k, d$ are positive integers with $k<d$. Let $W_d$ be the set of words on alphabet $\{0,1\}$ of length $d$ and first letter $1$. For $w = w_1w_2 \ldots w_d$ in $W_d$, we may write $w$ as a concatenation of subwords $w = B_1(w)B_2(w) \ldots B_q(w)$ where $B_i(w)$ is a word of all $1$'s if $i$ is odd and all $0$'s if $i$ is even. We will call these the \emph{blocks} of $w$. For any $1 \leq j \leq d$, let $b_j(w)$ be the index of the block of $w$ containing $w_j$.  Let $W_d(k)$ denote the set of words in $W_d$ with exactly $k+1$ blocks.
plain_text_def: Suppose k, d are positive integers with k<d. Let W_d be the set of words on alphabet {0,1} of length d and first letter 1. For w = w_1w_2 … w_d in W_d, we may write w as a concatenation of subwords w = B_1(w)B_2(w) … B_q(w) where B_i(w) is a word of all 1's if i is odd and all 0's if i is even. We will call these the blocks of w. For any 1 ≤ j ≤ d, let b_j(w) be the index of the block of w containing w_j.  Let W_d(k) denote the set of words in W_d with exactly k+1 blocks.

[Theorems 2.8 and 5.13 of <cit.>]
The following three conditions about a cluster algebra 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱_0,B_0) with skew-symmetrizable B_0 are equivalent:

 
  * 𝒜 is of finite mutation type,
 
  * In every seed (𝐱,B) that is mutation-equivalent to (𝐱_0,B_0), the exchange matrix B satisfies |b_ij b_ji| ≤ 4 for all pairs 1 ≤ i, j ≤ n.
 
  * 𝒜 has one of the following properties:
  
   
  * 𝒜 is of rank 2,
   
  * 𝒜 is decomposable into blocks , as described in <cit.>, or
   
  * 𝒜 is one of the 11 exceptional types in Theorem <ref> or one of the 7 exceptional types G̃_2, F_4, F̃_4, V_4, W_4, Y_4, and Z_6.

def:
\label{thm:succblock}
  The succulents are exactly the connected graphs whose blocks\footnote{The \emph{blocks} of a graph are its maximal $2$-connected subgraphs.} are polygonal $2$-trees.
plain_text_def: The succulents are exactly the connected graphs whose blocks[The blocks of a graph are its maximal 2-connected subgraphs.] are polygonal 2-trees.

def:
We say that an internal path $P$ \emph{blocks} a pair $(p,q)$ if
  $\dam_{L,P}(p,q) > S_L(P) - 2\sizeof{V(P)}$, i.e., if we cannot extend the
  partial colouring $\phi(u) = p$, $\phi(v) = q$ to all of $P$.
plain_text_def:
We say that an internal path P blocks a pair (p,q) if
  _L,P(p,q) > S_L(P) - 2V(P), i.e., if we cannot extend the
  partial colouring ϕ(u) = p, ϕ(v) = q to all of P.

def:
\label{def:blowup1sk}
The generalized 1-skeleton $(\Gamma^\sharp,\alpha^\sharp,\theta^\sharp,\lambda^\sharp)$ is called the \emph{blow-up} of $(\Gamma,\alpha,\theta,\lambda)$ along the subskeleton $(\Gamma_0,\alpha_0,\theta_0,\lambda_0)$.
plain_text_def: The generalized 1-skeleton (Γ^♯,α^♯,θ^♯,λ^♯) is called the blow-up of (Γ,α,θ,λ) along the subskeleton (Γ_0,α_0,θ_0,λ_0).

def: A \emph{blow-up} is an inductive coloring of $K_n$, where the edges are colored as follows. Pick $m\leq n$ and fix a coloring of $K_m$ with labeled vertices $v_1,\ldots,v_m$. Divide the vertices of $K_n$ into $m$ disjoint sets of size $\lfloor\frac{n}{m}\rfloor$ and $\lceil\frac{n}{m}\rceil$, namely $V_1,\ldots,V_m$. For $u_i\in V_i$ and $u_j\in V_j$, color the edge $u_iu_j$ the same color as the edge $v_iv_j$ in the coloring of $K_m$. Repeat this process with each $V_i$ until there are no vertices left to be split into $m$ disjoint sets. We call this a blow-up of the initial coloring of $K_m$ with $n$ vertices.
plain_text_def: A blow-up is an inductive coloring of K_n, where the edges are colored as follows. Pick m≤ n and fix a coloring of K_m with labeled vertices v_1,…,v_m. Divide the vertices of K_n into m disjoint sets of size ⌊n/m⌋ and ⌈n/m⌉, namely V_1,…,V_m. For u_i∈ V_i and u_j∈ V_j, color the edge u_iu_j the same color as the edge v_iv_j in the coloring of K_m. Repeat this process with each V_i until there are no vertices left to be split into m disjoint sets. We call this a blow-up of the initial coloring of K_m with n vertices.

def:
\label{booster}
  Given a graph $G$, a non-edge $e=\left\{u,v\right\}$ of $G$ is called a
  \emph{booster} if adding $e$ to $G$ creates a graph $\tilde{G}$, which is
  either Hamiltonian or whose maximum path is longer than that of $G$.
plain_text_def:
Given a graph G, a non-edge e={u,v} of G is called a
  booster if adding e to G creates a graph G̃, which is
  either Hamiltonian or whose maximum path is longer than that of G.

def:
\label{def:booster}
For a hypergraph $G$, a \emph{booster} is an edge such that either $G \cup e$ has a longer (Berge) path than $G$ or $G \cup e$ is (Berge) Hamiltonian.
plain_text_def: For a hypergraph G, a booster is an edge such that either G ∪ e has a longer (Berge) path than G or G ∪ e is (Berge) Hamiltonian.

def:
\label{def::booster}
For a graph $G$, a non-edge $uv \notin E(G)$ is called a \emph{booster} of $G$, if either $G \cup \{uv\}$ is Hamiltonian, or the longest path in $G \cup \{uv\}$ is strictly longer than the longest path in $G$.
plain_text_def: For a graph G, a non-edge uv ∉ E(G) is called a booster of G, if either G ∪{uv} is Hamiltonian, or the longest path in G ∪{uv} is strictly longer than the longest path in G.

def:
\label{d:booster}
For every graph $G$, we say that a non-edge $uv\notin E(G)$ is a
\emph{booster} with respect to $G$, if either $G \cup \{uv\}$ is
Hamiltonian or $\ell(G \cup \{uv\})>\ell(G)$. We denote by
${\mathcal B}_G$ the set of boosters with respect to $G$.
