Let Fn(k,2) denote the set of all functions from a subset of {1,2,…,k} to {p,n}. We say that Fn(k,2) is full provided that, for every i ∈{1,2,…,k} and j ∈{p,n}, there is some f ∈ with f(i) = j. For each n ∈, let (n) denote the least k ∈ with the following property:


  (†)_n For any full Fn(k,2), there is some  and D ⋃_g ∈dom(g) such that |D| ≥ n, and no two members of  disagree on D.

If there is no such k ∈, then we say that (n) is not well-defined.

def: A subquiver is \emph{full} if it contains every vertex of $Q$ which lies within the boundary of the subquiver.
plain_text_def: A subquiver is full if it contains every vertex of Q which lies within the boundary of the subquiver.

def: We say that $w\in \mathfrak{S}_n$ is \emph{fully commutative} if starting from any reduced word for $w$ we can obtain any other reduced word for $w$ by applying a sequence of commutation relations (i.e., we only need to use the relations~\eqref{eqn:cox_comm}, not~\eqref{eqn:cox_braid}).
plain_text_def: We say that w∈𝔖_n is fully commutative if starting from any reduced word for w we can obtain any other reduced word for w by applying a sequence of commutation relations (i.e., we only need to use the relations (<ref>), not (<ref>)).

def:
\label{defi:FC}
 An element $w$ is \emph{fully commutative} (FC) if any reduced expression for $w$ can be obtained from any other one by using only commutation relations.
plain_text_def: An element w is fully commutative (FC) if any reduced expression for w can be obtained from any other one by using only commutation relations.

def: An element $w\in W$ is \emph{fully commutative} (FC) if the set $\mathcal{R}(w)$ forms a $\Gamma$-commutation class.
plain_text_def: An element w∈ W is fully commutative (FC) if the set ℛ(w) forms a Γ-commutation class.

A diagram D is fundamental if for each cell (r,c) of D that is leftmost in its row, either there is a cell in position (r+1,c), or for each column c'<c and for all k≥ 1 we have
  
    #{(s,c') ∈ D | r < s ≤ r+k }≤#{(s,c) ∈ D | r < s ≤ r+k }.

def:
[\cite{feichtnersturmfels}]\label{onlyfund}
  Let $B$ be a basis of the matroid $M$. For any $v \in \Sigma_B$, $v$ is in the local tropical linear space $\Trop(M)_B$ if and only if the minimum $\min \{v_i \mid i \in C\}$ is attained at least twice for any \emph{fundamental} circuit $C$ over the basis $B$.
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
  Let B be a basis of the matroid M. For any v ∈Σ_B, v is in the local tropical linear space (M)_B if and only if the minimum min{v_i | i ∈ C} is attained at least twice for any fundamental circuit C over the basis B.

def:
\label{def:fpp}
Given a lattice simplex $\mathcal{P}\subset \R^{n-1}$ with vertices $\{v_i\}_{i \in [n]}$, the \emph{fundamental parallelepiped} of $\mathcal P$ is the subset of $\cone{\mathcal P}$ defined by 
\[
\Pi_{\mathcal P} := \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i (v_i, 1) \mid 0 \le \lambda_i < 1  \right\} \, .
\]
Further, $|\Pi_{\mathcal{P}}\cap \Z^n|$ is equal to the determinant of the matrix whose $i$\ss{th} row is given by $(v_i,1)$.
plain_text_def:
Given a lattice simplex 𝒫⊂^n-1 with vertices {v_i}_i ∈ [n], the fundamental parallelepiped of 𝒫 is the subset of 𝒫 defined by 

    Π_𝒫 := {∑_i=1^n λ_i (v_i, 1) | 0 ≤λ_i < 1  }  .

Further, |Π_𝒫∩^n| is equal to the determinant of the matrix whose ißth row is given by (v_i,1).

The fundamental parallelepiped $̱ of the cone (with respect to
the generatorsv_i,i=1, …,d) is the set

    =̱∑_i=1^d [0,1[  v_i.

def:
\label{def:Fquasisymmetric}
Let $\alpha\vDash n$ be a composition. Then the
\emph{fundamental quasisymmetric function} $F_{\alpha}$ is defined by $F_\varnothing=1$ and
\[F_{\alpha}=\sum x_{i_1}\cdots x_{i_n}\]
where the sum is over all $n$-tuples $(i_1,\ldots,i_n)$ of positive integers
satisfying
\[\textrm{$1\leq i_1\leq\cdots\leq i_n\:$ and
$\;i_j<i_{j+1}\,$ if $\,j\in\set(\alpha)$.}\]
plain_text_def:
Let α n be a composition. Then the
fundamental quasisymmetric function F_α is defined by F_∅=1 and

    F_α=∑ x_i_1⋯ x_i_n

where the sum is over all n-tuples (i_1,…,i_n) of positive integers
satisfying

    1≤ i_1≤⋯≤ i_n and
    i_j<i_j+1 if j∈(α).

[<cit.>]
  For α a composition, the fundamental quasisymmetric function F_α is 
  
    F_α(x_1,x_2,…) = ∑_(b)  refines α x_1^b_1 x_2^b_2⋯,

  where the sum is over weak compositions b for which the composition (b) obtained by removing all parts equal to 0 refines α.

[<cit.>]
  The fundamental quasisymmetric function for D ⊆ [n-1] is
  
    F_D(X) = ∑_i_1 ≤⋯≤ i_n 
     j∈ D ⇒ i_j < i_j+1 x_i_1⋯ x_i_n .

[<cit.>]
  For α a strong composition, the fundamental quasisymmetric function F_α is given by
  
    F_α(X) = ∑_(b)  refines α x_1^b_1 x_2^b_2⋯ ,

  where the sum is over weak compositions b whose flattening refines α.

def:
\label{def:Fbasis}
Let $\alpha = (\alpha _1, \ldots , \alpha _\ell)$ be a composition. Then the \emph{fundamental quasisymmetric function} $F_\alpha$ is defined to be $F_0 = 1$ and
$$F_\alpha = \sum x_{i_1} \cdots x_{i_{|\alpha|}}$$where the sum is over all $|\alpha|$-tuples $(i_1, \ldots , i_{|\alpha|})$ of indices satisfying
$$i_1\leq \cdots \leq i_{|\alpha|} \mbox{ and } i_j<i_{j+1} \mbox{ if } j \in \set(\alpha).$$
plain_text_def:
Let α = (α _1, … , α _ℓ) be a composition. Then the fundamental quasisymmetric function F_α is defined to be F_0 = 1 and

    F_α = ∑ x_i_1⋯ x_i_|α|
where the sum is over all |α|-tuples (i_1, … , i_|α|) of indices satisfying

    i_1≤⋯≤ i_|α| i_j<i_j+1 j ∈(α).

For a weak composition a of length n, define the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where the sum is over all compositions b obtained by shifting or splitting the entries of a to the left while preserving their relative order.

def:
[\cite{AS1}]
  Given a weak composition $a$, the \emph{fundamental slide polynomial} $\Fund_{a}$ is defined by
  \[  \Fund_{a} = \sum_{\substack{b \geq a \\ \flatten(b) \ \mathrm{refines} \ \flatten(a)}} x^b.\]
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>]
  Given a weak composition a, the fundamental slide polynomial _a is defined by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x^b.

[<cit.>]
  The fundamental slide polynomial _a(X) is given by
  
    _a(X) = ∑_b ≥ a 
    flat(b)  refines flat(a) X^b,

  where flat(a) is the composition obtained by removing zero parts from a.

[<cit.>]
  For a weak composition a of length n, define the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    flat(b)  refines flat(a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where b ≥ a means b_1 + ⋯ + b_k ≥ a_1 + ⋯ + a_k for all k=1,…,n.

[<cit.>]
  For a weak composition a of length n, define the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x^b,

  where the relation b≥ a is dominance order, and (a) is the strong composition obtained by removing all 0 terms of a.

[<cit.>]
  For a weak composition a of length n, the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) is
  
    _a = ∑_b_1 + ⋯ + b_k ≥ a_1 + ⋯ + a_k  ∀ k 
    flat(b)  refines flat(a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where flat(a) denotes the composition obtained by removing all zero parts.

[<cit.>]
  For a weak composition a of length n, define the fundamental slide polynomial _a = _a(x_1,…,x_n) by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n,

  where b ≥ a means b_1 + ⋯ + b_k ≥ a_1 + ⋯ + a_k for all k=1,…,n.

def:
\label{def:gadget}
In the matrix given in the proof of the previous lemma, let $F_i=\{d_i,e_i,f_i,g_i\}$. We will call each $F_i$ a \textit{gadget} .
plain_text_def: In the matrix given in the proof of the previous lemma, let F_i={d_i,e_i,f_i,g_i}. We will call each F_i a gadget .

def:
[Gadget]\label{def:gadget}
Let $(H_0, H_i, L_i)^n$  be an ear decomposition of a trigraph
and $\mathcal{B}=\mathcal{B}(x,u)$ be a basic gadget.
A \emph{gadget} $\mathcal{G}$  (see Figure~\ref{fig:gadget}) of $(H_0, H_i, L_i)^n$ associated to $\mathcal{B}$   
is the block of ears $$\mathcal{G}=E_1(\mathcal{B}), E_2(\mathcal{B}), E_3, E_4(\mathcal{B}), D_1(\mathcal{B}), D_2(\mathcal{B}), D_3(\mathcal{B})$$ 
of $L_1, \ldots, L_n$, where  $E_3$ is the 3-ear on edge set $E'_3(\mathcal{B}) \cup \{x',x\}$ with
 $x'$ a neighbour of $x$ not in~$V(E'_3(\mathcal{B}))$.
plain_text_def:
[Gadget]
Let (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n  be an ear decomposition of a trigraph
and ℬ=ℬ(x,u) be a basic gadget.
A gadget 𝒢  (see Figure <ref>) of (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n associated to ℬ   
is the block of ears 
    𝒢=E_1(ℬ), E_2(ℬ), E_3, E_4(ℬ), D_1(ℬ), D_2(ℬ), D_3(ℬ)
 
of L_1, …, L_n, where  E_3 is the 3-ear on edge set E'_3(ℬ) ∪{x',x} with
 x' a neighbour of x not in V(E'_3(ℬ)).

term: gap vector for prefix $p$ with respect to $B$;satisfies;gap vector criterion
def: Given a set of forbidden patterns $B$ and prefix $p\in\S{k}$, then $\vec{v}\in\mathbb{N}^{k+1}$ is a \emph{gap vector for prefix $p$ with respect to $B$} if for all $n$ $\Spt{n}{B}{p}{w}=\emptyset$ for all $w$ such that $\vec{g}(n,w)\geq \vec{v}$.  When this happens, we say that $w$ \emph{satisfies} the \emph{gap vector criterion} for $\vec{v}$.
plain_text_def: Given a set of forbidden patterns B and prefix p∈k, then v⃗∈ℕ^k+1 is a gap vector for prefix p with respect to B if for all n nBpw=∅ for all w such that g⃗(n,w)≥v⃗.  When this happens, we say that w satisfies the gap vector criterion for v⃗.
plain_text_term: gap vector for prefix p with respect to B;satisfies;gap vector criterion

term: gap vector for prefix $p$ with respect to $B$;satisfies;gap vector criterion
def: Given a set of forbidden patterns $B$ and prefix $p$, then $\vec{v}$ is a \emph{gap vector for prefix $p$ with respect to $B$} if, for all $n$, $\Spt{n}{B}{p}{w}=\emptyset$ for any $w$ such that $\vec{g}(n,w)\geq \vec{v}$.  In this case we say that $w$ \emph{satisfies} the \emph{gap vector criterion} for $\vec{v}$.
plain_text_def: Given a set of forbidden patterns B and prefix p, then v⃗ is a gap vector for prefix p with respect to B if, for all n, nBpw=∅ for any w such that g⃗(n,w)≥v⃗.  In this case we say that w satisfies the gap vector criterion for v⃗.
plain_text_term: gap vector for prefix p with respect to B;satisfies;gap vector criterion

def:
Let $G$ be a graph.  We say two disjoint edges $uv$ and $xy$ form a \emph{gap} in $G$ if $G$ does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in $\{u,v\}$ and the other in $\{x,y\}$.
A graph without gaps is called \emph{gap-free} .  Equivalently, $G$ is gap-free if and only if $G^c$ contains no induced $C_4$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph.  We say two disjoint edges uv and xy form a gap in G if G does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in {u,v} and the other in {x,y}.
A graph without gaps is called gap-free .  Equivalently, G is gap-free if and only if G^c contains no induced C_4.

def:
Let $G$ be a graph.  We say two edges $(w, x)$ and $(y, z)$ form a \emph{gap} in $G$ if $G$ does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in $\{w, x\}$ and the other in $\{y, z\}$.
A graph without gaps is called \emph{gap-free} .  Equivalently, $G$ is gap-free if and only if $G^c$ contains no induced $C_4$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph.  We say two edges (w, x) and (y, z) form a gap in G if G does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in {w, x} and the other in {y, z}.
A graph without gaps is called gap-free .  Equivalently, G is gap-free if and only if G^c contains no induced C_4.

[<cit.>]
For a skew shifted tableau with entries i_j or i'_j for i∈{1,2,…} where j is any symbol, we call i the gene family of an entry i_j or i'_j and j the gene . Two such tableaux are equivalent if they are the same up to a relabeling of the genes j.  An equivalence class T of these tableaux is a semistandard genomic tableau if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the gene subscripts is semistandard and in canonical form.

  * Each gene j consists only of letters i_j and i'_j for some i, and its letters are consecutive in standardization order.

  * For every primed entry i'_j, there is an unprimed letter i_k preceding it in reading order from the same family i but different gene k≠ j.

  * No two squares of the same gene are horizontally or vertically adjacent.

The K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, …, c_r) where c_i is the number of genes in the i-th family. Finally, T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot for all T' obtained in this way.

[<cit.>]
Let T be a genomic tableau with entries i_j. We call i the gene family and j the gene . First, we say T is semistandard if:


  * The tableau T_ss obtained by forgetting the genes is semistandard (that is, each gene family forms a horizontal strip);

  * Within each gene family, the genes form a Pieri strip.

We say the K-theoretic content of T is (c_1, …, c_r) if c_i is the max-content of the Pieri strip of genes in the i-th gene family. Finally, we say T is ballot if it is semistandard and has the following property:


  (*) Let T' be any genomic tableau obtained by deleting, within each gene family of T, all but one of every repeated gene. Let T'_ss be the tableau obtained by deleting the corresponding entries of T_ss. Then the reading word of T'_ss is ballot.

def:
\label{generalposition}
We say that a subspace $P \subset U$ of codimension $k$ is in \emph{general position} (with respect to the hyperplane arrangement $\arr$),
if $x \cap P^\perp = \{0\}$ for all $x \in L_k$, and in addition, the hyperplanes $\pi_P (x)$, $x\in L_{k+1}$ of $P^*$
are distinct.
plain_text_def:
We say that a subspace P ⊂ U of codimension k is in general position (with respect to the hyperplane arrangement ),
if x ∩ P^⊥ = {0} for all x ∈ L_k, and in addition, the hyperplanes π_P (x), x∈ L_k+1 of P^*
are distinct.

def:
A set $M\in\overline{\mathfrak{M}}(2,n)$ is called to be in \textit{general position} ,
	if no four points of $M$ are concyclic.
	The set of all planar integral point sets in general position
	is denoted by $\dot{\mathfrak{M}}(2,n)$.
plain_text_def:
A set M∈𝔐(2,n) is called to be in general position ,
	if no four points of M are concyclic.
	The set of all planar integral point sets in general position
	is denoted by 𝔐̇(2,n).

[General position I]
Let p_1,…,p_n be points in ℝ^2 and λ'_1,…,λ'_l be cross-ratios that have pairwise distinct pairs of unordered numbers. These conditions are in general position if ∏_j=1^l_λ'_j^*( |λ'_j|)·∏_i=1^n_i^*( p_i)·ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ) is a nonempty finite set that is contained in the union of the interiors of top-dimensional polyhedra of ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ) and n+l=|Δ|-1. We say that p_1,…,p_n',λ_1,…,λ_l' with n'+l'<|Δ|-1 are in general position if there are p_n'+1,…,p_n,λ'_l'+1,…,λ'_l such that n+l=|Δ|-1 and p_1,…,p_n,λ'_1,…,λ'_l are in general position. If p_1,…,p_n,λ'_1,…,λ'_l with n+l=|Δ|-1 are in general position, we define

    N_0,n(λ'_1,…,λ'_l):=(∏_j=1^l_λ'_j^*( |λ'_j|)·∏_i=1^n_i^*( p_i)·ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ)),

the number of rational tropical curves of degree Δ satisfying the point conditions p_i and the cross-ratio conditions λ'_i. Denote by 𝒞_0,n( λ'_1,…,λ'_l) the set of tropical curves contributing to N_0,n(λ'_1,…,λ'_l).

def:
[projective lines in general position]\label{def:generalPosition}
We say that a set of at most $\dm+1$ projective lines in $\ps{q}{\dm}$ is in \emph{general position} if for any $k \in [\dm-1]$ no $k+1$ of them are contained in a $k$-flat.
plain_text_def:
[projective lines in general position]
We say that a set of at most +1 projective lines in q is in general position if for any k ∈ [-1] no k+1 of them are contained in a k-flat.

def:
[Bruggersser \cite{bruggersser}]\label{shelling2} Let $P$ be a
polytope and $\mathbf{x}$ be a point outside $P$. If point
$\mathbf{x}$ lies in \emph{general position} with respect to $P$,
then the boundary complex $\mathcal{C}_{\partial P}$ of $P$ has a
shelling such that the facets of $P$ that are visible from
$\mathbf{x}$ come first.
plain_text_def:
[Bruggersser <cit.>] Let P be a
polytope and 𝐱 be a point outside P. If point
𝐱 lies in general position with respect to P,
then the boundary complex 𝒞_∂ P of P has a
shelling such that the facets of P that are visible from
𝐱 come first.

def:
\label{def_GPG}
\rm{For positive integers $n$ and $k$ satisfying $2 \leq 2k <n$, the \textit{generalised Petersen graph} $P_{n,k}$ is defined by $$V(P_{n,k}) = \{u_{0},u_{1},...,u_{n-1},v_{0},v_{1},...,v_{n-1}\}~ \text{and} ~E(P_{n,k}) = \{u_{i}u_{i+1},u_{i}v_{i},v_{i}v_{i+k}~|~i=0,1,...,n-1\},$$ where the subscripts are read modulo $n$.}
plain_text_def:
For positive integers n and k satisfying 2 ≤ 2k <n, the generalised Petersen graph P_n,k is defined by 
    V(P_n,k) = {u_0,u_1,...,u_n-1,v_0,v_1,...,v_n-1} and E(P_n,k) = {u_iu_i+1,u_iv_i,v_iv_i+k | i=0,1,...,n-1},
 where the subscripts are read modulo n.

def:
\label{GPG}
\rm{Let $n$ and $k$ be positive integers such that  $2 \leq 2k <n$. Then the \textit{generalised Petersen graph} $P_{n,k}$ is defined to have the vertex set $V(P_{n,k}) = \{u_{i}, v_{i}~|~i\in[n]\},$ and edge set \linebreak[4] $ E(P_{n,k}) = \{u_{i}u_{i+1}, v_{i}v_{i+k},u_{i}v_{i}~|~i\in[n]\},$ where $[n]=\{0,1,...,n-1\}$ and the subscripts are read modulo $n$.}
plain_text_def: Let n and k be positive integers such that  2 ≤ 2k <n. Then the generalised Petersen graph P_n,k is defined to have the vertex set V(P_n,k) = {u_i, v_i | i∈[n]}, and edge set [4] E(P_n,k) = {u_iu_i+1, v_iv_i+k,u_iv_i | i∈[n]}, where [n]={0,1,...,n-1} and the subscripts are read modulo n.

term: generalised dicyclic group;generalised dicyclic;dicyclic;generalised quaternion group
def:
\label{defeq:2}{\rm
Let $A$ be an abelian group of even order and of exponent greater than $2$, and let $y$ be an involution of $A$. The \emph{generalised dicyclic group} $\Dic(A,y,x)$ is the group $\langle A,x\mid x^2=y, a^x=a^{-1}, \forall a \in A\rangle$. A group is called \emph{generalised dicyclic} if it is isomorphic to some $\Dic(A,y,x)$. When $A$ is cyclic, $\Dic(A,y,x)$ is called a \emph{dicyclic} or \emph{generalised quaternion group} .


We let $\bar{\iota}_A:\Dic(A,y,x)\to \Dic(A,y,x)$ be the mapping defined by $(ax)^{\bar{\iota}_A}=ax^{-1}$ and $a^{\bar{\iota}_A}=a$, for every $a\in A$. In particular, $\bar{\iota}_A$ is an automorphism of $\Dic(A,y,x)$.
The role of the label ``$A$'' in $\bar{\iota}_A$ seems unnecessary, however we use this label to stress one important fact. An abstract group $R$ might be isomorphic to $\Dic(A,y,x)$, for various choices of $A$. Therefore, since the automorphism $\bar{\iota}_A$ depends on $A$ and since we might have more than one choice of $A$, we prefer a notation that emphasizes this fact.}
plain_text_def:
Let A be an abelian group of even order and of exponent greater than 2, and let y be an involution of A. The generalised dicyclic group (A,y,x) is the group ⟨ A,x| x^2=y, a^x=a^-1, ∀ a ∈ A⟩. A group is called generalised dicyclic if it is isomorphic to some (A,y,x). When A is cyclic, (A,y,x) is called a dicyclic or generalised quaternion group .


We let ι̅_A:(A,y,x)→(A,y,x) be the mapping defined by (ax)^ι̅_A=ax^-1 and a^ι̅_A=a, for every a∈ A. In particular, ι̅_A is an automorphism of (A,y,x).
The role of the label “A” in ι̅_A seems unnecessary, however we use this label to stress one important fact. An abstract group R might be isomorphic to (A,y,x), for various choices of A. Therefore, since the automorphism ι̅_A depends on A and since we might have more than one choice of A, we prefer a notation that emphasizes this fact.
plain_text_term: generalised dicyclic group;generalised dicyclic;dicyclic;generalised quaternion group

term: generalised dicyclic group;generalised dicyclic;dicyclic;generalised quaternion group
def: Let $A$ be an abelian group of even order and of exponent greater than $2$, and let $y$ be an involution of $A$. The \emph{generalised dicyclic group} $\Dic(A,y,x)$ is the group $\langle A,x\mid x^2=y, a^x=a^{-1}, \forall a \in A\rangle$. A group is called \emph{generalised dicyclic} if it is isomorphic to some $\Dic(A,y,x)$. When $A$ is cyclic, $\Dic(A,y,x)$ is called a \emph{dicyclic} or \emph{generalised quaternion group} .
plain_text_def: Let A be an abelian group of even order and of exponent greater than 2, and let y be an involution of A. The generalised dicyclic group (A,y,x) is the group ⟨ A,x| x^2=y, a^x=a^-1, ∀ a ∈ A⟩. A group is called generalised dicyclic if it is isomorphic to some (A,y,x). When A is cyclic, (A,y,x) is called a dicyclic or generalised quaternion group .
plain_text_term: generalised dicyclic group;generalised dicyclic;dicyclic;generalised quaternion group

def:
Let $\mathcal A$ be an alphabet and $G$ be the set of all involutory antimorphisms on ${\mathcal A}^*$.
Let $\Delta = \delta_1 \delta_2 \ldots$ and $\Theta = \vartheta_1 \vartheta_2 \ldots$, where $\delta_i \in {\mathcal A}$ and $\vartheta_i \in G$ for all $i \in \mathbb{N}$. The infinite \emph{generalized pseudostandard word} $\mathbf{u}(\Delta, \Theta)$ generated by the generalized pseudopalindromic closure is the word whose prefixes $w_n$ are obtained from the recurrence relation
$$w_{n+1} = (w_n \delta_{n+1})^{\vartheta_{n+1}},$$ $$w_0 = \varepsilon.$$ The sequence $\Lambda = (\Delta, \Theta)$ is called the \emph{directive bi-sequence} of the word $\mathbf{u}(\Delta, \Theta)$.
plain_text_def:
Let 𝒜 be an alphabet and G be the set of all involutory antimorphisms on 𝒜^*.
Let Δ = δ_1 δ_2 … and Θ = ϑ_1 ϑ_2 …, where δ_i ∈𝒜 and ϑ_i ∈ G for all i ∈ℕ. The infinite generalized pseudostandard word 𝐮(Δ, Θ) generated by the generalized pseudopalindromic closure is the word whose prefixes w_n are obtained from the recurrence relation

    w_n+1 = (w_n δ_n+1)^ϑ_n+1,
 
    w_0 = ε.
 The sequence Λ = (Δ, Θ) is called the directive bi-sequence of the word 𝐮(Δ, Θ).

Let 𝒜  be an alphabet and G be the set of all involutory antimorphisms on ^*. Let Δ = δ_1 δ_2 … and Θ = ϑ_1 ϑ_2 …, where δ_i ∈ and ϑ_i ∈ G for all i ∈. The infinite generalized pseudostandard word  is the word whose prefixes w_n are obtained from the recurrence relation
		
    w_n+1   = (w_n δ_n+1)^ϑ_n+1,
    
    			w_0    = ε.

		The sequence  is called the directive bi-sequence of the word .

def: Let \(\alpha,\beta\) be partitions of \(n\). A \emph{generalized} \(\alpha\)-\emph{tableau} is produced by replacing each dot in the Young diagram of \(\alpha\) with a number between 1 and \(n\); if a generalized \(\alpha\)-tableau has \(\beta_{i}\) \(i\)'s \((1 \leq i \leq n)\) it is said to have \emph{content} \(\beta\). A generalized \(\alpha\)-tableau is said to be \emph{semistandard} if the numbers are non-decreasing along each row and strictly increasing down each column.
plain_text_def: Let α,β be partitions of n. A generalized α-tableau is produced by replacing each dot in the Young diagram of α with a number between 1 and n; if a generalized α-tableau has β_i i's (1 ≤ i ≤ n) it is said to have content β. A generalized α-tableau is said to be semistandard if the numbers are non-decreasing along each row and strictly increasing down each column.

def: Let \(\lambda,\mu\) be partitions of \(n\). A \emph{generalized} \(\lambda\)-\emph{tableau} is produced by placing a number between 1 and \(n\) in each space of the Young diagram of \(\lambda\); if it has \(\mu_{i}\) \(i\)'s \((1 \leq i \leq n)\), then it is said to have \emph{content} \(\mu\). A generalized \(\lambda\)-tableau is said to be \emph{semistandard} if the numbers are non-decreasing along each row and strictly increasing down each column.
plain_text_def: Let λ,μ be partitions of n. A generalized λ-tableau is produced by placing a number between 1 and n in each space of the Young diagram of λ; if it has μ_i i's (1 ≤ i ≤ n), then it is said to have content μ. A generalized λ-tableau is said to be semistandard if the numbers are non-decreasing along each row and strictly increasing down each column.

def:
\label{def_generating_set}
	Consider a seed $Q$ and an $(\ell,k)$-generating set $G$.
	By $S(G)$, we denote
	the subshift $S_X$ of finite type given by $X = \A^{\ell+1}\setmin G$.	
	We say that a seed $Q$ is \emph{generated} by $G$ if $Q\in \LL(S(G))$.
plain_text_def:
Consider a seed Q and an (ℓ,k)-generating set G.
	By S(G), we denote
	the subshift S_X of finite type given by X = ^ℓ+1 G.	
	We say that a seed Q is generated by G if Q∈(S(G)).

def: Let $\C$ be a code, and let $\{T_j\}$ be a collection of trunks in $\C$. A trunk $T\subseteq \C$ is \emph{generated} by $\{T_j\}$ if $T$ can be written as an intersection of various $T_j$.
plain_text_def: Let  be a code, and let {T_j} be a collection of trunks in . A trunk T⊆ is generated by {T_j} if T can be written as an intersection of various T_j.

def:
[Generate]
    If $U$ is a $Z_n$ instance of length $2^n-1$ we say the set of
    $Z_{n+1}$ instances of the form $U q_i U$ is \textit{generated} by $U$.
    From Lemma~\ref{thm:zcnt} we see that each instance generates a set of
    size $q$.
plain_text_def:
[Generate]
    If U is a Z_n instance of length 2^n-1 we say the set of
    Z_n+1 instances of the form U q_i U is generated by U.
    From Lemma <ref> we see that each instance generates a set of
    size q.

def:
\label{d gen func}
The \emph{generating function} of a D$_0$ graph $\G$ is
\[\sum_{\e{w} \in \ver(\G)} Q_{\Des(\e{w})}(\mathbf{x}),\]
where $Q_{\Des(\e{w})}(\mathbf{x})$ denotes Gessel's fundamental quasisymmetric function \cite{GesselPPartition}, $\Des(\e{w})$ is the descent set of $\e{w}$, and $\ver(\G)$ denotes the vertex set of $\G$.
plain_text_def:
The generating function of a D_0 graph  is

    ∑_w∈() Q_(w)(𝐱),

where Q_(w)(𝐱) denotes Gessel's fundamental quasisymmetric function <cit.>, (w) is the descent set of w, and () denotes the vertex set of .

def:
\label{def:generating}
Let $\v+\LL$ be a lattice translate, so that $\LL$ is any integer sublattice of $\Z^d$ and $\v$ is an integer vector.  
We define its \emph{generating function}  by
\[
\Theta_{\LL}(\z)=\sum_{\substack{\w\in \LL + \v \\ \w \geq 0}} \Chi_\z (\w) := 
\sum_{\substack{\w\in \LL + \v \\ \w \geq 0}}  \w^{\z} .
\]
plain_text_def:
Let +̌ be a lattice translate, so that  is any integer sublattice of ^d and $̌ is an integer vector.  
We define its generating function  by

    Θ_()=∑_∈ + ≥ 0Χ_ () := 
    ∑_∈ + ≥ 0^ .

def: We say that a height vector $\h\in\R^n$ is \emph{generic} (for $\V$) if it does not belong to $\H$. In this case, we write $\h\in\GHV$.
plain_text_def: We say that a height vector ∈^n is generic (for ) if it does not belong to $̋. In this case, we write∈.

We say that Γ_g is generic if none of ℓ_i/m_i can
	be written as the ratio of two positive integers with sum at most 2g-2.

def: A weight vector is called \emph{generic} if the sums $w_A$ are distinct for each coalition $A$.
plain_text_def: A weight vector is called generic if the sums w_A are distinct for each coalition A.

def:
\label{defn:non-degenerate}
We will say that a polytope $B$ in $\R^d$ is \emph{generic} if
there exists a sequence of faces $F_1 \subseteq F_3 \subseteq \ldots
\subseteq F_{d-1}$ of $B$ such that $F_j$ is a face of dimension $j$,
for every $j \le d-2$ the face $F_j$ is not parallel to any other face
of $F_{j+1}$, and the facet $F_{d-1}$ is not parallel to any other
facet of $B$.
plain_text_def:
We will say that a polytope B in ^d is generic if
there exists a sequence of faces F_1 ⊆ F_3 ⊆…⊆ F_d-1 of B such that F_j is a face of dimension j,
for every j ≤ d-2 the face F_j is not parallel to any other face
of F_j+1, and the facet F_d-1 is not parallel to any other
facet of B.

def:
A  tropical curve is a metric  graph $\Gamma$ embedded in $\mathbb{R}^n$, together with an integer weight function on the edges, such that
\begin{itemize}
\item The direction vector of each edge is rational.
\item At each vertex, the weighted sum of the primitive integral vectors of the edges
around the vertex is zero.
\end{itemize}
The \emph{genus} of a tropical curve is the first Betti number $\dim H^1(\Gamma,\mathbb{Z})$ of the graph.
plain_text_def:
A  tropical curve is a metric  graph Γ embedded in ℝ^n, together with an integer weight function on the edges, such that


  * The direction vector of each edge is rational.

  * At each vertex, the weighted sum of the primitive integral vectors of the edges
around the vertex is zero.

The genus of a tropical curve is the first Betti number H^1(Γ,ℤ) of the graph.

def:
\label{definition:genus} Let $M$ be a connected map embedded in a surface $\Sigma$. The \emph{genus} $g(M)$ of $M$ is the genus of $\Sigma$. 
The {\em Euler genus} $s(M)$ of $M$ is the  Euler genus of $\Sigma$, i.e., $$s(M)=\begin{cases} 2g(M) & \mbox{if $M$ is embedded in  orientable $\Sigma$,}\\
  g(M) & \mbox{if $M$ is embedded in  non-orientable $\Sigma$.}\end{cases}$$
The {\em signed genus} $\bar{g}(M)$ of $M$ is the parameter
$$\bar{g}(M)=2s(M)-3g(M)=\begin{cases} g(M) & \mbox{if $M$ is embedded in orientable $\Sigma$,}\\
  -g(M) & \mbox{if $M$ is embedded in non-orientable $\Sigma$.}\end{cases}$$
plain_text_def:
Let M be a connected map embedded in a surface Σ. The genus g(M) of M is the genus of Σ. 
The Euler genus s(M) of M is the  Euler genus of Σ, i.e., 
    s(M)= 2g(M)    
    
      g(M)

The signed genus g̅(M) of M is the parameter

    g̅(M)=2s(M)-3g(M)= g(M)    
    
      -g(M)

def:
\label{def-geom}
A distance-regular graph $X$ is called \textit{geometric} if there exists a collection $\mathcal{C}$ of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of $X$ lies in exactly one clique of $\mathcal{C}$.
plain_text_def: A distance-regular graph X is called geometric if there exists a collection 𝒞 of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of X lies in exactly one clique of 𝒞.

def:
\label{def-geom}
A distance-regular graph $X$ is called \textit{geometric} if there exists a collection $\mathcal{C}$ of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of $X$ lies in precisely one clique of $\mathcal{C}$.
plain_text_def: A distance-regular graph X is called geometric if there exists a collection 𝒞 of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of X lies in precisely one clique of 𝒞.

def:
\label{def-geom}
A distance-regular graph $X$ is called \textit{geometric} if there exists a collection $\mathcal{C}$ of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of $X$ lies in precisely one clique from $\mathcal{C}$.
plain_text_def: A distance-regular graph X is called geometric if there exists a collection 𝒞 of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of X lies in precisely one clique from 𝒞.

def: A lattice $L$ is called \emph{geometric} if (1) it is semimodular (i.e. $$\rk(p) + \rk(q) \geq \rk(p \wedge q) + \rk(p \vee q)$$ for all $p,q \in L$); and (2) every element is the join of atoms.
plain_text_def:
A lattice L is called geometric if (1) it is semimodular (i.e. 
    (p) + (q) ≥(p ∧ q) + (p ∨ q)
 for all p,q ∈ L); and (2) every element is the join of atoms.

def:
For every $n$, the \emph{geometric tree graph} $\mathcal{G}_n$, is the graph
which has as vertices all the geometric trees of order $n$ on a given set of vertices 
(in convex position), and there is an edge
between trees $T$ and $S$ if there exist edges $e$ of $T$ and $f$ of $S$ such that $S = T - e + f$, 
namely $S$ is obtained by removing $e$ from $T$ and adding $f$.
Geometric tree graphs were studied by Hernando, Hurtado, Marquez, Mora and Noy \cite{HHMM}.
plain_text_def:
For every n, the geometric tree graph 𝒢_n, is the graph
which has as vertices all the geometric trees of order n on a given set of vertices 
(in convex position), and there is an edge
between trees T and S if there exist edges e of T and f of S such that S = T - e + f, 
namely S is obtained by removing e from T and adding f.
Geometric tree graphs were studied by Hernando, Hurtado, Marquez, Mora and Noy <cit.>.

def:
Let $P$ be a finite point set in general position in the plane. The \emph{geometric tree graph} $G(P)$ is defined
as follows. The vertices of $G(P)$ are the simple (i.e., non-crossing) spanning trees (SSTs)
of $K(P)$. Two such vertices are adjacent in $G(P)$ if they differ in exactly two edges, i.e.,
if one can be obtained from the other by deleting an edge and adding another edge.
plain_text_def:
Let P be a finite point set in general position in the plane. The geometric tree graph G(P) is defined
as follows. The vertices of G(P) are the simple (i.e., non-crossing) spanning trees (SSTs)
of K(P). Two such vertices are adjacent in G(P) if they differ in exactly two edges, i.e.,
if one can be obtained from the other by deleting an edge and adding another edge.

[(Gluing of hypertrees)]
Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an S(2,l,n)
 Steiner system (i.e., every pair of points is contained in exactly one edge and m=|ℰ|=n2/l2).
Let k≥ 3, and suppose that for each E_i∈ℰ, a k-uniform hypergraph ℱ_i=(E_i, ℰ_i) is given.


  * If for all i=1,2,…, m |ℰ_i| = αl2, then |⋃_i=1^m ℰ_i| = αn2.

  * If for all i=1,2,…, m ℱ_i is an edge-minimal hypertree, then 
ℱ=(V,⋃_i=1^m ℰ_i) is also an edge-minimal hypertree.

In this case, the edge-minimal hypertree ℱ is called the gluing of the edge-minimal hypertrees {ℱ_i: E_i∈ℰ} along the Steiner system ℋ.

def:
Let $\gamma^{1}\in\nbCWalks$ be a closed nonbacktracking walk,
  $\gamma^{2}\in\bCSWalks$ be a closed loop, and assume $\gamma^{1}$
  and $\gamma^{2}$ edge intersect. The \emph{gluing} of $\gamma^{1}$
  and $\gamma^{2}$ is the walk $\gamma$ defined by
  \begin{equation}
    \gamma = (\gamma^{1}_{1},\ldots,\gamma^{1}_{s},\gamma^{2}_{1},
    \ldots, \gamma^{2}_{\abs{\gamma^{2}}}, \gamma^{1}_{s+1},\ldots,
    \gamma^{1}_{\abs{\gamma^{1}}})
  \end{equation}
  where $\gamma^{1}_{s}$ is the first edge in $\gamma^{1}$ that is
  contained in the loop $\gamma^{2}$ and $(\gamma^{2}_{1},\ldots,
  \gamma^{2}_{\abs{\gamma^{2}}})$ is the representative of
  $\gamma^{2}$ with initial (oriented) edge $\gamma^{1}_{s}$.
plain_text_def:
Let γ^1∈ be a closed nonbacktracking walk,
  γ^2∈ be a closed loop, and assume γ^1
  and γ^2 edge intersect. The gluing of γ^1
  and γ^2 is the walk γ defined by
  
    γ = (γ^1_1,…,γ^1_s,γ^2_1,
        …, γ^2_γ^2, γ^1_s+1,…,
        γ^1_γ^1)

  where γ^1_s is the first edge in γ^1 that is
  contained in the loop γ^2 and (γ^2_1,…,
  γ^2_γ^2) is the representative of
  γ^2 with initial (oriented) edge γ^1_s.

def: [Quadruples]\label{quad}  If $V$ is a vertex set, $G \leq \Hom(V,V)$, $a_k \in A_{=k}^{(V)}$, and $z_{<k} \in Z_{<k}^{(V)}$, we say that $(V,G,a_k,z_{<k})$ is \emph{good} if $Q^{(V)}(z_{<k})(C_{V,G,a_k}) > 0$, and \emph{bad} otherwise.  We define the probability measure $\rho_{V,G,a_k,z_{<k}} \in \Pr( (Z_{=k}^{(V)})^G )$ to equal the conditioned measure $(Q^{(V)}(z_{<k})|C_{V,G,a_k})$ (as defined in Appendix \ref{prob}) if $(V,G,a_k,z_{<k})$ is good, and $\delta_{\overline{z_*}^{(V)}(\phi)}$ otherwise.
plain_text_def: [Quadruples]  If V is a vertex set, G ≤(V,V), a_k ∈ A_=k^(V), and z_<k∈ Z_<k^(V), we say that (V,G,a_k,z_<k) is good if Q^(V)(z_<k)(C_V,G,a_k) > 0, and bad otherwise.  We define the probability measure ρ_V,G,a_k,z_<k∈( (Z_=k^(V))^G ) to equal the conditioned measure (Q^(V)(z_<k)|C_V,G,a_k) (as defined in Appendix <ref>) if (V,G,a_k,z_<k) is good, and δ_z_*^(V)(ϕ) otherwise.

def: Using the constants from Remark \ref{apbp} and given $p>1$ integer, we say an arc $A$ is \emph{good} in the arc-system $\mathcal{A}$, if to at least half of the vertices $v\in A$ we can assign a set of $$4b_{p-1}x^{(p-1)(p-2)/2}$$ arcs in $N_\mathcal{A}(v)$, each arc of $\mathcal{A}$ being assigned to at most one $v\in\mathcal{A}$. If an arc is not good we call it \emph{bad} .
plain_text_def:
Using the constants from Remark <ref> and given p>1 integer, we say an arc A is good in the arc-system 𝒜, if to at least half of the vertices v∈ A we can assign a set of 
    4b_p-1x^(p-1)(p-2)/2
 arcs in N_𝒜(v), each arc of 𝒜 being assigned to at most one v∈𝒜. If an arc is not good we call it bad .

def: A $k$-orbigraph $\Omega$ is said to be \emph{good} if it can be obtained as the quotient of a finite $k$-regular graph $\Gamma$ via an equitable partition on $\Gamma$.  If an orbigraph is not good it is called \emph{bad} .
plain_text_def: A k-orbigraph Ω is said to be good if it can be obtained as the quotient of a finite k-regular graph Γ via an equitable partition on Γ.  If an orbigraph is not good it is called bad .

A coloring φ∈Φ_5(A) is called good  
 if for each i∈[5] we have ϕ^-1(i)⊂ L_i for some largest sum-free set L_i of G, and


  * the tuple ℒ=(L_1,…,L_5) consists of one 4-atom and two 3-atoms, or

  * the tuple ℒ=(L_1,…,L_5) consists
of two 2-atoms, four 3-atoms and one 4-atom.

 Otherwise ϕ is called a bad coloring.

def: Let $w_G$ be as above. We say that an encoding of the state $w_G(t)$ is \emph{good} if $\lambda_{uv}(t)\le 0$ whenever $w_u(t)\ge w_v(t)$. Otherwise, we say that the encoding is \emph{bad} .
plain_text_def: Let w_G be as above. We say that an encoding of the state w_G(t) is good if λ_uv(t)≤ 0 whenever w_u(t)≥ w_v(t). Otherwise, we say that the encoding is bad .

def:
\label{def3}
Let $\alpha$ be a countable ordinal and $\preceq$ a quasi-ordering on
 $Q$. We say a function $f:B\to Q$ is \emph{good} with respect
 to $\preceq$, if there are some $s,t\in B$ such that $s\triangleleft t$
 and $f(s)\preceq f(t)$. Otherwise we say $f$ is \emph{bad} .
We say $\preceq$ an $\alpha$-\textsc{wqo}, if for every barrier
 with $\ot(B)\le\alpha$  every function $f:B\to Q$ is good with
 respect to $\preceq$. If $\preceq$ is an
 $\alpha$-\textsc{wqo} for all countable ordinal $\alpha$, we call
 $\preceq$ a \textsc{bqo}.
plain_text_def:
Let α be a countable ordinal and ≼ a quasi-ordering on
 Q. We say a function f:B→ Q is good with respect
 to ≼, if there are some s,t∈ B such that s◃ t
 and f(s)≼ f(t). Otherwise we say f is bad .
We say ≼ an α-wqo, if for every barrier
 with (B)≤α  every function f:B→ Q is good with
 respect to ≼. If ≼ is an
 α-wqo for all countable ordinal α, we call
 ≼ a bqo.

def: A \emph{graph} is a digraph $G$ in which the edge relation $E(G)$ is symmetric.
plain_text_def: A graph is a digraph G in which the edge relation E(G) is symmetric.

def: ~\label{graph_def}  The \emph{graph} of a permutation $\pi \in \mathcal{S}_n$ is the set of points $$\left\{(i,\pi_i) \middle| 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}.$$
plain_text_def:
The graph of a permutation π∈𝒮_n is the set of points 
    {(i,π_i) | 1 ≤ i ≤ n}.

def: The \emph{graph} $\Gamma(\pi)$ of a permutation $\pi$ has vertex set $\{1,2,\ldots$, $n\}$, and  contains an arc $(i,j)$ whenever $\pi_i=j$.
plain_text_def: The graph Γ(π) of a permutation π has vertex set {1,2,…, n}, and  contains an arc (i,j) whenever π_i=j.

def:
\label{df2}
Let $\Delta$ be a $(d-1)$-dimensional pure simplicial complex. For any $i=1,\dots,n$ we define the graph $G^i(\Delta)$ as follow:
\begin{itemize}
\item [-] The set of vertices is $V(G^i(\Delta))=\{V_i\}\cup \{F\in \Im (\Delta): v_i\notin F\},$ where $V_i$ is a new vertex.
\item [-] The set of egdes  is
$$E(G^i(\Delta))=
 \{\{F,G\}:  |F\cap G|=d-1\}\cup $$
$$
\{\{V_i,F\}:\text { there exists a facet } G\ni v_i \text{ and } |G\cap F|=d-1\}.
$$
\end{itemize}
The graph $G^i(\Delta)$ is called the $v_i$-\textit{graph} of $\Delta.$
plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex. For any i=1,…,n we define the graph G^i(Δ) as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V(G^i(Δ))={V_i}∪{F∈ (Δ): v_i∉ F}, where V_i is a new vertex.

  - The set of egdes  is

    E(G^i(Δ))=
     {{F,G}:  |F∩ G|=d-1}∪


    {{V_i,F}: there exists a facet  G∋ v_i  and  |G∩ F|=d-1}.


The graph G^i(Δ) is called the v_i-graph of Δ.

def:
[Graph of a permutation]
Given a permutation $\sigma:[n] \rightarrow [n]$, the \emph{graph} $G_{\sigma}$ of $\sigma$ is the bipartite graph  with disjoint copies of $[n]$ as color classes $A$ and $B$, where $\{a,b\}$, with $a \in A$ and $b \in B$, is an edge if and only if $\sigma(a)<b$.
plain_text_def:
[Graph of a permutation]
Given a permutation σ:[n] → [n], the graph G_σ of σ is the bipartite graph  with disjoint copies of [n] as color classes A and B, where {a,b}, with a ∈ A and b ∈ B, is an edge if and only if σ(a)<b.

def: In this section, a \emph{graph} $G = (V,E)$ will mean a (possibly infinite) undirected graph, with parallel edges allowed, but loops disallowed.  Thus $E$ should be thought of as a multiset (with its elements being sets of cardinality~$2$).  %All our infinite graphs will have countably many vertices and uniformly bounded degree.
plain_text_def: In this section, a graph G = (V,E) will mean a (possibly infinite) undirected graph, with parallel edges allowed, but loops disallowed.  Thus E should be thought of as a multiset (with its elements being sets of cardinality 2).

We define the graph Ξ_r as the graph of the following form (see figure <ref>).

    {[                  G = {x_0, …, x_r-1,y_0, …, y_r-1,z_0,
        …, z_r-1}; G = {(x_i,x_i+1), (z_i,z_i+1)}_i ∈0r-2∪{(x_i,y_i),(y_i,z_i)}_i ∈0r-1 ] .

We define the graph Ξ_r as the graph of the following form (see figure <ref>).

    {[           G = {x_0, …, x_r-1,y_0, …, y_r-1,z_0,
        …, z_r-1}; G = {x_i,x_i+1, z_i,z_i+1}_i ∈1r-1∪{x_i,y_i, y_i,z_i}_i ∈0r-1 ] .

def:
\label{def:Restrictive} 
A transitive permutation group $L$ is \emph{graph-restrictive} if there exists a constant
$c(L)$ such that, for every locally-$L$ pair $(\Gamma,G)$ and an arc $(u,v)$ of $\Gamma$, the
inequality $|G_{uv}|\leq c(L)$ holds.
plain_text_def:
A transitive permutation group L is graph-restrictive if there exists a constant
c(L) such that, for every locally-L pair (Γ,G) and an arc (u,v) of Γ, the
inequality |G_uv|≤ c(L) holds.

def:
\label{def:Restrictive} 
A permutation group $L$ is \emph{graph-restrictive} if there exists a constant $c(L)$ such that, for every locally-$L$ pair $(\Gamma,G)$ and for every vertex $v$ of $\Gamma$, the inequality $|G_v|\leq c(L)$ holds.
plain_text_def: A permutation group L is graph-restrictive if there exists a constant c(L) such that, for every locally-L pair (Γ,G) and for every vertex v of Γ, the inequality |G_v|≤ c(L) holds.

[Graphons]
  A graphon is a symmetric (Lebesgue) measurable function W[0,1]^2[0,1], that is, a measurable function
  such that W(x,y)=W(y,x) for every x,y∈[0,1].

  If W is a graphon and H is a graph, then we define
  
    (H,W)
             ∫_[0,1]^V(H)∏_{v,w}∈ E(H)W(x_v,x_w)dx;
          
    (H,W)
             ∫_[0,1]^V(H)   ∏_{v,w}∈ E(H)  
          W(x_v,x_w)
            ∏_{v,w}∈ E(H)  
          (1-W(x_v,x_w))dx;
          
    
          p(H,W)
             | V(H)|!/|(H)|(H,W),

  where E(H) = {{v,w}| (v,w)∈ R_E,H} denotes the set of edges of H and H denotes the complement of H.

def:
A \emph{graphon} is a symmetric, integrable function
$W \colon [0,1]^2 \to \RR$.
plain_text_def:
A graphon is a symmetric, integrable function
W  [0,1]^2 →.

def:
\label{def:GRAPHON} An $L^p$ \emph{graphon} is a
measurable, symmetric function $W\colon [0,1]^2\to \R$ such that
\[
\|W\|_p:=\left(\int |W(x,y)|^p \, dx \, dy\right)^{1/p}<\infty.
\]
Here symmetry means  $W(x,y)=W(y,x)$ for all $(x,y)\in [0,1]^2$. If we do not
specify $p$, we assume that $W$ is in $L^1$ and call it simply a graphon,
rather than an $L^1$ graphon.
plain_text_def:
An L^p graphon is a
measurable, symmetric function W [0,1]^2→ such that

    W_p:=(∫ |W(x,y)|^p   dx   dy)^1/p<∞.

Here symmetry means  W(x,y)=W(y,x) for all (x,y)∈ [0,1]^2. If we do not
specify p, we assume that W is in L^1 and call it simply a graphon,
rather than an L^1 graphon.

def:
\label{def:greedy}
A \emph{greedy} exploration of a connected component $\GG$ is any exploration in which the second step is the addition of an internal copy which contains at least one existing edge.
plain_text_def: A greedy exploration of a connected component  is any exploration in which the second step is the addition of an internal copy which contains at least one existing edge.

def:
Given a Coxeter element $c\in W$, we call a reduced expression $c=s_1\cdots
	s_n$ \emph{greedy} if
  $$
		h(i,c)\ge h(j,c)
	$$
	whenever $i<j$.
plain_text_def:
Given a Coxeter element c∈ W, we call a reduced expression c=s_1⋯
	s_n greedy if
  
    h(i,c)≥ h(j,c)

	whenever i<j.

[Grid graph]
                        Let ∈^.
                        The grid graph _g = _g, _g yielded by the dimensions vector  is the graph such that:

def: For positive integers $ m $ and $ n $, the \emph{grid graph} $ \Gamma_{m,n} $ is the graph product $ K_m \times K_n $, that is $ V \left(\Gamma_{m,n}\right) = [m] \times [n] $ and $ \{(i,j),(i',j')\} \in E \left(\Gamma_{m,n}\right)$ if and only if either $ i=j $ or $ i'=j' $.
plain_text_def: For positive integers m and n, the grid graph Γ_m,n is the graph product K_m × K_n, that is V (Γ_m,n) = [m] × [n] and {(i,j),(i',j')}∈ E (Γ_m,n) if and only if either i=j or i'=j'.

def: Given positive integers $s$ and $t$, let the $s \times t$ \textit{grid graph} $G_{s,t}$ be the graph with vertex set \[V(G_{s,t}) = \{(i,j) \in \mathbb{Z}^2: 1 \leq i \leq s, 1 \leq j \leq t\}\] and edge set \[E(G_{s,t}) =\{(a,b)(c,d) : |a-c|+|b-d| =1\}.\]
plain_text_def:
Given positive integers s and t, let the s × t grid graph G_s,t be the graph with vertex set 
    V(G_s,t) = {(i,j) ∈ℤ^2: 1 ≤ i ≤ s, 1 ≤ j ≤ t}
 and edge set 
    E(G_s,t) ={(a,b)(c,d) : |a-c|+|b-d| =1}.

def: Let \emph{gyration} , $\mathrm{Gyr}_H$ be the toggle group element which first toggles all elements $p$ of $P$ with $H(p)$ even, then all elements with $H(p)$ being odd.
plain_text_def: Let gyration , Gyr_H be the toggle group element which first toggles all elements p of P with H(p) even, then all elements with H(p) being odd.

def:
\rm
	Given an FPL, its \emph{gyration} is computed by first visiting all squares with lower left-hand corner $(i,j)$ for which $i+j$ is even, and then all squares for which $i+j$ is odd, swapping the edges around a square if the edges are parallel and otherwise leaving them fixed.
plain_text_def: Given an FPL, its gyration is computed by first visiting all squares with lower left-hand corner (i,j) for which i+j is even, and then all squares for which i+j is odd, swapping the edges around a square if the edges are parallel and otherwise leaving them fixed.

def: Suppose that $P$ is ranked. Then \emph{gyration} $\Phi_{\mathrm{gyr}}\colon J(P) \to J(P)$ is the map $\Phi_{\mathrm{gyr}} := \tau_{o_1} \circ \tau_{o_2} \circ \cdots \circ \tau_{o_k} \circ \tau_{e_1} \circ \tau_{e_2} \circ \cdots \circ \tau_{e_j}$ where $\{e_1,\ldots,e_j\}$ is the set of elements of $P$ of even rank and $\{o_1,\ldots,o_k\}$ is the set of elements of odd rank. (Gyration is well-defined because, again, most toggles commute.)
plain_text_def: Suppose that P is ranked. Then gyration Φ_gyr J(P) → J(P) is the map Φ_gyr := τ_o_1∘τ_o_2∘⋯∘τ_o_k∘τ_e_1∘τ_e_2∘⋯∘τ_e_j where {e_1,…,e_j} is the set of elements of P of even rank and {o_1,…,o_k} is the set of elements of odd rank. (Gyration is well-defined because, again, most toggles commute.)

term: half-twist of the $i^{\text{th;dual with respect to the $i^{\text{th
def:
\label{def.ops}

Let $(G,\ell) \in \calG_{or}$ and suppose $e_i$ is the $i^\text{th}$ edge in the ordering $l$. Also, suppose $G$ is given in term of its arrow presentation, so $e_i$ is a label of a pair of arrows.  

The \emph{half-twist of the $i^{\text{th}}$ edge} is $(\tau, i)(G,\ell)=(H,\ell)$ where $H$ is obtained from $G$  by reversing the direction of exactly one of the $e_i$-labelled arrows of the arrow presentation, as in Figure~\ref{taudelta}. Most importantly, $H$ inherits its edge order $\ell$ in the natural way from $G$.  

The \emph{dual with respect to the $i^{\text{th}}$ edge} is $(\delta,i) (G,\ell) = (H,\ell)$, where $H$ is obtained from $G$ as follows.  Suppose $A$ and $B$ are the two arrows labelled $e_i$ in the arrow presentation of $G$.  Draw a line segment with an arrow from the the head of $A$ to the tail of $B$, and a line segment with an arrow from the head of $B$ to the tail of $A$.  Label both of these arrows $e_i$, and delete $A$ and $B$ with the arcs containing them. The line segments with their arrows become arcs of a new circle in the arrow presentation of $H$.  As with the twist, $H$ here inherits its edge order $l$ from $G$. See Figure~\ref{taudelta}.
plain_text_def:
Let (G,ℓ) ∈_or and suppose e_i is the i^th edge in the ordering l. Also, suppose G is given in term of its arrow presentation, so e_i is a label of a pair of arrows.  

The half-twist of the i^th edge is (τ, i)(G,ℓ)=(H,ℓ) where H is obtained from G  by reversing the direction of exactly one of the e_i-labelled arrows of the arrow presentation, as in Figure <ref>. Most importantly, H inherits its edge order ℓ in the natural way from G.  

The dual with respect to the i^th edge is (δ,i) (G,ℓ) = (H,ℓ), where H is obtained from G as follows.  Suppose A and B are the two arrows labelled e_i in the arrow presentation of G.  Draw a line segment with an arrow from the the head of A to the tail of B, and a line segment with an arrow from the head of B to the tail of A.  Label both of these arrows e_i, and delete A and B with the arcs containing them. The line segments with their arrows become arcs of a new circle in the arrow presentation of H.  As with the twist, H here inherits its edge order l from G. See Figure <ref>.
plain_text_term: half-twist of the i^th;dual with respect to the i^th

term: half-twist of the $i^{\text{th;dual with respect to the $i^{\text{th
def:
\label{def.ops}
Let $(G,\ell) \in \calG_{or(n)}$ and suppose $e_i$ is the $i^\text{th}$ edge in the ordering $\ell$. Also, suppose $G$ is given in terms of its arrow presentation, so $e_i$ is a label of a pair of arrows.  

The \emph{half-twist of the $i^{\text{th}}$ edge} is $(\tau, i)(G,\ell)=(H,\ell)$ where $H$ is obtained from $G$  by reversing the direction of exactly one of the $e_i$-labelled arrows of the arrow presentation. $H$ inherits its edge order $\ell$ in the natural way from $G$.  

The \emph{dual with respect to the $i^{\text{th}}$ edge} is $(\delta,i) (G,\ell) = (H,\ell)$, where $H$ is obtained from $G$ as follows.  Suppose $A$ and $B$ are the two arrows labelled $e_i$ in the arrow presentation of $G$.  Draw a line segment with an arrow on it directed from the the head of $A$ to the tail of $B$, and a line segment with an arrow on it directed from the head of $B$ to the tail of $A$.  Label both of these arrows $e_i$, and delete $A$ and $B$ with the arcs containing them. The line segments with their arrows become arcs of a new circle (or circles) in the arrow presentation of $H$.  As with the twist, $H$ inherits its edge order $\ell$ from $G$.
plain_text_def:
Let (G,ℓ) ∈_or(n) and suppose e_i is the i^th edge in the ordering ℓ. Also, suppose G is given in terms of its arrow presentation, so e_i is a label of a pair of arrows.  

The half-twist of the i^th edge is (τ, i)(G,ℓ)=(H,ℓ) where H is obtained from G  by reversing the direction of exactly one of the e_i-labelled arrows of the arrow presentation. H inherits its edge order ℓ in the natural way from G.  

The dual with respect to the i^th edge is (δ,i) (G,ℓ) = (H,ℓ), where H is obtained from G as follows.  Suppose A and B are the two arrows labelled e_i in the arrow presentation of G.  Draw a line segment with an arrow on it directed from the the head of A to the tail of B, and a line segment with an arrow on it directed from the head of B to the tail of A.  Label both of these arrows e_i, and delete A and B with the arcs containing them. The line segments with their arrows become arcs of a new circle (or circles) in the arrow presentation of H.  As with the twist, H inherits its edge order ℓ from G.

def:
\label{def:hgad}
A \emph{hardness gadget} in a graph $H$
is a tuple $(\beta,s,t,O,i,K,k,w)$ 
where $\beta$ is a positive integer,
$s$, $t$ and~$i$ are vertices of $H$,
$(O,\{i\},K)$ is a partition of $\Gamma_H(s)$, and
$k\colon K \to \posints$ and $w\colon K \to V(H)$
are functions.
The following conditions must be satisfied.
\begin{enumerate}
\item\label{hgad1} $|O|$ is odd.
\item\label{hgad2} For any $o\in O$ and $y\in O\cup \{i\}$, $s$~is the
  unique vertex that is adjacent to $o$ and~$y$ and has an odd number
  of $\beta$-walks to~$t$.
\item\label{hgad3} There are an even number of $(1+\beta)$-walks from
  $i$ to~$t$.
\item\label{hgad4} For all $u\in K$, $w(u)$ has an even number of $k(u)$-walks to~$u$ 
and an odd number of $k(u)$-walks to every vertex in $O\cup \{i\}$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A hardness gadget in a graph H
is a tuple (β,s,t,O,i,K,k,w) 
where β is a positive integer,
s, t and i are vertices of H,
(O,{i},K) is a partition of Γ_H(s), and
k K → and w K → V(H)
are functions.
The following conditions must be satisfied.


  *  |O| is odd.

  *  For any o∈ O and y∈ O∪{i}, s is the
  unique vertex that is adjacent to o and y and has an odd number
  of β-walks to t.

  *  There are an even number of (1+β)-walks from
  i to t.

  *  For all u∈ K, w(u) has an even number of k(u)-walks to u 
and an odd number of k(u)-walks to every vertex in O∪{i}.

def:
\label{defn:hardness-gadget}
A \emph{hardness gadget} $(i,s,(J_1,y),(J_2,z),(J_3,y,z))$ for a
graph~$H$ consists
of vertices $i$ and~$s$ of~$H$ together with three connected, partially $H$-labelled
graphs with distinguished vertices 
$(J_1,y)$, $(J_2,z)$ and $(J_3,y,z)$ 
that satisfy certain
properties
as explained below.
Let
%
\begin{align*}
\Oy &= \{ a \in V(H) \mid |\Homs{(J_1, y)}{(H,a)}|\text{ is odd}\},\\
\Oz &= \{ b \in V(H) \mid |\Homs{(J_2, z)}{(H,b)}|\text{ is odd}\}, \mbox{ and}\\
\Sigma_{a,b} &=\Homs{(J_3,y,z)}{(H,a,b)}\,.
\end{align*}
%
The properties 
that
we require are 
the following.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $|\Oy|$ is even and $i\in \Oy$.
\item $|\Oz|$ is even and $s \in \Oz$.
\item 
For each $o\in \Oy-i$ and each $x\in \Oz-s$,
$|\Sox|$ is even.
\item
$|\Sis|$ is odd and, for each $o\in \Oy-i$ and each $x\in \Oz-s$,
$|\Sos|$ and $|\Six|$   are odd.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A hardness gadget (i,s,(J_1,y),(J_2,z),(J_3,y,z)) for a
graph H consists
of vertices i and s of H together with three connected, partially H-labelled
graphs with distinguished vertices 
(J_1,y), (J_2,z) and (J_3,y,z) 
that satisfy certain
properties
as explained below.
Let


    = { a ∈ V(H) | |(J_1, y)(H,a)| is odd},
       = { b ∈ V(H) | |(J_2, z)(H,b)| is odd}, 
    Σ_a,b   =(J_3,y,z)(H,a,b) .


The properties 
that
we require are 
the following.


  * || is even and i∈.

  * || is even and s ∈.

  * For each o∈-i and each x∈-s,
|| is even.

  * || is odd and, for each o∈-i and each x∈-s,
|| and ||   are odd.

def:
[access, accessible]
Say the robber  \emph{has access} to a subset $X\subseteq V(G)$
if there exists a cop-free path from the robber's vertex to a vertex in $X$.
A pair $(X,v)$ with $X\subseteq V(G)$ and $v\in V(G)$ is called \emph{accessible} if
\begin{itemize}
\item $c_{\infty}(G) \geq |X|$,
\item $N(v) = X$, and
\item if there are $|X|-1$ cops in the game, then there exists a strategy for the robber with the following properties:
the robber has access to $X$ in every round, but she never moves to a vertex in $X\cup\{v\}$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
[access, accessible]
Say the robber  has access to a subset X⊆ V(G)
if there exists a cop-free path from the robber's vertex to a vertex in X.
A pair (X,v) with X⊆ V(G) and v∈ V(G) is called accessible if


  * c_∞(G) ≥ |X|,

  * N(v) = X, and

  * if there are |X|-1 cops in the game, then there exists a strategy for the robber with the following properties:
the robber has access to X in every round, but she never moves to a vertex in X∪{v}.

def:
Let $u,v$ be two vertices of $G$ and
   $A_1 \mid B_1, A_2\mid B_2,\cdots,A_n\mid B_n$ a list of
   cuts. The \emph{height} , $h_{u,v}(q)$, of
   \[q=q_{A_1\mid B_1}q_{A_2\mid B_2}\cdots q_{A_n\mid B_n}\]
   with respect to $u$ and $v$ is the number of cuts in
   the list with $u$ and $v$ in different parts.

Let u,v be two vertices of G and
   A_1 | B_1, A_2| B_2,⋯,A_n| B_n a list of
   cuts. The height , h_u,v(q), of
   
    q=q_A_1| B_1q_A_2| B_2⋯ q_A_n| B_n

   with respect to u and v is the number of cuts in
   the list with u and v in different parts.

def: Let $C \in DC(n)$ and $j \in [n]$. We define the \textit{height} $h(j)$ of the integer $j$ as the number $n_e(j) - n_o(j)$ where $n_e(j)$ (resp. $n_o(j)$) is the number of even dots (resp. odd dots) in the first $j-1$ columns of $C$ (with $n_e(1) = n_o(1) = 0$).
plain_text_def: Let C ∈ DC(n) and j ∈ [n]. We define the height h(j) of the integer j as the number n_e(j) - n_o(j) where n_e(j) (resp. n_o(j)) is the number of even dots (resp. odd dots) in the first j-1 columns of C (with n_e(1) = n_o(1) = 0).

A height function of order n is an (n+1)× (n+1) matrix (h_i,j)_0≤ i,j ≤ n with h_0,k = h_k,0 = k and h_n,k = h_k,n = n-k for 0 ≤ k ≤ n, and such that adjacent entries in any row or column differ by 1.

def:
\label{height} By a \textit{height function} on $\N$,
we mean a
map $h\dvtx\N\to\Z_+\cup\{+\infty\}$ which is weakly increasing [i.e.,
$h(a)\le
h(b)$ for $a<b$] and satisfies $\lim_{a\to\infty} h(a)=+\infty$. The
set of all
height functions on $\N$ will be denoted $H(\N)$.
plain_text_def:
By a height function on ,
we mean a
map h→_+∪{+∞} which is weakly increasing [i.e.,
h(a)≤
h(b) for a<b] and satisfies lim_a→∞ h(a)=+∞. The
set of all
height functions on  will be denoted H().

def:
\label{def:heredindfree}
The arrangement $\CA$ is called 
\emph{hereditarily inductively free} provided 
that $\CA^X$ is inductively free for each $X \in L(\CA)$.
Denote this class by $\HIF$.
plain_text_def:
The arrangement  is called 
hereditarily inductively free provided 
that ^X is inductively free for each X ∈ L().
Denote this class by .

The set P of the form given above will be called hereditary if the
following is true:


for every orderly currency A=(1,a_1,…,a_k)
 the sub-currency
determined by P is also orderly
A set of elections Π is hereditary if for every election (C',𝒫') it holds that if there exists an election (C,𝒫)∈Π with (C',𝒫')⊑ (C,𝒫), then (C',𝒫')∈Π.

def: Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a class of graphs such that $G - x$ is in $\mathcal{C}$ whenever $G \in \mathcal{C}$ and $x$ is a vertex of $G$.  We call such a class \emph{hereditary} .
plain_text_def: Let 𝒞 be a class of graphs such that G - x is in 𝒞 whenever G ∈𝒞 and x is a vertex of G.  We call such a class hereditary .

A hierarchy H on a set X is a collection of subsets of X with the following properties:



  * H contains both X and all singleton sets {x} for x ∈ X.

  * If H_1,H_2∈ H, then H_1 ∩ H_2 = ∅, H_1 ⊆ H_2 or H_2 ⊆ H_1.

def:
\label{def:hiveflow}
A flow $f \in \oF(G)$ is called a \emph{hive flow} iff for all rhombi~$\varrho$ we have $\s \varrho f \geq 0$.
plain_text_def: A flow f ∈(G) is called a hive flow iff for all rhombi ϱ we have ϱ f ≥ 0.

def:
\label{def:hiveflow}
A flow $f \in \oF(G)$ is called a \emph{hive flow} iff $\s \varrho f \geq 0$ for all rhombi~$\varrho$ in $\Delta$.
plain_text_def: A flow f ∈(G) is called a hive flow iff ϱ f ≥ 0 for all rhombi ϱ in Δ.

def:
Let $S$ be a collection of ordered $k$-tuples $s=(s_1,\dots,s_k)$ of 
elements of a finite set $X$, and let us write $S_j(x)$ for the set of all 
$s$ in $S$ such that $s_j=x$. We shall say that $S$ is \emph{homogeneous}
if for each $j$ the sets $S_j(x)$ all have the same size.
plain_text_def:
Let S be a collection of ordered k-tuples s=(s_1,…,s_k) of 
elements of a finite set X, and let us write S_j(x) for the set of all 
s in S such that s_j=x. We shall say that S is homogeneous
if for each j the sets S_j(x) all have the same size.

We say a structure  is homogeneous if whenever A ⊂ M with |A| < |M| and f : A → M is a partial
	elementary map, there is an automorphism σ∈() such that σ↾ A = f.

def: An acyclic matching $M$ of the face poset of a labeled cell complex is \emph{homogeneous} if $\ell(\sigma)=\ell(\tau)$ for any $\sigma,\tau\in M$.
plain_text_def: An acyclic matching M of the face poset of a labeled cell complex is homogeneous if ℓ(σ)=ℓ(τ) for any σ,τ∈ M.

[Homogeneous linear forms]

A system of linear forms ℒ = {L_1,…,L_m}  in k variables is called homogeneous if for a uniform random variable ∈ (_p^n)^k, and every fixed c ∈_p^n,  (L_1(),…,L_m()) has the same distribution as (L_1()+c,…,L_m()+c).

def: A configuration $\mathfrak{X}$ is \textit{homogeneous} if $c(u,u) = c(v,v)$ for every $u,v\in V$.
plain_text_def: A configuration 𝔛 is homogeneous if c(u,u) = c(v,v) for every u,v∈ V.

def:
For $\phi\in \CM_{\ell}(V^*)$, not necessarily a rational function, the
  \emph{homogeneous component} $ \phi_{[m]}$ of degree~$m$ of~$\phi$ is
  defined by considering $\phi(\tau \xi)$ as a meromorphic function of one
  variable~$\tau\in\C$, with Laurent series expansion
 $$
 \phi(\tau \xi) = \sum_{m\geq m_0} \tau^m \phi_{[m]}(\xi).
 $$
plain_text_def:
For ϕ∈_ℓ(V^*), not necessarily a rational function, the
  homogeneous component ϕ_[m] of degree m of ϕ is
  defined by considering ϕ(τξ) as a meromorphic function of one
  variable τ∈, with Laurent series expansion
 
    ϕ(τξ) = ∑_m≥ m_0τ^m ϕ_[m](ξ).

term: homogeneous of degree at least~$m$;homogeneous of degree~$m$
def:
\label{def:Mell}~
  \begin{enumerate}[\rm(a)]
  \item We denote by $\CM_{\ell}(V^*)$ the ring of meromorphic functions
    around $0\in V^*_\C$ which can be written as a quotient
    $\frac{\phi(\xi)}{\prod_{j=1}^{N}  \la\xi,w_j\ra}$, where $\phi(\xi)$ is holomorphic
    near $0$ and $w_j$ are non-zero elements of $V$ in finite number.
  \item
    We denote by ${\mathcal R}_{[\geq m]}(V^*)$ the space of rational
    functions which can be written as $\frac{P(\xi)}{\prod_{j=1}^{N}
      \la\xi,w_j\ra}$, where $P$ is a homogeneous polynomial of degree greater
    or equal to $m+N$.  These rational functions are said to be
    \emph{homogeneous of degree at least~$m$} .
  \item We denote by ${\mathcal R}_{[ m]}(V^*)$ the space of rational
    functions which can be written as $\frac{P(\xi)}{\prod_{j=1}^{N}
      \la\xi,w_j\ra}$, where $P$ is homogeneous of degree $m+N$.
    These rational functions are said to be \emph{homogeneous of degree~$m$} .
  \end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
* We denote by _ℓ(V^*) the ring of meromorphic functions
    around 0∈ V^*_ which can be written as a quotient
    ϕ(ξ)/∏_j=1^Nξ,w_j, where ϕ(ξ) is holomorphic
    near 0 and w_j are non-zero elements of V in finite number.
  
  * We denote by ℛ_[≥ m](V^*) the space of rational
    functions which can be written as P(ξ)/∏_j=1^Nξ,w_j, where P is a homogeneous polynomial of degree greater
    or equal to m+N.  These rational functions are said to be
    homogeneous of degree at least m .
  
  * We denote by ℛ_[ m](V^*) the space of rational
    functions which can be written as P(ξ)/∏_j=1^Nξ,w_j, where P is homogeneous of degree m+N.
    These rational functions are said to be homogeneous of degree m .
plain_text_term: homogeneous of degree at least m;homogeneous of degree m
