def: A \emph{plabic graph} is an undirected graph $G$ drawn inside a disk $D$ (up to homotopy) which has a finite number of vertices on the boundary of $D$. Each of the remaining vertices of $G$ is strictly inside the disk and colored either black or white. Each vertex on the boundary of $D$ is incident to a single edge.
plain_text_def: A plabic graph is an undirected graph G drawn inside a disk D (up to homotopy) which has a finite number of vertices on the boundary of D. Each of the remaining vertices of G is strictly inside the disk and colored either black or white. Each vertex on the boundary of D is incident to a single edge.

def: A \textit{plabic graph} $\mathcal{G}$ is a planar bicolored graph embedded in a disk. It has $n$ boundary vertices numbered $1,\dots, n$ in a counterclockwise order. Boundary vertices lie on the boundary of the disk and are not colored. Additionally there are internal vertices colored black or white. Each boundary vertex is adjacent to a single internal vertex.
plain_text_def: A plabic graph 𝒢 is a planar bicolored graph embedded in a disk. It has n boundary vertices numbered 1,…, n in a counterclockwise order. Boundary vertices lie on the boundary of the disk and are not colored. Additionally there are internal vertices colored black or white. Each boundary vertex is adjacent to a single internal vertex.

def:
\label{def:relation}
	Let $T$ be a triangulation on $\Sg$ (possibly with holes), $g>0$, and let $d=\{e_1,e_2\}$ be a \emph{planar} double edge.
	If $c\neq d$ is a face, edge, or double edge, we write $c<d$ if the triangulation of the disc
	obtained by cutting along $d$ contains $c$.
plain_text_def:
Let T be a triangulation on  (possibly with holes), g>0, and let d={e_1,e_2} be a planar double edge.
	If c≠ d is a face, edge, or double edge, we write c<d if the triangulation of the disc
	obtained by cutting along d contains c.

A nearring (N,+,· ) is said to be planar if:

    
  * |N/≡_m|≥3;
    
  * ∀ a,b,c∈ N, with a≢_m b, the equation
        a·x=b·x+c
        has a unique solution in N.

A plane partition is a two dimensional array of positive integers {t_i,j} that weakly decreases across rows from left to right and down columns. We will sometimes take the array to be rectangular, in which case we complete the array to a rectangle by adding entries equal to zero. So we have the following n× m array satisfying t_i,j≥ t_i+1,j≥ 0 and t_i,j≥ t_i,j+1≥ 0.


[ t_1,1 t_1,2 t_1,3     ⋯ t_1,m; t_2,1 t_2,2 t_2,3       t_2,m;     ⋮                       ⋮; t_n,1 t_n,2 t_n,3     ⋯ t_n,m;       ]

def:
A \emph{plane partition} is a two-dimensional array of positive integers which weakly decrease across rows from left to right and weakly decrease down columns.
%
plain_text_def: A plane partition is a two-dimensional array of positive integers which weakly decrease across rows from left to right and weakly decrease down columns.

def:
\label{def:design}
		Let $P$ be a set with $v$ elements that are called \emph{points} . A \emph{$t$-$(v,k,\lambda)$~design} , or \emph{$t$-design} , in brief, is a collection of $k$-subsets, called \emph{blocks} , of $P$ such that every $t$-subset of $P$ is contained in exactly $\lambda$ blocks.
plain_text_def: Let P be a set with v elements that are called points . A t-(v,k,λ) design , or t-design , in brief, is a collection of k-subsets, called blocks , of P such that every t-subset of P is contained in exactly λ blocks.

def:
\label{def:design}
		Let $P$ be a set with $v$ elements ( \emph{points} ). A \emph{$t$-$(v,k,\lambda)$~design} (or \emph{$t$-design} , in brief) is a collection of $k$-subsets ( \emph{blocks} ) of $P$ such that each $t$-subset of $P$ is contained in exactly $\lambda$ blocks.
plain_text_def: Let P be a set with v elements ( points ). A t-(v,k,λ) design (or t-design , in brief) is a collection of k-subsets ( blocks ) of P such that each t-subset of P is contained in exactly λ blocks.

def: A (possibly multisort) species of structures ${\mathcal F}$ is \emph{polynomial} if there exists $n\geq 0$ such that  ${\mathcal F}_{\geq n}=0$. In other words, there are only a finite number of ${\mathcal F}$-structures.
plain_text_def: A (possibly multisort) species of structures ℱ is polynomial if there exists n≥ 0 such that  ℱ_≥ n=0. In other words, there are only a finite number of ℱ-structures.

def:
\label{profilpouzet1}
Let $R := (E, (\rho_i)_{i \in I})$ be a relational structure on an infinite set. Then, $\profile_R$ is non-decreasing. And provided that either the signature $\mu : =
  (n_i)_{i \in I}$ is bounded or the kernel $K(R)$ of $R$ is finite, the
  growth of $\profile_R$ is either \emph{polynomial} or as fast as
  every polynomial.
plain_text_def:
Let R := (E, (ρ_i)_i ∈ I) be a relational structure on an infinite set. Then, _R is non-decreasing. And provided that either the signature μ : =
  (n_i)_i ∈ I is bounded or the kernel K(R) of R is finite, the
  growth of _R is either polynomial or as fast as
  every polynomial.

[Polynomial map]
Suppose that H and G are I-filtered groups with H = (H,+) abelian[This is not actually a necessary assumption; see Appendix <ref>.  However, in the main body of the paper we will only be concerned with polynomial maps on additive domains.]. Then for any map g : H → G we define the derivative 

    ∂_h g(n) := g(n+h) g(n)^-1.
 
We say that g : H → G is polynomial if

    ∂_h_1…∂_h_m g (n) ∈ G_i_1 + … + i_m

for all m ≥ 0, all i_1,…, i_m ∈ I and all h_j ∈ H_i_j for j = 1,…, m, and for all n ∈ H_0. 

We denote by (H_I → G_I) the space of all polynomial maps from H_I to G_I.  As usual, we use (H_I → G_I) to denote the space of all limit polynomial maps from H_I to G_I (i.e. ultralimits of polynomial maps in (H_I → G_I)).

def:
\label{profilpouzet1}
  Let $R := (E, (\rho_i)_{i \in I})$ be a relational structure on an
  infinite set. Then, $\profile_R$ is non-decreasing. And provided
  that either the signature $\mu$ is bounded or the kernel $K(R)$ of
  $R$ is finite, the growth of $\profile_R$ is either
  \emph{polynomial} or as fast as every polynomial.
plain_text_def:
Let R := (E, (ρ_i)_i ∈ I) be a relational structure on an
  infinite set. Then, _R is non-decreasing. And provided
  that either the signature μ is bounded or the kernel K(R) of
  R is finite, the growth of _R is either
  polynomial or as fast as every polynomial.

def:
[Polytopal complex]
A \emph{polytopal complex} is a finite collection $\sC$ of polytopes of $\RR^n$ satisfying the following conditions:
\begin{enumerate}
\item the empty polytope $\emptyset$ is contained in $\sC$,
\item $P \in \sC$ implies $\La(P) \subset \sC$, 
\item $P, Q\in \sC$ implies $P\cap Q\in \La(P)\cap \La(Q)$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
[Polytopal complex]
A polytopal complex is a finite collection  of polytopes of ^n satisfying the following conditions:


  * the empty polytope ∅ is contained in ,

  * P ∈ implies (P) ⊂, 

  * P, Q∈ implies P∩ Q∈(P)∩(Q).

A polytopal complex 𝒞⊆ℝ^d is a finite set of polytopes such that



  * The empty face is present. That is, ∅∈𝒞.

  * If P ∈𝒞, then all proper faces of P are also in C. 

  * For any P, Q ∈𝒞, if P ∩ Q = F where F ≠∅, then F is a face of both P and Q.

def:
[Poset dimension]
Let $(\mathcal{P}, \lhd)$ be a poset (partially ordered set). A {\em linear extension} $L$ of $\mathcal{P}$ is a total order which satisfies $(x \lhd y \in \mathcal{P}) \implies (x \lhd y \in L)$. A {\em realiser} of $\mathcal{P}$ is a set of linear extensions of $\mathcal{P}$, say $\mathcal{R}$, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements $x$ and $y$, $x\lhd y \in \mathcal{P}$ if and only if $x \lhd y \in L$, $\forall L \in \mathcal{R}$.  
The \emph{poset dimension} of $\mathcal{P}$, denoted by $dim(\mathcal{P})$, is the minimum integer $k$ such that there exists a realiser of $\mathcal{P}$ of cardinality $k$. % The {\em height} of $P$ is the length of a largest chain in $P$.
plain_text_def:
[Poset dimension]
Let (𝒫, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of 𝒫 is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈𝒫)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of 𝒫 is a set of linear extensions of 𝒫, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈𝒫 if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  
The poset dimension of 𝒫, denoted by dim(𝒫), is the minimum integer k such that there exists a realiser of 𝒫 of cardinality k.

def:
[Poset dimension]
\label{definitionPosetDimension}
Let $(\mathcal{P}, \lhd)$ be a poset (partially ordered set). A {\em linear extension} $L$ of $\mathcal{P}$ is a total order which satisfies $(x \lhd y \in \mathcal{P}) \implies (x \lhd y \in L)$. A {\em realiser} of $\mathcal{P}$ is a set of linear extensions of $\mathcal{P}$, say $\mathcal{R}$, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements $x$ and $y$, $x\lhd y \in \mathcal{P}$ if and only if $x \lhd y \in L$, $\forall L \in \mathcal{R}$.  
The \emph{poset dimension} of $\mathcal{P}$, denoted by $dim(\mathcal{P})$, is the minimum integer $k$ such that there exists a realiser of $\mathcal{P}$ of cardinality $k$. % The {\em height} of $P$ is the length of a largest chain in $P$.
plain_text_def:
[Poset dimension]

Let (𝒫, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of 𝒫 is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈𝒫)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of 𝒫 is a set of linear extensions of 𝒫, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈𝒫 if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  
The poset dimension of 𝒫, denoted by dim(𝒫), is the minimum integer k such that there exists a realiser of 𝒫 of cardinality k.

def:
[Poset dimension]
Let $(P, \lhd)$ be a poset (partially ordered set). A {\em linear extension} $L$ of $P$ is a total order which satisfies $(x \lhd y \in P) \implies (x \lhd y \in L)$. A {\em realiser} of $P$ is a set of linear extensions of $P$, say $\mathcal{R}$, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements $x$ and $y$, $x\lhd y \in P$ if and only if $x \lhd y \in L$, $\forall L \in \mathcal{R}$.  The \emph{poset dimension} of $P$, denoted by $\pdim(P)$, is the minimum positive integer $k$ such that there exists a realiser of $P$ of cardinality $k$.
plain_text_def:
[Poset dimension]
Let (P, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of P is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈ P)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of P is a set of linear extensions of P, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈ P if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  The poset dimension of P, denoted by (P), is the minimum positive integer k such that there exists a realiser of P of cardinality k.

def:
A \emph{position} $p$ is a sequence $p=(W_0,W_1,\ldots,W_s)$ of ordered subsets of wagons such that 
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\bigcup_{i=0}^s W_i=W$ as sets,
\item $W_i$ and $W_j$ are disjoint whenever $i\not=j$,
\item $|W_i|\leq m_i$ for $1\leq i\leq s$, and
\item $|W_0|\leq h$.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A position p is a sequence p=(W_0,W_1,…,W_s) of ordered subsets of wagons such that 


  * ⋃_i=0^s W_i=W as sets,

  * W_i and W_j are disjoint whenever i≠j,

  * |W_i|≤ m_i for 1≤ i≤ s, and

  * |W_0|≤ h.

def: A \emph{position} is a mapping from the vertices of $G$ to the nonnegative integers.
plain_text_def: A position is a mapping from the vertices of G to the nonnegative integers.

def:
[Universally positive]\label{d:universallypositive}
We say that a Laurent polynomial is \emph{positive} if all of its coefficients are in $\R_{>0}$. An element $h\in\C[\opencheckX]$ is called {\it universally positive}  (for the $\mathcal A$-cluster structure) if for every $\mathcal A$-cluster seed  $\check\Sigma_G^{\mathcal A}$ the expansion $\mathbf h^G$ of $h$ in $\PCG$ is a positive Laurent polynomial. Similarly $f\in\C[\opencheckX \times \C^*]$ is called universally positive if its expansion $\mathbf f^G$ in the variables $\PCG\cup\{q\}$ is given by a positive Laurent polynomial for every seed $\check\Sigma_G^{\mathcal A}$.
plain_text_def:
[Universally positive]
We say that a Laurent polynomial is positive if all of its coefficients are in _>0. An element h∈[] is called universally positive  (for the 𝒜-cluster structure) if for every 𝒜-cluster seed  Σ̌_G^𝒜 the expansion 𝐡^G of h in  is a positive Laurent polynomial. Similarly f∈[×^*] is called universally positive if its expansion 𝐟^G in the variables ∪{q} is given by a positive Laurent polynomial for every seed Σ̌_G^𝒜.

def:
A cycle 2-cover $\{c_k,\ k=1,\cdots N\}$ of a graph is called
  \emph{positive} if the quadratic form $q=\frac12\sum_{k=1}^N c_k^2$ is
  positive definite.
plain_text_def:
A cycle 2-cover {c_k, k=1,⋯ N} of a graph is called
  positive if the quadratic form q=1/2∑_k=1^N c_k^2 is
  positive definite.

def: Call a $c$-cluster $C$ in $\Phi_{\ap}(c)$  \emph{positive} if $C\subset\Phi_+$.
plain_text_def: Call a c-cluster C in Φ_(c)  positive if C⊂Φ_+.

def:
\label{def:positive_grassmannian}
The {\textit{positive Grassmannian}}, $\Gr_{\geq 0}(k,n)$, is the subset of $\Gr(k,n)$ where all Pl\"ucker coordinates have the same sign.
plain_text_def: The positive Grassmannian, _≥ 0(k,n), is the subset of (k,n) where all Plücker coordinates have the same sign.

def:
The \emph{positive Grassmannian} $\Gr^+(k,n)$ is the 
subset of the real Grassmannian where all Pl\"ucker coordinates
are non-negative.
% (equivalently, all Pl\"ucker coordinates are non-positive).
plain_text_def:
The positive Grassmannian ^+(k,n) is the 
subset of the real Grassmannian where all Plücker coordinates
are non-negative.

def:
[Signed Sets]
A signed set is a set $A$ together with a decomposition $A=A^+\cup
A^-$ where $A^+\cap A^-=\emptyset$. 
The members of $A^+$ are \emph{positive} elements, those of
$A^-$ are \emph{negative} .
plain_text_def:
[Signed Sets]
A signed set is a set A together with a decomposition A=A^+∪
A^- where A^+∩ A^-=∅. 
The members of A^+ are positive elements, those of
A^- are negative .

def:
For every $i=1,\ldots, s$, let $P_{i,i-1}$ be an arbitrary point on $l_{i-1}\cap \Cl_i$ (note that there are $t_i$ such points), and let $P_{i,i}$ be its neighbor on $l_i$.

We construct two different types of paths in $\Cl_{i}$: all of them start at $P_{i,i-1}$ and
\begin{enumerate}
\item the next vertex is $P_{i,i}$. The other vertices in the path are easily determined from these first two, or
\item the next vertex is the neighbor of $P_{i,i-1}$ in $\Cl_{i}$ that is on the line $l_{i-2 \mod q+1}$. The other vertices in the path are easily determined from these first two.
\end{enumerate}
We will say that the first path is a \emph{positive} path, and that the second is a \emph{negative} path.
plain_text_def:
For every i=1,…, s, let P_i,i-1 be an arbitrary point on l_i-1∩_i (note that there are t_i such points), and let P_i,i be its neighbor on l_i.

We construct two different types of paths in _i: all of them start at P_i,i-1 and


  * the next vertex is P_i,i. The other vertices in the path are easily determined from these first two, or

  * the next vertex is the neighbor of P_i,i-1 in _i that is on the line l_i-2  q+1. The other vertices in the path are easily determined from these first two.

We will say that the first path is a positive path, and that the second is a negative path.

 \p_+(\rhc) := \{\rhpourMr, \rhpollWr, \rhpourMll, \rhpollWll\},\quad
 \p_-(\rhc) := \{\rhpoulMl, \rhpolrWl, \rhpoulMrr, \rhpolrWrr\},\mbox{ and }

$$

\emph{positive} ,
\emph{negative} , and 
\emph{neutral slack contributions} of 
the rhombus $\rhc$, respectively.

    _+() := {, , , },  _-() := {, , , },_0() := {,,,}

are called the sets of  of 
positive ,

the rhombus , respectively.
