  %(a) $|V_1|>1$ and $|V_2|>2$ and (b) every vertex $N(V_1)$ is
  %adjacent to every vertex of $N(V_2)$.
  \begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*), noitemsep, nosep]
  \item $|V_1|>2$ and $|V_2|>2$;
  \item every vertex of $N(V_1)$ is adjacent to every of $N(V_2)$.
  \end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A split <cit.> of a graph G with vertex set V is
  a bipartition (V_1,V_2) of V ( i.e. ,
  V=V_1∪ V_2, V_1∩V_2=∅)
  such that
  
  
  
  
  * |V_1|>2 and |V_2|>2;
  
  * every vertex of N(V_1) is adjacent to every of N(V_2).

def:
Let $G$ be a simple graph. A \emph{split} $(V_{1}$, $X_{1}$; $V_{2}$, $X_{2})$
of $G$ is given by a partition $V(G)=V_{1}\cup V_{2}$ with $\left\vert
V_{1}\right\vert $, $\left\vert V_{2}\right\vert \geq2$ and subsets
$X_{i}\subseteq V_{i}$ with these properties: the complete bipartite graph
with vertex-classes $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$ is a subgraph of $G$, and $G$ does not
have any other edge from $V_{1}$ to $V_{2}$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a simple graph. A split (V_1, X_1; V_2, X_2)
of G is given by a partition V(G)=V_1∪ V_2 with |
V_1|, | V_2|≥2 and subsets
X_i⊆ V_i with these properties: the complete bipartite graph
with vertex-classes X_1 and X_2 is a subgraph of G, and G does not
have any other edge from V_1 to V_2.

Let P, P_1, and P_2 be three positions. We say that (P_1, P_2) is a split of P if there exist two positions Q_0 and Q_1 such that



  * For all vertices v of G, P(v) = Q_0(v) + Q_1(v).

  * For all vertices v of G, P_1(v) is the sum of Q_0(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 0-arc in G points from u to v.

  * For all vertices v of G, P_2(v) is the sum of Q_1(u) over all vertices u of G such that a 1-arc in G points from u to v.

def:
%
  \label{def:split}%
  A \emph{split}~\cite{Cunningham82} of a graph $G$ with vertex set $V$ is a bipartition $(\cramped{V_1},\cramped{V_2})$ of $V$ ( \textit{i.e.} , $V=\cramped{V_1}\cup V_2$, $\cramped{V_1}\cap \cramped{V_2}=\emptyset$) such that
  \begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*), noitemsep, nosep]
  \item $|V_1|\geqslant 2$ and $|V_2|\geqslant 2$;
  \item every vertex of $N(\cramped{V_1})$ is adjacent to every vertex of $N(\cramped{V_2})$.
  \end{enumerate}

Given $n,k,t$, positive integers with $n\geq t  \geq 2$, we define the $k$-uniform hypergraph $\mathcal{F}_k(n,t)\subseteq \binom{[n]}{k}$:
\[
\mathcal{F}_k(n,t):= \left\{A\in \binom{[n]}{k}\colon A\cap [t]\neq \emptyset\right\}.
\] 
Furthermore,
\[\mathfrak{F}_k(n,t,r)=\{\mathcal{H}\subseteq \binom{[n]}{k}\colon \mathcal{F}_k(n,t)\subseteq \mathcal{H}, e(\mathcal{H})=e(\mathcal{F}_k(n,t))+r   \}\]
is the family of  $k$-hypergraphs that contains $\mathcal{F}_k(n,t)$ as a subhypergraph and has exactly $r$ edges with no vertices in $[t]$. The graph $\mathcal{F}_2(n,t)$ is also known as a \emph{split graph} (see \cite{golumbic2004algorithmic}).
plain_text_def:
Given n,k,t, positive integers with n≥ t  ≥ 2, we define the k-uniform hypergraph ℱ_k(n,t)⊆[n]k:

    ℱ_k(n,t):= {A∈[n]k A∩ [t]≠∅}.
 
Furthermore,

    𝔉_k(n,t,r)={ℋ⊆[n]kℱ_k(n,t)⊆ℋ, e(ℋ)=e(ℱ_k(n,t))+r   }

is the family of  k-hypergraphs that contains ℱ_k(n,t) as a subhypergraph and has exactly r edges with no vertices in [t]. The graph ℱ_2(n,t) is also known as a split graph (see <cit.>).

def: A \emph{split graph} is a graph in which the vertices can be partitioned into a clique and an independent set.
plain_text_def: A split graph is a graph in which the vertices can be partitioned into a clique and an independent set.

def:
[Split graph]
A graph $G$ is called \emph{split graph} if the node set can be partitioned
into a clique $C$ and a stable set $S$.
plain_text_def:
[Split graph]
A graph G is called split graph if the node set can be partitioned
into a clique C and a stable set S.

def:
A connected graph $G$ is \emph{splittable} if there exists an independent set $\Sigma$ in $G^2$ such
that $G - \Sigma$ is disconnected.
plain_text_def:
A connected graph G is splittable if there exists an independent set Σ in G^2 such
that G - Σ is disconnected.

def: A collection $B_1,\ldots B_n$ of subsets of $[k]$ is \emph{splittable} if there exists $A\subseteq[k]$ which simultaneously splits all the $B_i$.
plain_text_def: A collection B_1,… B_n of subsets of [k] is splittable if there exists A⊆[k] which simultaneously splits all the B_i.

def: Given an Euler circuit $C$ of a $\st$-graph $\Gamma$, a 6-vertex $v \in \Gamma$ is \emph{splitting} if for some $a \in C^{-1}(\{v\})$, $C(a+\epsilon)$ and $C(a-\epsilon)$ are on opposite half-edges around $v$, and for the other two points $b, c \in C^{-1}(\{v\})$, $C(b+\epsilon)$ and $C(b-\epsilon)$ are on adjacent half-edges, and $C(c+\epsilon)$ and $C(c-\epsilon)$ are on adjacent half-edges.
plain_text_def: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ, a 6-vertex v ∈Γ is splitting if for some a ∈ C^-1({v}), C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) are on opposite half-edges around v, and for the other two points b, c ∈ C^-1({v}), C(b+ϵ) and C(b-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges, and C(c+ϵ) and C(c-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges.

def:
Let $F(x_i)$ be an element of $\QQ[[\xx, \pp]]$, considered as a power series in $x_i$, and let $j \geq 1$ be an index other than $i \geq 1$. Then the $i$-to-$j$ \emph{splitting} operator is defined by
  \[
    \Split_{i \to j} F(x_i) = \frac{x_j F(x_i) - x_i F(x_j)}{x_i - x_j} + F(0),
  \]
  so that
  \[
    \Split_{i \to j} x_i^k = x_i^{k-1} x_j + x_i^{k-2} x_j^2 + \cdots + x_i x_j^{k-1}.
  \]
plain_text_def:
Let F(x_i) be an element of [[, ]], considered as a power series in x_i, and let j ≥ 1 be an index other than i ≥ 1. Then the i-to-j splitting operator is defined by
  
    _i → j F(x_i) = x_j F(x_i) - x_i F(x_j)/x_i - x_j + F(0),

  so that
  
    _i → j x_i^k = x_i^k-1 x_j + x_i^k-2 x_j^2 + ⋯ + x_i x_j^k-1.

def: Given an Euler circuit $C$ of a $\st$-graph $\Gamma$, a 6-vertex $v \in \Gamma$ is \emph{splitting} with respect to $C$ if for some $a \in C^{-1}(\{v\})$, $C(a+\epsilon)$ and $C(a-\epsilon)$ are on opposite half-edges around $v$, and for the other two points $b, c \in C^{-1}(\{v\})$, $C(b+\epsilon)$ and $C(b-\epsilon)$ are on adjacent half-edges, and $C(c+\epsilon)$ and $C(c-\epsilon)$ are on adjacent half-edges.
plain_text_def: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ, a 6-vertex v ∈Γ is splitting with respect to C if for some a ∈ C^-1({v}), C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) are on opposite half-edges around v, and for the other two points b, c ∈ C^-1({v}), C(b+ϵ) and C(b-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges, and C(c+ϵ) and C(c-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges.

def:
A connected trivalent  graph $G$ is called \emph{sprawling}
 if there exists a vertex $s$ of $G$ such that $G \backslash \{s\}$ consists of three distinct components.
plain_text_def:
A connected trivalent  graph G is called sprawling
 if there exists a vertex s of G such that G \{s} consists of three distinct components.

def:
A connected, trivalent, leafless graph $G$ is called \emph{sprawling}
 if there exists a vertex $s$ of $G$ such that $G \backslash \{s\}$ consists of three distinct components.
plain_text_def:
A connected, trivalent, leafless graph G is called sprawling
 if there exists a vertex s of G such that G \{s} consists of three distinct components.

Let r, k and ℓ be fixed. The problem 𝒫_n,r,k,ℓ of determining (n,r,k,ℓ) is stable if, for every >0, there exist δ>0 and n_0>0 such that the following is satisfied. Let H^∗ be an r-uniform extremal hypergraph for (n,r,k,ℓ), where n>n_0, and let H be an r-uniform hypergraph on [n] satisfying κ(H,k,ℓ) > (1-δ) (n,r,k,ℓ). Then 
 |E(H) △ E(H')|<  |E(H')| for some hypergraph H' isomorphic to H^∗.

def:
[Shelah]
 A formula $\phi(\xbar;\ybar)$ is \textit{stable} in $\mcm$ if for some $N \in \omega$ there are not sequences $\abar_1,\ldots,\abar_N \in M^{|\xbar|}$ and $\bbar_1,\ldots,\bbar_N \in M^{|\ybar|}$ such that $\phi(\abar_i;\bbar_j)^\mcm \iff i < j$.
plain_text_def:
[Shelah]
 A formula ϕ(;) is stable in  if for some N ∈ω there are not sequences _1,…,_N ∈ M^|| and _1,…,_N ∈ M^|| such that ϕ(_i;_j)^ i < j.

def:
Let $\TT$ denote the operator on $\NN^a$ such that  
$$
\TT(z_0, z_1, \cdots, z_{a-1}) = (z_1, \cdots, z_{a-1}, z_0),
$$
for any $(z_0, z_1, \cdots, z_{a-1}) \in \NN^a$. Let $S$ be a set of tuples $(z_0, z_1, \cdots z_{a-1}) \in \NN^a$. We say $S$ is \emph{stable} under $\TT$ if $\TT(S) = S$.
plain_text_def:
Let  denote the operator on ^a such that  

    (z_0, z_1, ⋯, z_a-1) = (z_1, ⋯, z_a-1, z_0),

for any (z_0, z_1, ⋯, z_a-1) ∈^a. Let S be a set of tuples (z_0, z_1, ⋯ z_a-1) ∈^a. We say S is stable under  if (S) = S.

def: Let $P$ be a graph property.  We say that $P$ is \emph{stable} if for any graph $G$ satisfying $P$ and any maximal degree vertex $x$ of $G$, both $G - \st x$ and $G - x$ satisfy $P$.
plain_text_def: Let P be a graph property.  We say that P is stable if for any graph G satisfying P and any maximal degree vertex x of G, both G -  x and G - x satisfy P.

def: A relative map $[f:C\to \PP^1]$ is said to be \textit{stable} if $f_1$-contracted genus $0$ components have at least $3$ special points, and for $i\neq 0$, there exists a component $C'$ of $C$ mapping to $T$ that is not a trivial bubble.
plain_text_def: A relative map [f:C→^1] is said to be stable if f_1-contracted genus 0 components have at least 3 special points, and for i≠ 0, there exists a component C' of C mapping to T that is not a trivial bubble.

def:
\label{def:guaranteed}
Let $G\in \mathbb{S}$ be an atomic game. Then $G$ is \emph{stable} if $\LS(G)\leqslant \RS(G)$, and $G$ is guaranteed if, for every atom $\emptyset^s$ which is a follower of $\GL$, and every atom $\emptyset^t$ which is a follower of $\GR$, $s\leqslant t$. In general, a game in $\mathbb{S}$ is \textit{stable} ( \emph{guaranteed} ) if every atomic follower is stable (guaranteed). Let $\GB$ be the class of all guaranteed Scoring games.
plain_text_def: Let G∈𝕊 be an atomic game. Then G is stable if (G)⩽(G), and G is guaranteed if, for every atom ∅^s which is a follower of , and every atom ∅^t which is a follower of , s⩽ t. In general, a game in 𝕊 is stable ( guaranteed ) if every atomic follower is stable (guaranteed). Let  be the class of all guaranteed Scoring games.

def: A strategy for Alice is \emph{stable} if, whenever Alice makes a move following this strategy, she moves to a position $w$ such that $R(G_w)$ is as small as possible.
plain_text_def: A strategy for Alice is stable if, whenever Alice makes a move following this strategy, she moves to a position w such that R(G_w) is as small as possible.

def:
A weak dual equivalence for $(\mathcal{A},\des)$ is \emph{stable} if the restricted dual equivalence classes of degrees up to $6$ are $\fund$-stable key polynomials.
  \label{def:deg-weak-stable}
plain_text_def: A weak dual equivalence for (𝒜,) is stable if the restricted dual equivalence classes of degrees up to 6 are -stable key polynomials.

Let = (, ≼) be a partially ordered subset of 2^S not
    containing the empty set. We say that  is a staircase diagram
    if the following are true:
    
        
  * Every B∈ is connected, and if B covers B' then B∪ B' is connected.
        
  * The subset _s is a chain for every s ∈ S.
        
  * If s t, then _s∪_t is a chain, and _s and _t
            are saturated subchains of _s ∪_t.
        
  * If B∈, then there is some s∈ S (resp. s'∈ S) such
            that B is the minimum element of _s (resp. maximum element of
            _s').

[<cit.>]
    Let Γ be a graph with vertex set S.  Let = (, ≼) be a partially ordered subset of 2^S not
    containing the empty set. We say that  is a staircase diagram
    if the following are true:
    
        
  * Every B∈ is connected, and if B covers B' then B∪ B' is connected.
        
  * The subset _s is a chain for every s ∈ S.
        
  * If s t, then _s∪_t is a chain, and _s and _t
            are saturated subchains of _s ∪_t.
        
  * If B∈, then there is some s∈ S (resp. s'∈ S) such
            that B is the minimum element of _s (resp. maximum element of
            _s').

Given a tableau U in _d(), let W = W_1 ⋯ W_n ∈ [d]^n be the reading word of U (as in Definition–Proposition <ref>), and let W' = (d + 1 - W_n) ⋯ (d + 1 - W_1) be the reverse-complement of W.  Under RSK, W' corresponds to a pair (P(W'), Q(W')), and we define e_d(U) = P(W').  In particular, if U is a standard tableau, then W is a permutation, W' = w_0 W w_0 as elements of _n, and e_n(U) = e(U) is the usual evacuation defined in <ref>.

Further, we define a map e_d^* = w_0 ∘ e_d, where w_0 is the longest element of _d acting as in Definition–Proposition <ref>.

def:
Given a word $w$ let $v$ be the letters of $w$ to which the
through strings of the unique $w$-admissible half-pairing
are attached. Then $v$ is a cyclic reduction of $w$ -- we
shall call it the \textit{standard} cyclic reduction of $w$
and denote it $\wh{w}$.
plain_text_def:
Given a word w let v be the letters of w to which the
through strings of the unique w-admissible half-pairing
are attached. Then v is a cyclic reduction of w – we
shall call it the standard cyclic reduction of w
and denote it w.

def: Let \(\lambda\) be a partition of \(n\). A \(\lambda\)-tableau is said to be \emph{standard} if the numbers are strictly increasing along each row and down each column.
plain_text_def: Let λ be a partition of n. A λ-tableau is said to be standard if the numbers are strictly increasing along each row and down each column.

def:
[standard permutation]
The permutation $\s$ is \emph{standard} if $\s(1)=1$.
plain_text_def:
[standard permutation]
The permutation  is standard if (1)=1.

def:
[Grosshans--Rota--Stein {\cite{grs}}]\label{thm:std basis}
  The elements $\tab(T_r|T_c) \in \Super(L^-|P^+)$ where 
  \begin{enumerate}
  \item $T_r$ and $T_c$ are tableaux of the same shape,
  \item $T_r$ is row strict with entries in $[n]$,
  \item $T_c$ is column strict,
  \end{enumerate}
  form a basis for the free module $\Super(L^-|P^+)$. We will call
  such tableaux \textit{standard} .

  In the expansion of $\tab(T|S)$ as a sum of standard tableaux
  $\sum_i c_i\tab(T_i|S_i)$ we have that the shape of each $T_i$ is
  larger than or equal to the shape of $T$, in dominance
  order. Further, the content of every $T_i$ is equal to the content
  of $T$ and the content of every $S_i$ is equal to the content of
  $S$.
plain_text_def:
[Grosshans–Rota–Stein <cit.>]
  The elements (T_r|T_c) ∈(L^-|P^+) where 
  
  
  * T_r and T_c are tableaux of the same shape,
  
  * T_r is row strict with entries in [n],
  
  * T_c is column strict,
  
  form a basis for the free module (L^-|P^+). We will call
  such tableaux standard .

  In the expansion of (T|S) as a sum of standard tableaux
  ∑_i c_i(T_i|S_i) we have that the shape of each T_i is
  larger than or equal to the shape of T, in dominance
  order. Further, the content of every T_i is equal to the content
  of T and the content of every S_i is equal to the content of
  S.

def: A tableau $t$ of $\lambda$ will be called \textit{standard} if all of its entries are increasing from left to right along a row and from top to bottom down a column.
plain_text_def: A tableau t of λ will be called standard if all of its entries are increasing from left to right along a row and from top to bottom down a column.

def:
\label{def:thinbasis}
The basis in Lemma   \ref{lemma:thin2}(ii) is called \emph{standard} .
plain_text_def: The basis in Lemma   <ref>(ii) is called standard .

def: A word $m_{x'}^{c'}$ obtained as described above is called a \emph{standard form} of $x'\in\mathcal{P}_{c'}$
plain_text_def: A word m_x'^c' obtained as described above is called a standard form of x'∈𝒫_c'

def:
[Standard form of a dominant equation]\label{definition=standard}
Let $b_1x_1+b_2x_2+\cdots +b_rx_r=0$ be a balanced and dominant $\mathbb{Z}$-equation. Then we may rewrite the equation above, only by transposition of terms, as that of the form
\[
b'_jx_j=\sum_{i\in [r]\setminus \{j\}}b_i'x_i,\quad \textrm{where},\quad b'_j=\sum_{i\in [r]\setminus \{j\}}b_i'.
\]
Here $b'_j>0$, for all $i\in [r]$, $b'_i\geq 0$, and $b_j'=\sum_{i\in [r]\setminus \{j\}}b_i'$. It is called a \textit{standard form} of the dominant equation.
plain_text_def:
[Standard form of a dominant equation]
Let b_1x_1+b_2x_2+⋯ +b_rx_r=0 be a balanced and dominant ℤ-equation. Then we may rewrite the equation above, only by transposition of terms, as that of the form

    b'_jx_j=∑_i∈ [r]∖{j}b_i'x_i,  where,   b'_j=∑_i∈ [r]∖{j}b_i'.

Here b'_j>0, for all i∈ [r], b'_i≥ 0, and b_j'=∑_i∈ [r]∖{j}b_i'. It is called a standard form of the dominant equation.

def:
A \emph{standard key tableau} is a bijective filling of a key diagram with $\{1,2,\ldots,n\}$ such that rows weakly decrease and if some entry $i$ is above and in the same column as an entry $k$ with $i<k$, then there is an entry immediately right of $k$, say $j$, and $i<j$. 
  \label{def:key-tab}
plain_text_def: A standard key tableau is a bijective filling of a key diagram with {1,2,…,n} such that rows weakly decrease and if some entry i is above and in the same column as an entry k with i<k, then there is an entry immediately right of k, say j, and i<j.

[<cit.>]
  A standard key tableau is a bijective filling of a key diagram with {1,2,…,n} such that rows decrease (left to right) and if some entry i is above and in the same column as an entry k with i<k, then there is an entry right of k, say j, such that i<j.

def:
Let $w=w_1w_2\dots w_k$ be a word and let
$a_1 < a_2 < \cdots < a_\ell$ be the ordered list of letters
appearing in~$w$. The \emph{standardization}
of~$w$ %, written $\std(w)$, 
 is the word formed by replacing $a_i$ with $i$ in $w$.

Similarly, let $T$ be a tableau and let
$a_1 < a_2 < \cdots < a_\ell$ be the ordered list
of letters appearing in~$T$.
The standardization of~$T$ is the tableau
formed from $T$ by replacing every entry $a_i$ with $i$.
plain_text_def:
Let w=w_1w_2… w_k be a word and let
a_1 < a_2 < ⋯ < a_ℓ be the ordered list of letters
appearing in w. The standardization
of w 
 is the word formed by replacing a_i with i in w.

Similarly, let T be a tableau and let
a_1 < a_2 < ⋯ < a_ℓ be the ordered list
of letters appearing in T.
The standardization of T is the tableau
formed from T by replacing every entry a_i with i.

def: \label{def:stadardization} Given a word $w=w_1\cdots w_n$ such that $w_1, \ldots, w_n$ are distinct positive integers, we say that the \emph{standardization} of $w$ is the permutation $\sigma \in \sgrp _n$ such that $\sigma(i) < \sigma (j)$ if and only if $w_i <w_j$ for $1\leq i,j \leq n$.
plain_text_def: Given a word w=w_1⋯ w_n such that w_1, …, w_n are distinct positive integers, we say that the standardization of w is the permutation σ∈ _n such that σ(i) < σ (j) if and only if w_i <w_j for 1≤ i,j ≤ n.

def: Given an ordered multiset partition $\pi \in \OP(m,n)$ we can define the \emph{standardization} with respect to a statistic (it being inv, dinv, or maj) as the unique standard multiset partition obtained from $\pi$ by replacing its $1$'s by $1,2, \dots \alpha_1$, its $2$'s by $\alpha_1+1, \dots, \alpha_1+\alpha_2$ and so on, in such a way that the reverse reading word (with respect to the relevant statistic) of the standardization is an $\alpha$-shuffle (i.e. it is in $1, \dots, \alpha_1 \shuffle \alpha_1+1, \dots, \alpha_1+\alpha_2 \shuffle \dots$).
plain_text_def: Given an ordered multiset partition π∈(m,n) we can define the standardization with respect to a statistic (it being inv, dinv, or maj) as the unique standard multiset partition obtained from π by replacing its 1's by 1,2, …α_1, its 2's by α_1+1, …, α_1+α_2 and so on, in such a way that the reverse reading word (with respect to the relevant statistic) of the standardization is an α-shuffle (i.e. it is in 1, …, α_1 α_1+1, …, α_1+α_2 …).

def: A \emph{star} is a tree of diameter 2.
plain_text_def: A star is a tree of diameter 2.
Star of the skeleton T at v ∈ V (T) is defined as the subtree of T consisting of the hyperedges of T incident to v. The vertex v is called the center of this star.

def:
We say that $w \in F_n$ is a \emph{star} if $\Gamma(w)$ is a star. $\mathcal{S}_i$ denotes the word $w \in F_n$
such that $\Gamma(w)$ is the star centered at $i$.
plain_text_def:
We say that w ∈ F_n is a star if Γ(w) is a star. 𝒮_i denotes the word w ∈ F_n
such that Γ(w) is the star centered at i.

def: A tree is called a \textit{star} if it has at most one internal vertex.
plain_text_def: A tree is called a star if it has at most one internal vertex.

def:
A \emph{star} $S_k$ is the complete bipartite graph $K_{1, k}$.  In other
words, $S_k$ has one central vertex and $k$ leaves
connected to this vertex.
plain_text_def:
A star S_k is the complete bipartite graph K_1, k.  In other
words, S_k has one central vertex and k leaves
connected to this vertex.

def:
If $v$ is a vertex of a simplicial complex $\Delta$, then the \emph{star} of $v$ 
in $\Delta$, denoted $\Star(v)$, is the union of the interiors of those 
simplices of $\Delta$ that have $v$ as a vertex.
plain_text_def:
If v is a vertex of a simplicial complex Δ, then the star of v 
in Δ, denoted (v), is the union of the interiors of those 
simplices of Δ that have v as a vertex.

def: Let $r$ and $t$ be positive integers. The \index{double star graph}\emph{star graph} denoted by $S_{r,t}$ is defined by the graph union $S_{r} \cup S_{t}$ and connecting the two centers of the two stars.
plain_text_def: Let r and t be positive integers. The double star graphstar graph denoted by S_r,t is defined by the graph union S_r∪ S_t and connecting the two centers of the two stars.

def:
A \emph{star graph} $S_n$ is a tree with $n$ vertices; one vertex of degree
  $n-1$ and $n-1$ leaves (vertices of degree one). Or, alternatively, it is 
  a complete bipartite graph $K_{1,n-1}$.
plain_text_def:
A star graph S_n is a tree with n vertices; one vertex of degree
  n-1 and n-1 leaves (vertices of degree one). Or, alternatively, it is 
  a complete bipartite graph K_1,n-1.

def: Let $H$ be a uniform hypergraph of rank $k$ with no singleton vertices.  $H$ is a \emph{star hypergraph} if all of its hyperedges intersect in a common set of size $k-1$.
plain_text_def: Let H be a uniform hypergraph of rank k with no singleton vertices.  H is a star hypergraph if all of its hyperedges intersect in a common set of size k-1.

def:
Let $H$ be a uniform hypergraph of rank $k$.  $H$ is a \emph{star hypergraph} if all of its hyperedges intersect in a common set of size $k-1$.
%
plain_text_def: Let H be a uniform hypergraph of rank k.  H is a star hypergraph if all of its hyperedges intersect in a common set of size k-1.

def:
Let $\Gamma$ be a pure $n$-dimensional simplicial complex, and let $\sigma \in \Gamma$ be an $i$-face. 

\begin{itemize}
\item The \emph{star} of $\sigma$ is the $n$-dimensional simplicial subcomplex induced by the faces that contain $\sigma$. That is,

$$\text{Star}_\Gamma (\sigma) = \{x \in \Gamma \, | \, \exists F \in \Gamma \text{ such that } \sigma \leq F, \text{ and } x \leq F\} \, . $$

\item The \emph{link} of $\sigma$ is the $(n-i-1)$-dimensional simplicial subcomplex given by all the faces of the Star$_\Gamma (\sigma)$ that do not intersect $\sigma$. That is, 

$$\text{Link}_\Gamma (\sigma) = \{x \in \text{Star}_\Gamma (\sigma) \, | \, \sigma \nleq x\} \, .$$
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Let Γ be a pure n-dimensional simplicial complex, and let σ∈Γ be an i-face. 



  * The star of σ is the n-dimensional simplicial subcomplex induced by the faces that contain σ. That is,


    Star_Γ (σ) = {x ∈Γ  |  ∃ F ∈Γ such that σ≤ F,  and  x ≤ F}  .



  * The link of σ is the (n-i-1)-dimensional simplicial subcomplex given by all the faces of the Star_Γ (σ) that do not intersect σ. That is, 


    Link_Γ (σ) = {x ∈Star_Γ (σ)   |  σ≰ x}  .

def: The \emph{star} of a face \(\sigma\) in a simplicial complex \(\Delta\) is the simplicial complex generated by the facets containing \(\sigma\), \(st_\Delta(\sigma)= \{\tau \mid \tau \subset F\text{ for some } F \in \Delta \text{ such that } \sigma \subset F \} \). The \emph{link} of a face \(\sigma\) in a simplicial complex is the set of faces whose intersection with \(\sigma\) is empty, and whose union with \(\sigma\) is in \(\Delta\), \(lk_\Delta(\sigma) = \{\tau \mid \tau \cap \sigma = \emptyset, \tau \cup \sigma \in \Delta\}\).
plain_text_def: The star of a face σ in a simplicial complex Δ is the simplicial complex generated by the facets containing σ, st_Δ(σ)= {τ|τ⊂ F for some  F ∈Δ such that σ⊂ F }. The link of a face σ in a simplicial complex is the set of faces whose intersection with σ is empty, and whose union with σ is in Δ, lk_Δ(σ) = {τ|τ∩σ = ∅, τ∪σ∈Δ}.

def:
\label{theo:complexity}
Given any fixed integer~$k$, there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the highest $k+1$ degree
terms of the quasi-polynomial $E(\a)(t)$, that is
$$\mathrm{Top}_kE(\a)(t)=\sum_{i=0}^k E_{N-i}(t) t^{N-i}.$$
The coefficients are recovered as \emph{step polynomial} functions of $t$.
plain_text_def:
Given any fixed integer k, there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the highest k+1 degree
terms of the quasi-polynomial E()(t), that is

    Top_kE()(t)=∑_i=0^k E_N-i(t) t^N-i.

The coefficients are recovered as step polynomial functions of t.

def:
\label{theo:knap-main}
Given any fixed integer~$k$, there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the highest $k+1$ degree
terms of the quasi-polynomial $E(\a; t)$, that is
$$\mathrm{Top}_kE(\a; t)=\sum_{i=0}^k E_{N-i}(t) t^{N-i}.$$
The coefficients are recovered as \emph{step polynomial} functions of $t$.
plain_text_def:
Given any fixed integer k, there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the highest k+1 degree
terms of the quasi-polynomial E(; t), that is

    Top_kE(; t)=∑_i=0^k E_N-i(t) t^N-i.

The coefficients are recovered as step polynomial functions of t.

def:
\label{def:step-poly-V}
 $\polypp(V)$ is the algebra of functions on $V$ generated by the functions
 $s\mapsto \{\langle\lambda,s\rangle\}$, where $\lambda\in V^*_\Q$.
 An element of $\polypp(V)$  is called a (rational) \emph{step-polynomial} on $V$.
 %% I added `rational' for the benefit of a discussion of the more general
 %% case in 3Polys. --Matthias
plain_text_def:
(V) is the algebra of functions on V generated by the functions
 s↦{⟨λ,s⟩}, where λ∈ V^*_.
 An element of (V)  is called a (rational) step-polynomial on V.

def:
\label{def:step-poly}
A \emph{step-polynomial} function $F(t)$ on $\R$ is an element of the algebra generated by the functions $t\mapsto \{\gamma t\}$, with $\gamma \in \R$.
plain_text_def: A step-polynomial function F(t) on  is an element of the algebra generated by the functions t↦{γ t}, with γ∈.

def:
\label{def:lin2treest}
A straight linear 2-tree is a graph $G_n$ with $n$ vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one, the first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure~\ref{fig:2tree}.
plain_text_def: A straight linear 2-tree is a graph G_n with n vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one, the first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure <ref>.

def:
\label{def:lin2treest}
A straight linear 2-tree is a graph $G_n$ with $n$ vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one, and first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure~\ref{fig:2tree}.
plain_text_def: A straight linear 2-tree is a graph G_n with n vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one, and first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure <ref>.

def:
\label{def:lin2treest}
A straight linear 2-tree is a graph $G_n$ with $n$ vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one and first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure~\ref{fig:2tree}.
plain_text_def: A straight linear 2-tree is a graph G_n with n vertices with adjacency matrix that is symmetric, banded, with the first and second subdiagonals equal to one and first and second superdiagonals equal to one, and all other entries equal to zero. See Figure <ref>.

def: We say that a sheltering matroid $Q = (M,\Omega)$ is \emph{strict} if $r(M)\leq|\Omega|$.
plain_text_def: We say that a sheltering matroid Q = (M,Ω) is strict if r(M)≤|Ω|.

def: A scaling is called \emph{strict} if all of its entries are strictly positive.
plain_text_def: A scaling is called strict if all of its entries are strictly positive.

def:
\label{definition:supp}
If $P$ is a non-empty $p \times q$ classical transportation polytope and $x = (x_{i,j})_{i \in [p], j \in [q]}$ is in $P$, then $x_{i,j} \geq 0$ for all $i \in [p]$ and $j \in [q]$. The pairs $(i,j) \in [p] \times [q]$ where $x_{i,j}$ is \emph{strictly} positive are called \defn{support entries}. For a point $x \in P$, we define the \defn{support set} $\supp(x)$ to be $\{(i,j) \in [p]\times [q] \mid x_{i,j} > 0\}$.
plain_text_def: If P is a non-empty p × q classical transportation polytope and x = (x_i,j)_i ∈ [p], j ∈ [q] is in P, then x_i,j≥ 0 for all i ∈ [p] and j ∈ [q]. The pairs (i,j) ∈ [p] × [q] where x_i,j is strictly positive are called support entries. For a point x ∈ P, we define the support set (x) to be {(i,j) ∈ [p]× [q] | x_i,j > 0}.

Let T be an augmented filling with weakly decreasing rows.
An inversion triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c
and T(a) ≥ T(c) ≥ T(b).

Similarly, an inversion triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c
and T(a) ≥ T(c) ≥ T(b).

    Type A:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
     a     b 
       [⋮] 
        c 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
     c    
    [⋮]     
    
    a     b

A triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c.

Similarly, a triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c.


A type A triple is an inversion triple if the entries ordered increasingly,
form a counter-clockwise orientation. Similarly, a type B triple is an inversion triple
if the entries ordered increasingly form a clockwise orientation.
If two entries are equal, the one with largest subscript in <ref>
is considered largest.

    Type A:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
     a_3     b_1 
       [⋮] 
        c_2 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
    c_2    
    [⋮]     
    
    a_3     b_1

A triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c.

Similarly, a triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c.

A type A triple is an inversion triple if the entries ordered increasingly
form a counter-clockwise orientation. Similarly, a type B triple is an inversion triple
if the entries ordered increasingly form a clockwise orientation.
If two entries are equal, the one with the largest subscript in <ref>
is considered to be largest.

    Type A:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
     a_3     b_1 
       [⋮] 
        c_2 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
    c_2    
    [⋮]     
    
    a_3     b_1

def:
\label{D:ribbon}
A skew diagram $\theta$ is a {\em strip} if $\theta$ is edgewise connected and it contains no $2\times 2$ blocks of boxes.
plain_text_def: A skew diagram θ is a strip if θ is edgewise connected and it contains no 2× 2 blocks of boxes.

def: A \textit{strip} in a planar quad-graph $\Lambda$ is a path on its dual $\Diamond$ such that two successive faces share an edge and the strip leaves a face in the opposite edge where it enters it. Moreover, strips are assumed to have maximal length, i.e., there are no strips containing it apart from itself.
plain_text_def: A strip in a planar quad-graph Λ is a path on its dual  such that two successive faces share an edge and the strip leaves a face in the opposite edge where it enters it. Moreover, strips are assumed to have maximal length, i.e., there are no strips containing it apart from itself.

def:
A \textit{strong placement game} is a combinatorial game which satisfies the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item[(i)] The starting position is the empty board.
\item[(ii)] Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.
\item[(iii)] Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.
\item[(iv)] The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.
\end{itemize}
The \textsc{Trivial} placement game on a board is the strong placement game that has no additional rules.
plain_text_def:
A strong placement game is a combinatorial game which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the strong placement game that has no additional rules.

A strong placement game is a combinatorial game played on a graph which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the placement game that has no additional rules.

def:
\ 
The system $\mathbf \Phi$ is \emph{strongly connected} if the directed graph on $\{1,\ldots,c\}$ given by $j\to i$ whenever $\frac {\partial \Phi_i}{\partial y_j}$ is nonzero, is strongly connected.
plain_text_def: The system Φ is strongly connected if the directed graph on {1,…,c} given by j→ i whenever ∂Φ_i/∂ y_j is nonzero, is strongly connected.

* Two different edges are strongly connected if they both originate from, or both end in, a common vertex.  Thinking of a dual-colored edge as consisting of two over-lapping edges with different colors, we consider those two edges to be strongly connected to each other.


  * Let Γ̃ be a subnetwork of Γ formed from the vertex-disjoint path families B={β_1,…,β_k} and R={ρ_1,…,ρ_ℓ} as above.  A chain in Γ̃ is an equivalence class of edges in Γ̃ under the reflexive and transitive closure of the strongly connected relation.  Figure <ref> gives an example of a colored network Γ̃ in which each of the edges in a chain are given the same number.

def: A pure $(d-1)$-dimensional simplicial complex $\Delta$ is called \emph{strongly connected} if for any two facets $F$ and $G$ of $\Delta$, there exist facets $F=F_0,F_1,\ldots, F_m=G$ such that $|F_i\cap F_{i+1}|=d-1$ for all $0\leq i\leq m-1$.
plain_text_def: A pure (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex Δ is called strongly connected if for any two facets F and G of Δ, there exist facets F=F_0,F_1,…, F_m=G such that |F_i∩ F_i+1|=d-1 for all 0≤ i≤ m-1.

def:
\label{def:strong_connectedness}
If $g$ and $h$ are vertices in a digraph, then $g$ is \textit{strongly connected} to $h$ if there exists a directed path from $g$ to $h$ and a directed path from $h$ to $g$. A digraph is \textit{strongly connected} if every pair of vertices is strongly connected.
plain_text_def: If g and h are vertices in a digraph, then g is strongly connected to h if there exists a directed path from g to h and a directed path from h to g. A digraph is strongly connected if every pair of vertices is strongly connected.

def:
\label{def:strongconn}
Define a graph $G_{\text{strong}}$ with vertex set $\Z^2$ and edge set $E$, where $\big\{(a_1,b_1),(a_2,b_2)\big\}\in E$ if and only if
% by saying that sites  are \emph{strongly connected} , written $x\sim y$, if
\[
|a_1-a_2| \leq 1 \qquad \text{and} \qquad |a_1-a_2| + |b_1-b_2| \leq 2.
\]
We say that a set of vertices $K\subset \Z^2$ is \emph{strongly connected} if the subgraph of $G_{\text{strong}}$ induced by $K$ is connected.
plain_text_def:
Define a graph G_strong with vertex set ^2 and edge set E, where {(a_1,b_1),(a_2,b_2)}∈ E if and only if


    |a_1-a_2| ≤ 1     and     |a_1-a_2| + |b_1-b_2| ≤ 2.

We say that a set of vertices K⊂^2 is strongly connected if the subgraph of G_strong induced by K is connected.

def: The indices $u,v \in V(M)$ are \emph{strongly cospectral} if $\varphi(u) = \pm \varphi(v)$ for every eigenvector $\varphi$ of $M$.
plain_text_def: The indices u,v ∈ V(M) are strongly cospectral if φ(u) = ±φ(v) for every eigenvector φ of M.

def:
\label{def:str-cosp}\textbf{(Strongly Cospectral)}
Let $e_u$ denote the characteristic vector for any vertex $u$. We say that vertices $a$ and $b$ are \emph{strongly cospectral} if
\[
E_\theta e_a = \pm E_\theta e_b
\]
for all projections $E_\theta$ in the spectral decomposition of $M$.
plain_text_def:
(Strongly Cospectral)
Let e_u denote the characteristic vector for any vertex u. We say that vertices a and b are strongly cospectral if

    E_θ e_a = ± E_θ e_b

for all projections E_θ in the spectral decomposition of M.

def:
[Strong stability]\label{def:strong_stable}
	A family of graphical degree sequences $\mathcal{D}$ is called \emph{strongly stable} if there exists a constant $\ell$ such that $k_{JS}(d) \leq \ell$ for all $d \in \mathcal{D}$.
plain_text_def:
[Strong stability]
	A family of graphical degree sequences 𝒟 is called strongly stable if there exists a constant ℓ such that k_JS(d) ≤ℓ for all d ∈𝒟.

def:
[\cite{SeiB}]\label{StronglyStab}
% % % % % A monomial ideal $I\triangleleft \mathcal{P}=\mathbf{k}[x_1,...,x_n]$ is called 
% % % % % \emph{strongly stable}
% % % % % if, for every term $\tau\in I$ and pair of variables
% % % % % $x_i,\ x_j$ such that $x_i\vert \tau$ and $x_i<x_j$,
% % % % % then also $
% % % % % \frac{\tau x_j}{x_i} $ belongs to $I$ or, equivalently,
% % % % % for every $\sigma \in {\sf N}(I)$, and pair of
% % % % % variables $x_i,\ x_j$ such that $x_i\vert \sigma$
% % % % % and $x_i>x_j$,
% % % % % then also $\frac{\sigma x_j}{x_i} $ belongs to ${\sf N}(I)$.
% % % % %

\label{thm:subdivision}
Let ${\cal A}=\{A_1,A_2,\dotsc,A_m\}$ be a bimodal collection of disjoint subsets of an abelian group $G$.  Suppose that $A_i$ is a coset of $H_i$ for some $i$.  Let $A_i^1,A_i^2, \dotsc, A_i^r$ be disjoint subsets partitioning $A_i$, having internal difference groups $H_i^1,H_i^2, \dotsc, H_i^r$ respectively, and which possess the property that for $j=1,2,\dotsc, r$ the set $A_i^j$ is a coset of $H_i^j$.  Then the collection ${\cal A^{\prime}}=\{A_1,A_2,\dotsc,A_{i-1},A_i^1,A_i^2,\dotsc,A_i^r ,A_{i+1},\dotsc,A_m\}$ satisfies the bimodal property.  We shall refer to $\cal A^{\prime}$ as a \emph{subdivision} of ${\cal A}$.
plain_text_def: Let A={A_1,A_2,…,A_m} be a bimodal collection of disjoint subsets of an abelian group G.  Suppose that A_i is a coset of H_i for some i.  Let A_i^1,A_i^2, …, A_i^r be disjoint subsets partitioning A_i, having internal difference groups H_i^1,H_i^2, …, H_i^r respectively, and which possess the property that for j=1,2,…, r the set A_i^j is a coset of H_i^j.  Then the collection A^'={A_1,A_2,…,A_i-1,A_i^1,A_i^2,…,A_i^r ,A_i+1,…,A_m} satisfies the bimodal property.  We shall refer to A^' as a subdivision of A.

def:
[Graph subdivision~\cite{holzman2015strong}]
%A directed graph $G$ is a \emph{subdivision} of a directed graph $G'$ if $G$ can be derived from $G'$ by replacing every edge in $G'$ with a path of one or more edge.
%
plain_text_def: [Graph subdivision <cit.>]

Given face posets of regular CW complexes Π and Π, we say that Π is a subdivision of Π if there exists a surjective, order preserving map ϕ : Π→Π such that for all F ∈Π the following conditions hold:



  * F := ϕ^-1([0, F]) is a CW complex of the same dimension as F.

  * ϕ^-1(F) consists of all the interior cells of F.

  * |F| = |F|

def:
A grid-labelled graph $H_{l}^{a,b}$ is a \emph{subgraph} of a grid-labelled
	graph $G_{l}^{a,b}$, denoted $H_{l}^{a,b}\subseteq G_{l}^{a,b}$, if every
	edge of $H_{l}^{a,b}$ is an edge of $G_{l}^{a,b}$.
plain_text_def:
A grid-labelled graph H_l^a,b is a subgraph of a grid-labelled
	graph G_l^a,b, denoted H_l^a,b⊆ G_l^a,b, if every
	edge of H_l^a,b is an edge of G_l^a,b.

def:
Let us have a family of graphs $\mathcal{F}$. Let $\mathcal{G}_{n,q}$ be the set of all multigraphs on $n$ vertices with maximum edge multiplicity $q$ and let $H \prec G$ denote that $H$ is a submultigraph of the multigraph $G$. Then we define
\[
\ex_q(n,\mathcal{F}) = \max\{|E(G)| : G\in \mathcal{G}_{n,q} \text{ and }\forall F \in \mathcal{F},  \not\exists H\prec G, H\cong F\}.
\]
This takes the maximum number of edges of a graph that does not contain any $F \in \mathcal{F}$ as a \textit{subgraph} , not just an induced subgraph.
plain_text_def:
Let us have a family of graphs ℱ. Let 𝒢_n,q be the set of all multigraphs on n vertices with maximum edge multiplicity q and let H ≺ G denote that H is a submultigraph of the multigraph G. Then we define

    _q(n,ℱ) = max{|E(G)| : G∈𝒢_n,q and ∀ F ∈ℱ,  ∄H≺ G, H≅ F}.

This takes the maximum number of edges of a graph that does not contain any F ∈ℱ as a subgraph , not just an induced subgraph.

def: A \emph{substitution} is a map from~$\NNNN$ to~$\Treelab$. If $\sigma$ is a substitution and $\TT$ is a tree in~$\Treelab$, we define~$\TT^\sigma$ to be the tree obtained from~$\TT$ by replacing every $\ii$-labeled leaf of~$\TT$ by the tree~$\sigma(\ii)$.
plain_text_def: A substitution is a map from  to . If σ is a substitution and  is a tree in , we define ^σ to be the tree obtained from  by replacing every -labeled leaf of  by the tree σ().

def:
%
Let $\theta=\theta(1)\cdots \theta(d)$ be a permutation of size $d$, and let $\pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}$ be $d$ other permutations. 
The \emph{substitution} of $\pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}$ in $\theta$ is the permutation of size $|\pi^{(1)}|+ \dots +|\pi^{(d)}|$ 
obtained by replacing each $\theta(i)$ by a sequence of integers isomorphic to $\pi^{(i)}$ while keeping the relative order induced by $\theta$ between these subsequences.\\
This permutation is denoted by $\theta[\pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}]$.
plain_text_def:
Let θ=θ(1)⋯θ(d) be a permutation of size d, and let π^(1),…,π^(d) be d other permutations. 
The substitution of π^(1),…,π^(d) in θ is the permutation of size |π^(1)|+ … +|π^(d)| 
obtained by replacing each θ(i) by a sequence of integers isomorphic to π^(i) while keeping the relative order induced by θ between these subsequences.

This permutation is denoted by θ[π^(1),…,π^(d)].

Let  be a simplicial complex on the set [m], and let _1, …, _m be a set of m simplicial complexes. We refer to the simplicial complex

    (_1, …, _m) = {I_j_1⊔…⊔ I_j_k |  I_j_l∈_j_l,  l = 1,…, k   and  {j_1, …, j_k}∈}

as the substitution of _1, …, _m into .


The set of missing faces MF((_1, …, _m)) of a substitution complex can be described as follows. First, every missing face of each _i is the missing face of (_1, …, _m). Second, for every missing face Δ(i_1, …, i_k) of  we have the following set of missing faces of the substitution complex:

    MF_i_1,…, i_k((_1, …, _m)) = 
      {Δ(j_1, …, j_k) |  j_l ∈_i_l,  l =1,…, k}.

It is easy to see that there are no other missing faces in (_1, …, _m), so we have

    MF((_1, …, _m)) = MF  
      (_1)⊔…⊔MF
      (_m)⊔_Δ(i_1, …, i_k)∈MF
      ()MF_i_1,…, i_k((_1, …, _m)).

def:
\label{def:SubstitutionTree}
A \emph{substitution tree} of size $n$ is a labeled rooted planar tree with $n$ leaves,
where any internal node with $k \ge 2$ children is labeled by a permutation of size $k$.
Internal nodes with only one child are forbidden.
% 
% 
% 
% 
% 
% 
% 
% 
%
plain_text_def:
A substitution tree of size n is a labeled rooted planar tree with n leaves,
where any internal node with k ≥ 2 children is labeled by a permutation of size k.
Internal nodes with only one child are forbidden.

def:
\label{def:SubstitutionTree}
A \emph{substitution tree} of size $n$ is a rooted plane tree with $n$ leaves,
where any internal node with $k \ge 2$ children is labeled by a permutation of size $k$.
Internal nodes with only one child are forbidden. 
The labels $12$ (resp. $21$) of internal nodes are often replaced by $\oplus$ (resp. $\ominus$).
plain_text_def:
A substitution tree of size n is a rooted plane tree with n leaves,
where any internal node with k ≥ 2 children is labeled by a permutation of size k.
Internal nodes with only one child are forbidden. 
The labels 12 (resp. 21) of internal nodes are often replaced by ⊕ (resp. ⊖).

def:
% 
A permutation class $\mathcal{C}$ is \emph{substitution-closed} if, for every $\theta, \pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}$ in $\mathcal{C}$,
$\theta[\pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}] \in \mathcal{C}$.
plain_text_def:
A permutation class 𝒞 is substitution-closed if, for every θ, π^(1),…,π^(d) in 𝒞,
θ[π^(1),…,π^(d)] ∈𝒞.

def:
% 
A permutation class $\CCC$ is \emph{substitution-closed} if, for every $\theta, \pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}$ in $\CCC$, the substitution
$\theta[\pi^{(1)},\dots,\pi^{(d)}]$ also belongs to $\CCC$.
plain_text_def:
A permutation class  is substitution-closed if, for every θ, π^(1),…,π^(d) in , the substitution
θ[π^(1),…,π^(d)] also belongs to .

def:
A word $w'$ is a \emph{subword} of a word $w\in \Sigma^*$ if{f} there exist $x_1,x_2,\dotsc, x_n, y_0, y_1, \dotsc,y_n\in \Sigma^*$, some of them possibly empty, such that
$$w'=x_1x_2\dotsm x_n \text{ and } w=y_0x_1y_1\dotsm y_{n-1}x_ny_n.$$
plain_text_def:
A word w' is a subword of a word w∈Σ^* iff there exist x_1,x_2,…, x_n, y_0, y_1, …,y_n∈Σ^*, some of them possibly empty, such that

    w'=x_1x_2… x_n  and  w=y_0x_1y_1… y_n-1x_ny_n.

def:
A word $w'$ is a \emph{subword} of $w\in \Sigma^*$ if{f} there exist $x_1,x_2,\dotsc, x_n$, $y_0, y_1, \dotsc,y_n\in \Sigma^*$, some of them possibly empty, such that
$$w'=x_1x_2\dotsm x_n \text{ and } w=y_0x_1y_1\dotsm y_{n-1}x_ny_n.$$
plain_text_def:
A word w' is a subword of w∈Σ^* iff there exist x_1,x_2,…, x_n, y_0, y_1, …,y_n∈Σ^*, some of them possibly empty, such that

    w'=x_1x_2… x_n  and  w=y_0x_1y_1… y_n-1x_ny_n.

def:
\label{def:specsum}
  For two species $F$ and $G$, define their \emph{sum} to be the species $F + G$ given by $\pbracs[big]{F + G} \sbrac{A} = F \sbrac{A} \sqcup G \sbrac{A}$ (where $\sqcup$ denotes disjoint set union).
plain_text_def: For two species F and G, define their sum to be the species F + G given by [big]F + GA = F A⊔ G A (where ⊔ denotes disjoint set union).

def: For any set of integers $A$, the \emph{sum} of $A$, denoted $S(A)$, is the sum of the elements in $A$.
plain_text_def: For any set of integers A, the sum of A, denoted S(A), is the sum of the elements in A.

def:
[Addition of ultrafilters, limit version]
The \emph{sum}\index{ultrafilter sum}\index{ultrafilter addition|see{ultrafilter sum}} of two ultrafilters $p,q\in\bN$ is defined as the double limit
\[  q + p := \left(\lim_{m\to q}\ \lim_{n\to p}\ (m + n)\right)  \in\bN ,\]
of the ordinary sum $m+n$ of natural numbers $m,n\in\N$.
This limit is well-defined because the topological space $\bN$ is compact.
plain_text_def:
[Addition of ultrafilters, limit version]
The sumultrafilter sumultrafilter addition|seeultrafilter sum of two ultrafilters p,q∈ is defined as the double limit

    q + p := (lim_m→ q lim_n→ p (m + n))  ∈ ,

of the ordinary sum m+n of natural numbers m,n∈.
This limit is well-defined because the topological space  is compact.

def:
For any partitions $\mu$ and $\alpha$ we define their \emph{sum} to be the partition
$$\mu+\alpha= (\mu_1+\alpha_1, \mu_2+\alpha_2,\ldots).$$
plain_text_def:
For any partitions μ and α we define their sum to be the partition

    μ+α= (μ_1+α_1, μ_2+α_2,…).

def:
Let $\s{F}$ and $\s{G}$ be species. Then their \emph{sum} $\s{F}+\s{G}$ is the species where
\[ (\s{F}+\s{G})[U] = \s{F}[U] \sqcup \s{G}[U], \]
where $A \sqcup B$, the disjoint union of $A$ and $B$, is the set of $A$-elements colored red and $B$-elements colored blue, and
\[ (\s{F}+\s{G})[\sigma](s) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}
F[\sigma](s) & \mbox{if } s \in \s{F}[U] \\
G[\sigma](s) & \mbox{if } s \in \s{G}[U].
\end{array} \right. \]
plain_text_def:
Let F and G be species. Then their sum F+G is the species where

    (F+G)[U] = F[U] ⊔G[U],

where A ⊔ B, the disjoint union of A and B, is the set of A-elements colored red and B-elements colored blue, and

    (F+G)[σ](s) = {[  F[σ](s)  s ∈F[U];  G[σ](s) s ∈G[U]. ].

def:
Let $G$ be a finite group, $\mathcal{K}$ be a partition of $G$ into unions of conjugacy classes, and $\mathcal{X}$ be a set of characters of $G$. We say that the pair $(\mathcal{K},\mathcal{X})$ is a \emph{supercharacter theory} of $G$ if
\begin{enumerate}[leftmargin=.52in]
\item[(SCT1)] $|\mathcal{X}|=|\mathcal{K}|$,
\item[(SCT2)] the characters $\chi\in \mathcal{X}$ are constant on the members of $\mathcal{K}$, and
\item[(SCT3)] each irreducible character of $G$ is a constituent of exactly one character in $\mathcal{X}$.
\end{enumerate}
The characters $\chi \in \mathcal{X}$ are called \emph{supercharacters} and the blocks $K \in \mathcal{K}$ are called \emph{superclasses} .
plain_text_def:
Let G be a finite group, 𝒦 be a partition of G into unions of conjugacy classes, and 𝒳 be a set of characters of G. We say that the pair (𝒦,𝒳) is a supercharacter theory of G if


  (SCT1) |𝒳|=|𝒦|,

  (SCT2) the characters χ∈𝒳 are constant on the members of 𝒦, and

  (SCT3) each irreducible character of G is a constituent of exactly one character in 𝒳.

The characters χ∈𝒳 are called supercharacters and the blocks K ∈𝒦 are called superclasses .

Let G be a finite group, and suppose that 𝒦 is a partition of G into unions of conjugacy classes and 𝒳 is a set of characters of G. We say that the pair (𝒦,𝒳) is a supercharacter theory of G if


  (SCT1) |𝒳|=|𝒦|,

  (SCT2) the characters χ∈𝒳 are constant on the blocks of 𝒦, and

  (SCT3) each irreducible character of G is a constituent of exactly one character in 𝒳.

The characters χ∈𝒳 are referred to as supercharacters and the blocks K ∈𝒦 are called superclasses.

def:
The \emph{superset region} for any proximity map $N(\cdot)$
in $\Omega$ is defined to be $\RS(N):=\bigl\{ x \in \Omega: N(x) = \Omega \bigr\}$. $\square$
plain_text_def:
The superset region for any proximity map N(·)
in Ω is defined to be (N):={ x ∈Ω: N(x) = Ω}. □

def:
The \emph{superset region} for any proximity map $N(\cdot)$ in
$\Omega$ is defined to be
$$\RS(N):=\bigl\{ x \in \Omega: N(x) =\Omega \bigr\}.$$
%
plain_text_def:
The superset region for any proximity map N(·) in
Ω is defined to be

    (N):={ x ∈Ω: N(x) =Ω}.

def:
The \emph{superset region} for any proximity map $N(\cdot)$
in $\Omega$ is defined to be $\RS(N):=\bigl\{ x \in \Omega: N(x) = \Omega \bigr\}$.
When $X$ is $\Omega$-valued random variable, then we assume $X \in \RS(N)$
if $N(X) = \Omega$ a.s.
$\square$
plain_text_def:
The superset region for any proximity map N(·)
in Ω is defined to be (N):={ x ∈Ω: N(x) = Ω}.
When X is Ω-valued random variable, then we assume X ∈(N)
if N(X) = Ω a.s.
□

def: For a characteristic map $\lambda$ over $P_m$ and $p\in[m]$, the \emph{support} of $p$ for $\lambda$, denoted by $\supp_\lambda p$, is $\supp_\lambda p = \lambda^{-1}(\lambda(p))$. Since $\supp_\lambda p =\supp_{\lambda'} p$ whenever $\lambda $ and $\lambda'$ are D-J equivalent, the support $\supp_\lambda p$ is well defined for a D-J class $\lambda$.
plain_text_def: For a characteristic map λ over P_m and p∈[m], the support of p for λ, denoted by _λ p, is _λ p = λ^-1(λ(p)). Since _λ p =_λ' p whenever λ and λ' are D-J equivalent, the support _λ p is well defined for a D-J class λ.

def:
\label{def-rook-triple}
  We call the \emph{support} of a rook $r$ denoted $\supp(r)$ the set of
  non-zero letters appearing in its rook vector.  For each letter
  $\ell\in\supp(r)$, we denote $Z_r(\ell)$ the number of $0$ which appear
  after $\ell$ in the rook vector of $r$.

  We finally say that $(\supp(r), \Inv(r), Z_r)$ is the \emph{rook triple
    associated to $r$} .
plain_text_def:
We call the support of a rook r denoted (r) the set of
  non-zero letters appearing in its rook vector.  For each letter
  ℓ∈(r), we denote Z_r(ℓ) the number of 0 which appear
  after ℓ in the rook vector of r.

  We finally say that ((r), (r), Z_r) is the rook triple
    associated to r .

def: The \emph{support} of a length-$n$ Motzkin path $P$, written $\overline{P}$, is a Dyck prefix of length $n$ with $\overline P_i=u$ if $P_i$ is $U$ or  $E$ and $\overline P_i=d$ if $P_i$ is $D$.
plain_text_def: The support of a length-n Motzkin path P, written P, is a Dyck prefix of length n with P_i=u if P_i is U or  E and P_i=d if P_i is D.

def:
The \emph{support} of a polynomial $h$, denoted $\supp(h)$, is the set of
monomials that appear in $h$ with nonzero coefficient.
plain_text_def:
The support of a polynomial h, denoted (h), is the set of
monomials that appear in h with nonzero coefficient.

def:
\label{definition:semifree}
    Let $M$ be a nonzero commutative binoid. We say that $M$ is \textbf{semifree} with \textbf{semibasis} $(a_i)_{i\in I}$ if $M$ is generated by $\{a_i\mid i\in I\}$ and every element $f\in M$ can be written uniquely as $f=\sum_{i\in I} n_ia_i$ with $n_i=0$ for almost all $i\in I$. The set of $a_i$ such that $n_i\neq 0$ is called the \emph{support} of $f$, $\gls{supp}(f)=\{a_i\mid n_i\neq 0\}$.
plain_text_def: Let M be a nonzero commutative binoid. We say that M is semifree with semibasis (a_i)_i∈ I if M is generated by {a_i| i∈ I} and every element f∈ M can be written uniquely as f=∑_i∈ I n_ia_i with n_i=0 for almost all i∈ I. The set of a_i such that n_i≠ 0 is called the support of f, supp(f)={a_i| n_i≠ 0}.

def:
A function $c:\Delta^{(k)}\rightarrow\Z$ is said to be a {\em Minkowski weight} of codimension $k$ if it satisfies the {\em balancing condition}, that is, for every $\tau\in\Delta^{(k+1)}$,
\[\sum_{\substack{\sigma\in\Delta^{(k)}\\\sigma\supset\tau}} c(\sigma)v_{\sigma/\tau}=0\]
in $N/N_\tau$.
The \emph{support} of $c$ is the set of cones in $\Delta^{(k)}$ on which $c$ is non-zero.
plain_text_def:
A function c:Δ^(k)→ is said to be a Minkowski weight of codimension k if it satisfies the balancing condition, that is, for every τ∈Δ^(k+1),

    ∑_σ∈Δ^(k)
    σ⊃τ c(σ)v_σ/τ=0

in N/N_τ.
The support of c is the set of cones in Δ^(k) on which c is non-zero.

def: The \emph{support} of a position $P$ is the number of vertices $v$ of $G$ such that $P(v)$ is nonzero.
plain_text_def: The support of a position P is the number of vertices v of G such that P(v) is nonzero.

Let n,k∈ℕ with n odd. Let A and B be two CW(n,k^2) whose respective first rows, a and b, have disjoint support[The support of c=(c_0,c_1,…,c_n-1)∈ℝ^n is the set {i∈{0,…,n-1}: c_i≠ 0}.]. Then the circulant matrix c(w) is a CW(2n,4k^2) where the vector  w=(w_0,w_1,w_2,…,w_2n-1)∈ℝ^2n is given component-wise by

    w_s:={[            a_s/2+b_s/2,           if s is even,;        a_s+n/2-b_s+n/2, if s is odd and s≤ n-2,;        a_s-n/2-b_s-n/2, if s is odd and s> n-2. ].

def:
A Schr\"oder-type path from $p$ to $q$, for points $p,q\in\Z\times\Z$, is a
  sequence $P=(p_0,p_1,\ldots,p_k)$ with $k\in\N$, $p_i\in\Z\times\Z$ for
  $0\leq i\leq k$, $p_0=p$, $p_k=q$, and
  $p_{i+1}-p_i\in\{\pt0{+1},\pt{-1}{+1},\pt{-1}0\}$ for $0\leq i<k$. The
  \emph{support} of $P$ is $\supp(P)=\{p_0,p_1,\ldots,p_k\}$.
plain_text_def:
A Schröder-type path from p to q, for points p,q∈×, is a
  sequence P=(p_0,p_1,…,p_k) with k∈, p_i∈× for
  0≤ i≤ k, p_0=p, p_k=q, and
  p_i+1-p_i∈{0+1,-1+1,-10} for 0≤ i<k. The
  support of P is (P)={p_0,p_1,…,p_k}.

def:
\normalfont\cite{AIR,IT}
A $\Lambda$-module $M$ is said to be a \emph{support tilting module} if $M$ is a tilting $kQ(M)$-module. The set of non-isomorphic basic support tilting module of $\Lambda$ is denoted by $\stilt(\Lambda)$.
plain_text_def:
<cit.>
A Λ-module M is said to be a support tilting module if M is a tilting kQ(M)-module. The set of non-isomorphic basic support tilting module of Λ is denoted by (Λ).

def:
\cite{AIR,IT}
A $\Lambda$-module $M$ is said to be a \emph{support tilting module} if $M$ is a tilting $kQ(M)$-module.
plain_text_def:
<cit.>

def:
[A supported event]
Given any $Y \subseteq X$ and $k \in [K]$, we say that $(Y,k)$ is \emph{supported} if $Q_k(Y) > 0$.
plain_text_def:
[A supported event]
Given any Y ⊆ X and k ∈ [K], we say that (Y,k) is supported if Q_k(Y) > 0.

def:
For $\cQ\subseteq \powerset([k])$, let $\cG=(G_Q)_{Q\in \cQ}$ be a sequence of $Q$-directed hypergraphs $G_Q$ on the same vertex set $V$. 
We say an ordered $k$-tuple $\bv=(v_1,\ldots,v_k)\in \binom{V}{k}_<$ is \emph{supported} by $\cG$ if, for every $Q\in\cQ$,
\[
	\bv_Q=(v_i\colon i\in Q)\in E(G_Q)\,.
\]
Moreover, we denote by $\cK_k(\cG) \subseteq {V \choose k}_<$ the set of all ordered $k$-tuples supported by $\cG$.
plain_text_def:
For ⊆([k]), let =(G_Q)_Q∈ be a sequence of Q-directed hypergraphs G_Q on the same vertex set V. 
We say an ordered k-tuple =(v_1,…,v_k)∈Vk_< is supported by  if, for every Q∈,

    _Q=(v_i i∈ Q)∈ E(G_Q) .

Moreover, we denote by _k() ⊆V  k_< the set of all ordered k-tuples supported by .

def: Given a chord diagram $D$, \emph{surgery} of $D$ is the following process: For each chord $e$ connecting points $a,b$, delete a neighborhood of $e$ and connect the obtained endpoints $a+\epsilon$ to $b-\epsilon$ and $a-\epsilon$ to $b+\epsilon$ if $e$ is positive, and $a+\epsilon$ to $b+\epsilon$ and $a-\epsilon$ to $b-\epsilon$ if $e$ is negative. This produces a family of circles; these are called the \emph{result of surgery} of $D$.
plain_text_def: Given a chord diagram D, surgery of D is the following process: For each chord e connecting points a,b, delete a neighborhood of e and connect the obtained endpoints a+ϵ to b-ϵ and a-ϵ to b+ϵ if e is positive, and a+ϵ to b+ϵ and a-ϵ to b-ϵ if e is negative. This produces a family of circles; these are called the result of surgery of D.

def: Given a chord diagram $D$, \emph{surgery} of $D$ is the following process: For each chord $e$ connecting points $a,b$, delete a neighborhood of $e$ and connect the obtained endpoints $a+\epsilon$ to $b-\epsilon$ and $a-\epsilon$ to $b+\epsilon$. This produces a family of circles; these are called the \emph{result of surgery} of $D$.
plain_text_def: Given a chord diagram D, surgery of D is the following process: For each chord e connecting points a,b, delete a neighborhood of e and connect the obtained endpoints a+ϵ to b-ϵ and a-ϵ to b+ϵ. This produces a family of circles; these are called the result of surgery of D.

Let 𝒦_1 and 𝒦_2 be two simplicial complexes.


  (1) Let v_i ∈ V(𝒦_i) be a distinguished vertex called base point, for i = 1,2. The wedge (product) of K_1 and K_2, (K_1,v_1)∨ (K_2,v_2), is a simplicial complex obtained by identifying v_1 and v_2. The homotopy type of the resulting simplicial complex is preserved under change of the base points v_1 and v_2 inside the connected components in the original complexes. In particular, for connected simplicial complexes the wedge is well defined up to homotopy equivalence without specifying base points.

  (2) The join of 𝒦_1 and 𝒦_2, 𝒦_1 * 𝒦_2, is a simplicial complex with vertex set V(𝒦_1*𝒦_2) = V(𝒦_1)⊔ V(𝒦_2) and simplexes s ∈ P(𝒦_1*𝒦_2), with s = s_1⊔ s_2 for s_i ∈ P(𝒦_i).

  (3) If V(𝒦_2) = v, then the join 𝒦_1 * v is called a cone with apex v and base 𝒦_1 (sometimes denoted by cone(v, 𝒦_1)).

  (4) If 𝒦_2 = S^0 (a complex whose topological realization consists of two isolated vertices), then 𝒦_1 * 𝒦_2 is called suspension of 𝒦_1 and denoted by Σ𝒦_1.

def: Let $B_2$ denote the boolean algebra of rank two. Let $P$ be a poset. Then we call $P * B_2$ the \emph{suspension} of $P$ and denote it as $\Sigma P$.
plain_text_def: Let B_2 denote the boolean algebra of rank two. Let P be a poset. Then we call P * B_2 the suspension of P and denote it as Σ P.

def:
Given a 2-graph $H$, let $S(H)$ denote the \emph{suspension} of $H$, that is, the 3-graph with vertex set $V(H)\sqcup\{x_{\star}\}$ and 3-edges 
\[\{x_{\star}vv': \ vv' \in E(H)\}.\]
plain_text_def:
Given a 2-graph H, let S(H) denote the suspension of H, that is, the 3-graph with vertex set V(H)⊔{x_⋆} and 3-edges 

    {x_⋆vv':  vv' ∈ E(H)}.

def:
\RM A \emph{suspension} over a digraph $X$ is a digraph $\func{Sus}X$ that
is obtained from $X$ by adding two vertices $a,b$ and all the edges $%
c\rightarrow a$ and $c\rightarrow b$ for all $c\in X$. The vertices $a,b$
are called the suspension vertices.
plain_text_def:
A suspension over a digraph X is a digraph SusX that
is obtained from X by adding two vertices a,b and all the edges c→ a and c→ b for all c∈ X. The vertices a,b
are called the suspension vertices.

def:
\label{sus}
Let $P$ be a poset with  $\hat{1}$. We define the \emph{ suspension}
of $P$, denoted by $\Sigma(P)$, to be the poset $P$ with two new
elements $a_1$ and $a_2$. $\Sigma(P)$ has the following order
relation:

$\hat{1}>_{\Sigma(P)} {a_i}>_{\Sigma(P)} y$, for all $y< \hat{1}$ in
$P$ and $i=1, 2$.
plain_text_def:
Let P be a poset with  1̂. We define the  suspension
of P, denoted by Σ(P), to be the poset P with two new
elements a_1 and a_2. Σ(P) has the following order
relation:

1̂>_Σ(P)a_i>_Σ(P) y, for all y< 1̂ in
P and i=1, 2.

def:
If $(\Theta_w, \tau)$ is the subshift of $\Aron^\Z$ associated to $w$, we
define its \emph{suspension} $(\Omega_w, \phi)$ by:
\[
\Omega_w = \Theta_w \times \R / \sim
\]
where $\sim$ is the equivalence relation generated by the relations
$(x,t) \sim (\tau(x),t-1)$ for all $x \in \Theta_w$ and all $t \in \R$.
The map $\phi$ is an action of $\R$ defined by:
\[
\phi_s ( [(x,t)] ) := [(x,t+s)]
\]
With these definitions, $(\Omega_w, \phi)$ is a $\R$-dynamical system.
plain_text_def:
If (Θ_w, τ) is the subshift of ^ associated to w, we
define its suspension (Ω_w, ϕ) by:

    Ω_w = Θ_w × / ∼

where ∼ is the equivalence relation generated by the relations
(x,t) ∼ (τ(x),t-1) for all x ∈Θ_w and all t ∈.
The map ϕ is an action of  defined by:

    ϕ_s ( [(x,t)] ) := [(x,t+s)]

With these definitions, (Ω_w, ϕ) is a -dynamical system.

def:
Given a $3$-cube $$\mathcal{C}=\{(i_1,j_1,k_1), (i_1,j_2,k_1), 
(i_2,j_1,k_1), (i_2,j_2,k_1), (i_1,j_1,k_2), (i_1,j_2,k_2), 
(i_2,j_1,k_2),  (i_2,j_2,k_2)\}$$ in a Latin cube $L$, 
a \textit{swap on $\mathcal{C}$} (or simply a \textit{swap} )
denotes the transformation $L \rightarrow L'$ which retains the content
of all cells of $L$ except that if 
$$L(i_1,j_1,k_1)=L(i_2,j_2,k_1)=L(i_1,j_2,k_2)=L(i_2,j_1,k_2)=x_1$$
and $$L(i_1,j_2,k_1)= L(i_2,j_1,k_1)=L(i_1,j_1,k_2)= L(i_2,j_2,k_2)=x_2$$ then
$$L'(i_1,j_1,k_1)=L'(i_2,j_2,k_1)=L'(i_1,j_2,k_2)=L'(i_2,j_1,k_2)=x_2$$
and $$L'(i_1,j_2,k_1)= L'(i_2,j_1,k_1)=L'(i_1,j_1,k_2)= L(i_2,j_2,k_2)=x_1.$$
plain_text_def:
Given a 3-cube 
    𝒞={(i_1,j_1,k_1), (i_1,j_2,k_1), 
    (i_2,j_1,k_1), (i_2,j_2,k_1), (i_1,j_1,k_2), (i_1,j_2,k_2), 
    (i_2,j_1,k_2),  (i_2,j_2,k_2)}
 in a Latin cube L, 
a swap on 𝒞 (or simply a swap )
denotes the transformation L → L' which retains the content
of all cells of L except that if 

    L(i_1,j_1,k_1)=L(i_2,j_2,k_1)=L(i_1,j_2,k_2)=L(i_2,j_1,k_2)=x_1

and 
    L(i_1,j_2,k_1)= L(i_2,j_1,k_1)=L(i_1,j_1,k_2)= L(i_2,j_2,k_2)=x_2
 then

    L'(i_1,j_1,k_1)=L'(i_2,j_2,k_1)=L'(i_1,j_2,k_2)=L'(i_2,j_1,k_2)=x_2

and 
    L'(i_1,j_2,k_1)= L'(i_2,j_1,k_1)=L'(i_1,j_1,k_2)= L(i_2,j_2,k_2)=x_1.

def: A colouring $ \chi' \in C_r(m,n) $ is obtained from $ \chi \in C_r(m,n) $ by \emph{switching} two colours $ c $ and $ \tilde c $ at an edge $ e $ if, for every $ i= 1, \ldots, n $, we have $ \chi'_i(e) = \tilde c $ whenever $ \chi_i(e) =  c$, $ \chi'_i(e) = c $ whenever $ \chi_i(e) =  \tilde c$ and $ \chi = \chi' $ everywhere else. For $ \chi,\chi' \in C_r(m,n) $, we then say that $ \chi \sim \chi' $ if $ \chi' $ can be obtained from $ \chi $ by finitely many switches.
plain_text_def: A colouring χ' ∈ C_r(m,n) is obtained from χ∈ C_r(m,n) by switching two colours c and c̃ at an edge e if, for every i= 1, …, n, we have χ'_i(e) = c̃ whenever χ_i(e) =  c, χ'_i(e) = c whenever χ_i(e) =  c̃ and χ = χ' everywhere else. For χ,χ' ∈ C_r(m,n), we then say that χ∼χ' if χ' can be obtained from χ by finitely many switches.

def:
Let $f,f'\colon X\to Y$ be injective functions. We say that $f'$ is obtained
  from $f$ by a \emph{switching} if there are
  $u,v\in X$ with $f'(u)=f(v)$ and $f'(v)=f(u)$ and $f(w)=f'(w)$ for all
  $w\not\in\{u,v\}$. The \emph{switching distance} \emph{$\swdist(f,f')$}
  of $f$ and $f'$ is at most $s$ if the mapping $f'$ can be obtained from $f$
  by a sequence of at most $s$ switchings.
plain_text_def:
Let f,f' X→ Y be injective functions. We say that f' is obtained
  from f by a switching if there are
  u,v∈ X with f'(u)=f(v) and f'(v)=f(u) and f(w)=f'(w) for all
  w∉{u,v}. The switching distance (f,f')
  of f and f' is at most s if the mapping f' can be obtained from f
  by a sequence of at most s switchings.

plain_text_def: [Switching] Let σ: E^or→ H be a given signature. For any function

def:
A function from the vertex set of $G$ to the  complex unit circle $\mathbb{T}$ is called a \textit{switching function} . We say that, two gain graphs $\Phi_1=(G,\varphi_1)$ and $\Phi_2=(G,\varphi_2)$ are \textit{switching equivalent} , written as $\Phi_1\sim\Phi_2$, if there is a switching function $\zeta:V\rightarrow\mathbb{T}$ such that $$\varphi_2(e_{ij})=\zeta(v_i)^{-1}\varphi_1(e_{ij})\zeta(v_j).$$

    The switching equivalence of two gain graphs can be defined in the following equivalent way:
    Two gain graphs $\Phi_1=(G,\varphi_1)$ and $\Phi_2=(G,\varphi_2)$ are switching equivalent, if there exists a diagonal matrix $D_\zeta$ with diagonal entries from $\mathbb{T}$, such that
    $$A(\Phi_2)=D_\zeta^{-1}A(\Phi_1)D_\zeta.$$
plain_text_def:
A function from the vertex set of G to the  complex unit circle 𝕋 is called a switching function . We say that, two gain graphs Φ_1=(G,φ_1) and Φ_2=(G,φ_2) are switching equivalent , written as Φ_1∼Φ_2, if there is a switching function ζ:V→𝕋 such that 
    φ_2(e_ij)=ζ(v_i)^-1φ_1(e_ij)ζ(v_j).


    The switching equivalence of two gain graphs can be defined in the following equivalent way:
    Two gain graphs Φ_1=(G,φ_1) and Φ_2=(G,φ_2) are switching equivalent, if there exists a diagonal matrix D_ζ with diagonal entries from 𝕋, such that
    
    A(Φ_2)=D_ζ^-1A(Φ_1)D_ζ.

def: A \textit{symbol block} of the starting Latin cube $L$ of order $n$ is a set of $n^2$ cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
plain_text_def: A symbol block of the starting Latin cube L of order n is a set of n^2 cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.

def: A \textit{symbol block} of a Latin cube $L$ is a set of $n^2$ cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
plain_text_def: A symbol block of a Latin cube L is a set of n^2 cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.

def: A cycle factor is said to be \textit{symmetric} if it is also a left coset partition.
plain_text_def: A cycle factor is said to be symmetric if it is also a left coset partition.

def: Let $\gm$ be a one-faced collection, $x$ and $y$ be two oriented edges of $\gm$. We say that $x$ and $y$ are \textit{symmetric} if the gluing pattern for $\gm$ starting at $x$ is the same as the one starting at $y$ up to relabeling. %(cyclic permutation is not allowed here).
plain_text_def: Let  be a one-faced collection, x and y be two oriented edges of . We say that x and y are symmetric if the gluing pattern for  starting at x is the same as the one starting at y up to relabeling.

def:
\label{symmetry}
A permutation is \textit{symmetric} if it is invariant under the reverse-complement map $rc$.
plain_text_def: A permutation is symmetric if it is invariant under the reverse-complement map rc.

def: The control law~\eqref{eq:control-law} is \emph{symmetric} if all the vehicles use the same control gains: $k_{(i,j)}=k_{0},$ for all $(i,j) \in \E$ and $b_i=b_0$ for all $i \in \V$, where $k_0$ and $b_0$ are positive constants.
plain_text_def: The control law (<ref>) is symmetric if all the vehicles use the same control gains: k_(i,j)=k_0, for all (i,j) ∈ and b_i=b_0 for all i ∈, where k_0 and b_0 are positive constants.

def:
We say $f\in L^\infty(\mathcal{B}_k)$ is \emph{symmetric} if for every permutation $\pi:[k]\rightarrow[k]$, $f\circ \pi=f$.  We say $A\in\mathcal{B}_k$ is symmetric if $\chi_A$ is.

Suppose that either $V=\bigcup_{i<k}V_i$, $H=(V_0,\ldots,V_{k-1},E)$ is a finite $k$-partite $k$-uniform hypergraph and $f\in L^\infty(\mathcal{B}_k)$, or $H=(V,E)$ and $f\in L^\infty(\mathcal{B}_k)$ is symmetric; then we define
\[t_H(f)=\int \prod_{e\in E}f(\vec x_e) d\mu^V.\]
When $A\in\mathcal{B}_k$, $t_H(A)=t_H(\chi_A)$.
plain_text_def:
We say f∈ L^∞(ℬ_k) is symmetric if for every permutation π:[k]→[k], f∘π=f.  We say A∈ℬ_k is symmetric if χ_A is.

Suppose that either V=⋃_i<kV_i, H=(V_0,…,V_k-1,E) is a finite k-partite k-uniform hypergraph and f∈ L^∞(ℬ_k), or H=(V,E) and f∈ L^∞(ℬ_k) is symmetric; then we define

    t_H(f)=∫∏_e∈ Ef(x⃗_e) dμ^V.

When A∈ℬ_k, t_H(A)=t_H(χ_A).

def:
[Yannakakis~\cite{Yan91}]
	\label{thm:YanLBSym}
	For even~$n$, the size of every \emph{symmetric} extended formulation of~$\matchPoly{n/2}{n}$ is at least 
	 $\Omega(\binom{n}{\lfloor (n-2)/4\rfloor})$.
plain_text_def:
[Yannakakis <cit.>]
	
	For even n, the size of every symmetric extended formulation of n/2n is at least 
	 Ω(n⌊ (n-2)/4⌋).

def: For two first-order structures $\cM$, $\cN$ an embedding $e:\cN\to \cM$ is called \emph{symmetric} if every automorphism of $e[\cN]$ extends to an automorphism of $\cM$. So a substructure $\cN\subset \cM$ is symmetrically embedded if the inclusion map $\iota$ is symmetric.
plain_text_def: For two first-order structures ,  an embedding e:→ is called symmetric if every automorphism of e[] extends to an automorphism of . So a substructure ⊂ is symmetrically embedded if the inclusion map ι is symmetric.

def:
Let \((N;v)\) be a coalitional game, and let \(i, j \in N\). Players
  \(i\) 
  and \(j\) are \emph{symmetric} if for every coalition 
  \(S \subseteq N \setminus \left\{i,j\right\} \), we have 
  \(v\left(S\cup \left\{i\right\}\right) = v\left(S \cup \left\{j\right\}\right).\)
plain_text_def:
Let (N;v) be a coalitional game, and let i, j ∈ N. Players
  i 
  and j are symmetric if for every coalition 
  S ⊆ N ∖{i,j}, we have 
  v(S∪{i}) = v(S ∪{j}).

def:
[c.f. {\cite[Section 4.1]{Fayers}}]
\label{DEF:level-t-group-action-self-conjugate}

Fix coprime $s,t\ge1$. Let $H_{s,t}$ be the subgroup of $G_{s,t}$ consisting of $f\in G_{s,t}$ such that $f(-1-m) = -1-f(m)$ for all $m\in\ZZ$ (based on the involution $m\mapsto -1-m$).

It is easy to check that $H_{s,t}$ has a group structure, and that it acts in the obvious way on the set of \emph{symmetric} $s$-sets $\mcal{S}_s(\lambda)$, or equivalently suitable beta-sets. This induces an action on $\mcal{D}_s$, via Corollary \ref{COR:conjugate-s-set}.
plain_text_def:
[c.f. <cit.>]


Fix coprime s,t≥1. Let H_s,t be the subgroup of G_s,t consisting of f∈ G_s,t such that f(-1-m) = -1-f(m) for all m∈ (based on the involution m↦ -1-m).

It is easy to check that H_s,t has a group structure, and that it acts in the obvious way on the set of symmetric s-sets S_s(λ), or equivalently suitable beta-sets. This induces an action on D_s, via Corollary <ref>.
