    ∑_i r_i F(_i)=0.

def:
For a function field $\mathbb{C}(C)$,
	a function $
u : \mathbb{C}(C) ightarrow \mathbb{Z} \cup \{\infty \}$ is a \emph{valuation} if 
	 egin{enumerate}[(i)]
		\item $
u (x) = \infty$ if and only if $x = 0$.
		
		\item $
u (xy) = 
u (x) + 
u (y)$.
		
		\item $
u (x + y) \geq \min \{ 
u (x) , 
u (y) \}$, with equality if $
u (x) 
eq 
u (y)$.
		
		\item $
u (x) = 0$ if $x \in \mathbb{C} \setminus \{0\}$.
	\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
For a function field ℂ(C),
	a function ν : ℂ(C) →ℤ∪{∞} is a valuation if 
	
		
  * ν (x) = ∞ if and only if x = 0.
		
		
  * ν (xy) = ν (x) + ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x + y) ≥min{ν (x) , ν (y) }, with equality if ν (x) ≠ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x) = 0 if x ∈ℂ∖{0}.

def:
Let $M$ be a vector space. An $M$-valued \emph{valuation} $\Phi$ is a  map
from the set of polyhedra $ \p\subset V$ to the vector space $M$
such that whenever the indicator functions $\charfun{\p_i}$ of a
family of polyhedra $\p_i$ satisfy a linear relation $\sum_i r_i
\charfun{\p_i}=0$, then the elements $\Phi(\p_i)$ satisfy the same
relation
$$
\sum_i r_i \Phi(\p_i)=0.
$$
plain_text_def:
Let M be a vector space. An M-valued valuation Φ is a  map
from the set of polyhedra ⊂ V to the vector space M
such that whenever the indicator functions _i of a
family of polyhedra _i satisfy a linear relation ∑_i r_i
_i=0, then the elements Φ(_i) satisfy the same
relation

    ∑_i r_i Φ(_i)=0.

def:
\label{VC}
Given a compactification $V$ of $U$, the \emph{variety of critical points} of $U$ is defined to be the closure 
\[
\mathfrak{X}_V(U):=\overline{\mathfrak{X}^\circ(U)} \subseteq V \times \mathbb{P}(W).
\]
We denote the variety of critical points by $\mathfrak{X}(U)$ when there is no danger of confusion.
plain_text_def:
Given a compactification V of U, the variety of critical points of U is defined to be the closure 

    𝔛_V(U):=𝔛^∘(U)⊆ V ×ℙ(W).

We denote the variety of critical points by 𝔛(U) when there is no danger of confusion.

def:
The \emph{variety of critical points} of $(X,D)$ is the closed subset
\[
\mathfrak{X}:= \Big\{(x,\xi) \mid  \mathscr{L}_{X,D,x}(\xi) =0 \Big\} \subseteq X \times \mathbb{P}(\mathfrak{b}).
\]
plain_text_def:
The variety of critical points of (X,D) is the closed subset

    𝔛:= {(x,ξ) |ℒ_X,D,x(ξ) =0 }⊆ X ×ℙ(𝔟).

def:
A pure simplicial complex $\Delta$ 
is called \emph{vertex decomposable} if
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\Delta$ is a simplex, or 
\item there is some vertex $v \in V$ such that $\Delta \setminus v$ and 
${\rm link}_\Delta(v)$ are vertex decomposable.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A pure simplicial complex Δ 
is called vertex decomposable if


  * Δ is a simplex, or 

  * there is some vertex v ∈ V such that Δ∖ v and 
link_Δ(v) are vertex decomposable.

def: A pure $d$-dimensional simplicial complex $\Delta$ is \emph{vertex decomposable} if it is the $d$-simplex or there exists a vertex $v$ such that $\lk_{\Delta}(v)$ and $\Delta\setminus v:=\left\lbrace F\in\Delta: v\notin F \right\rbrace $ are vertex decomposable.
plain_text_def: A pure d-dimensional simplicial complex Δ is vertex decomposable if it is the d-simplex or there exists a vertex v such that _Δ(v) and Δ∖ v:={ F∈Δ: v∉ F } are vertex decomposable.

A simplicial complex Δ is vertex-decomposable if either


  * Δ is a simplex

  * There exists a vertex v∈Δ such that 


  * _Δ(v) is vertex decomposable.

  * Del_Δ (v) = {σ∖ v | σ∈Δ} is vertex decomposable

def:
The connected regions that partition the triangle, $\TY$,
(in the sense that the intersections of the regions have zero $\R^2$-Lebesgue measure)
 such that each region has one and only one vertex of $\TY$ on its boundary
are called \emph{vertex regions} . $\square$
plain_text_def:
The connected regions that partition the triangle, ,
(in the sense that the intersections of the regions have zero ^2-Lebesgue measure)
 such that each region has one and only one vertex of  on its boundary
are called vertex regions . □

def:
The connected regions that partition the triangle, $\TY$,
(in the sense that the pairwise intersections of the regions have zero $\R^2$-Lebesgue measure)
 such that each region has one and only one vertex of $\TY$ on its boundary
are called \emph{vertex regions} .
$\square$
plain_text_def:
The connected regions that partition the triangle, ,
(in the sense that the pairwise intersections of the regions have zero ^2-Lebesgue measure)
 such that each region has one and only one vertex of  on its boundary
are called vertex regions .
□

A simplicial complex H is vertex-decomposable if 


  * H is a simplex or H = {∅}, or 

  * there exists a vertex x ∈ H such that 


  * H ∖{x} and _H(x) are vertex decomposable, and 

  * no facet of _H(x) is a facet of H ∖{x}.

A (not necessarily pure) simplicial complex Δ is vertex-decomposable if either 


  * Δ is a simplex, or

  * Δ contains a vertex v such that _Δ(v) and _Δ(v) are vertex-decomposable, and such that every facet of _Δ(v) is a facet of Δ.

def:
A \emph{vertex-minor} of a looped simple graph $G$ is a graph obtained from
$G$ through some sequence of local complementations, loop complementations
and vertex deletions.
plain_text_def:
A vertex-minor of a looped simple graph G is a graph obtained from
G through some sequence of local complementations, loop complementations
and vertex deletions.

def: Let $G$ and $H$ be looped simple graphs. Then $H$ is a~\emph{vertex-minor} of $G$ if there is a graph $G'$ that is locally equivalent to $G$, such that $H=G'-X$ for some subset $X \subseteq V(G')$.
plain_text_def: Let G and H be looped simple graphs. Then H is a vertex-minor of G if there is a graph G' that is locally equivalent to G, such that H=G'-X for some subset X ⊆ V(G').

def: We call a partition $p\in \Cp$ \emph{verticolor-reflexive} if $\tilde p=p$.
plain_text_def: We call a partition p∈ verticolor-reflexive if p̃=p.

def: A partition $p\in \Cp$ is called \emph{verticolor-reflexive} if $\tilde p=p$.
plain_text_def: A partition p∈ is called verticolor-reflexive if p̃=p.

Let σ∈ S_n, we denote by (d_i(σ))_i and (g_i(σ))_i the finite sequences defined by


  * d_i(σ):=| { j>i  |  σ(j)<σ(i) }|,

  * g_i(σ):=| { j<i  |  σ(j)>σ(i) }|.

We denote by μ(σ) and λ(σ) the partitions obtained by rearranging in a nonincreasing order the sequences (d_i)_i and (g_i)_i, respectively. We say that σ is vexillary if and only if λ(σ)=μ'(σ).

[<cit.>]
  A weak composition a is vexillary if the following hold:
  
  
  *  if i<k and a_i > a_k, then #{ i<j<k | a_j < a_k}≤ a_i-a_k;
  
  *  if i<k and a_i ≤ a_k, then a_j ≥ a_i whenever i<j<k.

def:
Given a graph $G(V,E)$ with its vertices colored with black and
white. Any black vertex $v$ can be pressed, which has the following
effect: (a) all neighbors of $v$ change color, white neighbors become
black and \emph{vice versa} , (b) all pair of neighbors of $v$ change
connectivity, connected pairs become unconnected, unconnected ones
become connected, (c) and finally, $v$ becomes a separated white
vertex. The aim of the game is to transform $G$ into an all white,
empty graph.
plain_text_def:
Given a graph G(V,E) with its vertices colored with black and
white. Any black vertex v can be pressed, which has the following
effect: (a) all neighbors of v change color, white neighbors become
black and vice versa , (b) all pair of neighbors of v change
connectivity, connected pairs become unconnected, unconnected ones
become connected, (c) and finally, v becomes a separated white
vertex. The aim of the game is to transform G into an all white,
empty graph.

def:
\label{mainLemmaLexProd}
Let $G$ be a connected graph and let $H$ be a non-trivial graph. Then, every metric generator for $G \circ H$ is also an adjacency generator, and \textit{vice versa} .
plain_text_def: Let G be a connected graph and let H be a non-trivial graph. Then, every metric generator for G ∘ H is also an adjacency generator, and vice versa .

def:
For a standard tableau $T$, let $(\tau^{(k)}|\ldots|\tau^{(1)})$ be the run decomposition of $T$. Set $t_k = \mathrm{row}(\tau^{(k)}_1)$ and, for $i<k$, set $t_i = \min(\mathrm{row}(\tau^{(i)}_j),t_{i+1}-1)$, where $j=1,\ldots,|\tau^{(i)}|$. Define the \emph{weak descent composition of $T$} , denoted by $\des(T)$, by $\des(T)_{t_i} = |\tau^{(i)}|$ and all other parts are zero if all $t_i>0$ and $\des(T) = \varnothing$ otherwise.
  \label{def:des-std}
plain_text_def: For a standard tableau T, let (τ^(k)|…|τ^(1)) be the run decomposition of T. Set t_k = row(τ^(k)_1) and, for i<k, set t_i = min(row(τ^(i)_j),t_i+1-1), where j=1,…,|τ^(i)|. Define the weak descent composition of T , denoted by (T), by (T)_t_i = |τ^(i)| and all other parts are zero if all t_i>0 and (T) = ∅ otherwise.

[<cit.>]
  For a standard key tableau T, define the weak descent composition of T , denoted by (T), as follows. Let (τ^(k) | ⋯ | τ^(1)) be the run decomposition of n ⋯ 2 1 based on descents of T, that is, each τ^(i) has no descents between adjacent letters and is as long as possible. Set t_i = min(τ^(i)) for i=1,…,k. Set t̂_k = r_k, and for i<k, set t̂_i = min(r_i,t̂_i+1-1). If t_1 ≤ 0, then define (ρ) = ∅; otherwise, set the t̂_ith part of (T) to be (T)_t̂_i = |τ^(i)| and set all other parts to 0.

def:
Given a standard filling $T$ of a key diagram, the \emph{weak descent composition of $T$} , denoted by $\des(T)$, is constructed as follows. Partition the decreasing permutation $n \cdots 2 1$ into blocks, say $\tau^{(k)} | \cdots | \tau^{(1)}$, broken between $i+1$ and $i$ precisely when $i+1$ lies weakly right of $i$ in $T$. Set $t_k$ to be the row of $\tau^{(k)}_1$ if it lies in the first column and otherwise $n$. For $i<k$, set $t_i = \min(\mathrm{row}(\tau^{(i)}_1),t_{i+1}-1)$ if $\tau^{(i)}_1$ lies in the first column and otherwise $t_{i+1}-1$. Set $\des(T)_{t_i} = |\tau^{(i)}|$ and all other parts are zero if all $t_i>0$ and $\des(T) = \varnothing$ otherwise. 
  \label{def:weak-des}
plain_text_def: Given a standard filling T of a key diagram, the weak descent composition of T , denoted by (T), is constructed as follows. Partition the decreasing permutation n ⋯ 2 1 into blocks, say τ^(k) | ⋯ | τ^(1), broken between i+1 and i precisely when i+1 lies weakly right of i in T. Set t_k to be the row of τ^(k)_1 if it lies in the first column and otherwise n. For i<k, set t_i = min(row(τ^(i)_1),t_i+1-1) if τ^(i)_1 lies in the first column and otherwise t_i+1-1. Set (T)_t_i = |τ^(i)| and all other parts are zero if all t_i>0 and (T) = ∅ otherwise.

[<cit.>]
  For a reduced word ρ, define the weak descent composition of ρ , denoted by (ρ), as follows. Let (ρ^(k) | ⋯ | ρ^(1)) be the run decomposition of ρ, that is, each ρ^(i) is increasing and as long as possible. Set r_i = min(ρ^(i)) for i=1,…,k. Set r̂_k = r_k, and for i<k, set r̂_i = min(r_i,r̂_i+1-1). If r_1 ≤ 0, then define (ρ) = ∅; otherwise, set the r̂_ith part of (ρ) to be (ρ)_r̂_i = |ρ^(i)| and set all other parts to 0.

def:
For a reduced expression $\rho$ with run decomposition $(\rho^{(k)} | \cdots | \rho^{(1)})$, set $r_k = \rho^{(k)}_1$ and, for $i<k$, set $r_i = \min(\rho^{(i)}_1,r_{i+1}-1)$. Define the \emph{weak descent composition of $\rho$} , denoted by $\des(\rho)$, by $\des(\rho)_{r_i} = |\rho^{(i)}|$ and all other parts are zero if all $r_i>0$ and $\des(\rho) = \varnothing$ otherwise.
  \label{def:des-red}
plain_text_def: For a reduced expression ρ with run decomposition (ρ^(k) | ⋯ | ρ^(1)), set r_k = ρ^(k)_1 and, for i<k, set r_i = min(ρ^(i)_1,r_i+1-1). Define the weak descent composition of ρ , denoted by (ρ), by (ρ)_r_i = |ρ^(i)| and all other parts are zero if all r_i>0 and (ρ) = ∅ otherwise.

[<cit.>]
    For a reduced expression ρ with run decomposition (ρ^(k) | ⋯ | ρ^(1)), set r_k = ρ^(k)_1 and, for i<k, set r_i = min(ρ^(i)_1,r_i+1-1). Define the weak descent composition of ρ , denoted by (ρ), by (ρ)_r_i = |ρ^(i)| and all other parts are zero if all r_i>0 and (ρ) = ∅ otherwise.

Let 𝒜 be a finite set, and let  be a map from 𝒜 to weak compositions of n. A weak dual equivalence for (𝒜 ,) is a family of involutions {ψ_i}_1<i<n on 𝒜 such that
  
  
  
  * For all i-h ≤ 3 and all T ∈𝒜, there exists a weak composition a of i-h+3 such that
    
    ∑_U ∈ [T]_(h,i)__(h-1,i+1)(U) = _a,

    where [T]_(h,i) is the equivalence class generated by ψ_h,…,ψ_i, and _(h,i)(T) is the weak composition of i-h+1 obtained by deleting the first h-1 and last n-i nonzero parts from (T).
    
  
  * For all |i-j| ≥ 3 and all T ∈𝒜, we have
    
      ψ_j ψ_i(T) = ψ_i ψ_j(T).

[<cit.>]
  Let 𝒜 be a finite set, and let  be a map from 𝒜 to weak compositions of n. A weak dual equivalence for (𝒜 ,) is a family of involutions {ψ_i}_1<i<n on 𝒜 such that
  
  
  
  * For all i-h ≤ 3 and all T ∈𝒜, there exists a weak composition a of i-h+3 such that
    
    ∑_U ∈ [T]_(h,i)__(h-1,i+1)(U) = _a,

    where [T]_(h,i) is the equivalence class generated by ψ_h,…,ψ_i, and _(h,i)(T) deletes the first h-1 and last n-i nonzero parts from (T).
    
  
  * For all |i-j| ≥ 3 and all T ∈𝒜, we have ψ_jψ_i(T) = ψ_iψ_j(T).

<cit.>

For every c∈ and projective a∈, we call
    
    (Br(c| a|c))Br(c|Br(c| a|c)| c)

    the weak inversion and
        
    (Br(c| a|c))Br(c|Id(c)⊗ a⊗Id(c)| c)

        the strong inversion of Br(c| a|c).

def:
\textbf{\cite{Marshall79,Zhang08}}
A non-negative vector $\mathbf{x} = (x_1, ..., x_p)$, $p \in
\mathbb{N}$, \emph{weakly majorizes} a non-negative vector
$\mathbf{y} = (y_1, ..., y_p)$ (which is denoted with
$\mathbf{y}\preceq^w \mathbf{x}$ or $\mathbf{x}\succeq^w
\mathbf{y}$) if
$$\sum_{i=1}^k x_{[i]} \le \sum_{i=1}^k y_{[i]} \text{ for all }k=1,...,p.$$
Moreover, if $\mathbf{x}_\uparrow \neq \mathbf{y}_\uparrow$, then
$\mathbf{x}$ is said to \emph{strictly weakly majorize} $\mathbf{y}$
(which is denoted with $\mathbf{y}\prec^w \mathbf{x}$ or
$\mathbf{x}\succ^w \mathbf{y}$).
plain_text_def:
<cit.>
A non-negative vector 𝐱 = (x_1, ..., x_p), p ∈ℕ, weakly majorizes a non-negative vector
𝐲 = (y_1, ..., y_p) (which is denoted with
𝐲≼^w 𝐱 or 𝐱≽^w
𝐲) if

    ∑_i=1^k x_[i]≤∑_i=1^k y_[i] for all k=1,...,p.

Moreover, if 𝐱_↑≠𝐲_↑, then
𝐱 is said to strictly weakly majorize 𝐲
(which is denoted with 𝐲≺^w 𝐱 or
𝐱≻^w 𝐲).

def:
\textbf{\cite{Marshall79,Zhang08}}
A non-negative vector $\mathbf{x} = (x_1, ..., x_p)$, $p \in
\mathbb{N}$, \emph{weakly majorizes} a non-negative vector
$\mathbf{y} = (y_1, ..., y_p)$ (which is denoted with
$\mathbf{x}\succeq \mathbf{y}$) if
$$\sum_{i=1}^k x_{[i]} \le \sum_{i=1}^k y_{[i]} \text{ for all }k=1,...,p.$$
If $\mathbf{x}_\uparrow \neq \mathbf{y}_\uparrow$, then $\mathbf{x}$
is said to \emph{strictly weakly majorize} $\mathbf{y}$ (which is
denoted with $\mathbf{x}\succ \mathbf{y}$).
plain_text_def:
<cit.>
A non-negative vector 𝐱 = (x_1, ..., x_p), p ∈ℕ, weakly majorizes a non-negative vector
𝐲 = (y_1, ..., y_p) (which is denoted with
𝐱≽𝐲) if

    ∑_i=1^k x_[i]≤∑_i=1^k y_[i] for all k=1,...,p.

If 𝐱_↑≠𝐲_↑, then 𝐱
is said to strictly weakly majorize 𝐲 (which is
denoted with 𝐱≻𝐲).

def: Given a partition $\mu$ with parts $\mu_j=2^{k_j}\cdot m_j$, where $m_j$ odd, the \textit{weight} of the partition is $wt(\mu)=\ds \sum_{j=1}^{\ell(\mu)} (2^{k_j}-1)$.
plain_text_def: Given a partition μ with parts μ_j=2^k_j· m_j, where m_j odd, the weight of the partition is wt(μ)=∑_j=1^ℓ(μ) (2^k_j-1).

def:
\label{weight}
The vertices of the digraph $G_{n}$ are the elements of $\mathcal{S}_{n}$. For two permutations (vertices) $p_{\alpha}$ and $p_{\alpha '}$, there is an arc from $p_{\alpha}$ to $p_{\alpha '}$ if and only if the last symbols of $p_{\alpha}$ match the first symbols of $p_{\alpha '}$ (there is no arc when there is no match). Let $p_{\alpha},p_{\alpha '} \in \mathcal{S}_{n}$ be two connected vertices in $G_{n}$. The \textit{weight} $f_{n}(\alpha,\alpha ') \in \{1, \ldots, n-1 \}$ associated with the arc $(p_{\alpha},p_{\alpha '})$ is the number of symbols that have to be erased to the left of $p_{\alpha}$ so that the last symbols of $p_{\alpha}$ match the first symbols of $p_{\alpha '}$.
plain_text_def: The vertices of the digraph G_n are the elements of 𝒮_n. For two permutations (vertices) p_α and p_α ', there is an arc from p_α to p_α ' if and only if the last symbols of p_α match the first symbols of p_α ' (there is no arc when there is no match). Let p_α,p_α '∈𝒮_n be two connected vertices in G_n. The weight f_n(α,α ') ∈{1, …, n-1 } associated with the arc (p_α,p_α ') is the number of symbols that have to be erased to the left of p_α so that the last symbols of p_α match the first symbols of p_α '.

def: Let $e=\{x,y\} \in E(G)$. The \emph{weight} of $e$ is defined as $\wt(e)=x+y$.
plain_text_def: Let e={x,y}∈ E(G). The weight of e is defined as (e)=x+y.

def:
[Weight of a $(m,k,s)$-star: $w(S_{m,k,s})$]
The \textit{weight} of a $(m,k,s)$-star of vertices set $\mathcal V_1\cup\mathcal V_2$ is defined as follows:\\
let $\{i_1,...,i_m\}=\mathcal V_1$, and $w(i_1,j)=...=w(i_m,j), \forall j\in\mathcal V_2$ where all the vertices in $\mathcal V_1$ are connected to each other by links with the same weight, $w(i_p,i_1)=...=w(i_p,i_{p-1})=w(i_p,i_{p+1})=...=w(i_p,i_{m}), \forall i_p\in\mathcal V_1$, then we denote the weight of a $(m,k,s)$-star by $w(S_{m,k,s})$: $$w(S_{m,k,s}):=\sum_{j\in \mathcal V}w(i,j)
\mbox{ for any }i\in\mathcal V_1.$$
plain_text_def:
[Weight of a (m,k,s)-star: w(S_m,k,s)]
The weight of a (m,k,s)-star of vertices set 𝒱_1∪𝒱_2 is defined as follows:

let {i_1,...,i_m}=𝒱_1, and w(i_1,j)=...=w(i_m,j), ∀ j∈𝒱_2 where all the vertices in 𝒱_1 are connected to each other by links with the same weight, w(i_p,i_1)=...=w(i_p,i_p-1)=w(i_p,i_p+1)=...=w(i_p,i_m), ∀ i_p∈𝒱_1, then we denote the weight of a (m,k,s)-star by w(S_m,k,s): 
    w(S_m,k,s):=∑_j∈𝒱w(i,j)
    i∈𝒱_1.

def:
\label{def:weightB}
The \emph{weight} $\wei_\gamma(\sigma)$ of $\sigma = (S, \veps)
\in \Sigma^B(n)$ (equivalently, of the signed composition of $n$
corresponding to $\sigma$) with respect to $\gamma$ is defined as
follows:
  \begin{itemize}
    \itemsep=0pt
    \item[$\bullet$]
    $\wei_\gamma(\sigma) := 0$ %The weight is zero
    if either $\sigma$ is not $\gamma$-unimodal, or else
    for some index $1 \le i \le k$ the sign vector $\teps \in \{-, +\}^n$ of $\sigma$
    is not constant on the set $\{r_{i-1} + 1,\dots,r_i\}$.
    \item[$\bullet$]
    Otherwise we set
      \begin{equation} \label{eq:defwei}
        \wei_\gamma (\sigma) \ := \
        (-1)^{|S \sm S(\gamma)| \, + \, n_\gamma(\sigma)}
      \end{equation}
    where $n_\gamma (\sigma)$ is the number of indices $i$ for which
    the elements of $\{r_{i-1} + 1,\dots,r_i\}$ are assigned the negative sign by
    (the sign vectors of) both $\sigma$ and $\gamma$.
  \end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
The weight _γ(σ) of σ = (S, )
∈Σ^B(n) (equivalently, of the signed composition of n
corresponding to σ) with respect to γ is defined as
follows:
  
    =0pt
    
  ∙
    _γ(σ) := 0 
    if either σ is not γ-unimodal, or else
    for some index 1 ≤ i ≤ k the sign vector ∈{-, +}^n of σ
    is not constant on the set {r_i-1 + 1,…,r_i}.
    
  ∙
    Otherwise we set
      
    _γ (σ)  :=         (-1)^|S  S(γ)|   +   n_γ(σ)

    where n_γ (σ) is the number of indices i for which
    the elements of {r_i-1 + 1,…,r_i} are assigned the negative sign by
    (the sign vectors of) both σ and γ.

def: The \emph{weight} of a position $P$ is the sum of $P(v)$ over all vertices $v$ of $G$.
plain_text_def: The weight of a position P is the sum of P(v) over all vertices v of G.

Let σ_Γ be any fixed top dimensional cone of the tropical moduli space ℳ^trop_h,r+s. Denote by σ^_Θ↦σ_Γ a  cone  in the moduli space ^trop_g,d(μ⃗) of combinatorial type Θ such that the base graph of Θ  is equal to Γ. The restriction of the tropical branch map is a surjective morphism of cones with integral structure of the same dimension, and consequently has a dilation factor which we denote d_Θ(br).

Refer to Definition <ref> for the precise definition of the  weight ω(Θ). Informally, this weight is a product of “local Hurwitz numbers”, expansion factors along bounded edges, and an automorphism factor. 


Then the  Hurwitz number is equal to: 

    h_g→ h,d(μ⃗) = ∑_σ^_Θ↦σ_Γω(Θ)· d_Θ(br^trop).

def:
\label{3.H}
The \textit{weight} of a standard path with endpoint $\lambda$ is
defined as the
product of the weights of the edges comprising the path. Let us say
that a
probability measure on the path space of $\Ga(q,d)$ is a \textit{Gibbs
measure}
if, for every~$\lambda$, the conditional measure of a standard path terminating
at $\lambda$ is proportional to the weight of this path (in the
terminology of
Kerov and Vershik \cite{VK}, such a measure is called ``central'').
plain_text_def:
The weight of a standard path with endpoint λ is
defined as the
product of the weights of the edges comprising the path. Let us say
that a
probability measure on the path space of (q,d) is a Gibbs
measure
if, for every λ, the conditional measure of a standard path terminating
at λ is proportional to the weight of this path (in the
terminology of
Kerov and Vershik <cit.>, such a measure is called “central”).

def:
\label{Osets}
For any configuration $c$, we can partition the figures of $c$ into $k$ maximal sets $O_i$ such that all the figures in $O_i$ are identical and overlap completely. Then the \textit{weight} $w_c$ of a configuration $c$ is defined to equal $\prod_{i=1}^{k}(o_i!)^{-1}$, where $o_i = |O_i|$.
plain_text_def: For any configuration c, we can partition the figures of c into k maximal sets O_i such that all the figures in O_i are identical and overlap completely. Then the weight w_c of a configuration c is defined to equal ∏_i=1^k(o_i!)^-1, where o_i = |O_i|.

def: The \emph{weight} function $w_\Gamma:\Gamma\to\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ assigns to each vertex of $\Gamma$ the number of lattice points in the interior of its dual face, and is zero everywhere else.
plain_text_def: The weight function w_Γ:Γ→ℤ_≥ 0 assigns to each vertex of Γ the number of lattice points in the interior of its dual face, and is zero everywhere else.

def:
The \emph{weight} of the cylindric partition $\mathfrak{c} = (\mu^0, \mu^1, \ldots \mu^T)$ is given by
$  |\mathfrak{c}| = |\mu^1| + |\mu^2| + \cdots |\mu^T|$.
plain_text_def:
The weight of the cylindric partition 𝔠 = (μ^0, μ^1, …μ^T) is given by
|𝔠| = |μ^1| + |μ^2| + ⋯ |μ^T|.

The
 weight of a directed edge (x,y) of G is 

    w(x,y):= -1/(x)∑_i=0^(x)-1 i (y_i+1)/(y_i+1),
  
where  (x,y_i):=m_x^i(x,y) is the edge obtained by incrementing the edge (x,y) for i consecutive times by using the rotor mechanism at x.

def: The \emph{weight} of a vertex $v \in V(Q_n)$, denoted by $w(v)$, is the number of $1$'s in the binary representation of $v$.
plain_text_def: The weight of a vertex v ∈ V(Q_n), denoted by w(v), is the number of 1's in the binary representation of v.

Let P be a feasible partition on G=(V,E).  The weight of P is defined as
    
    w(P) = |E|/k_P-1.

def:
[Weight of a witness tree]
For any tree-structure $\tau$, whose nodes are labeled by events $B_1, \dots, B_s$, we define the \emph{weight} of $\tau$ by
$w(\tau) = \prod_{i=1}^s P_{\Omega}(B_i)$.
plain_text_def:
[Weight of a witness tree]
For any tree-structure τ, whose nodes are labeled by events B_1, …, B_s, we define the weight of τ by
w(τ) = ∏_i=1^s P_Ω(B_i).

def:
\label{def:frachomM}Let $\cL$ be a $3$-uniform hypergraph. 
A function $h\colon V(\cL) \times E(\cL) \rightarrow [0,1]$ is called a fractional $\hom(\cM)$-tiling of $\cL$ if
\begin{enumerate}[label=\alabel]
\item $h(v,e) \neq 0 \Rightarrow v \in e$,
\item \label{en:pk2} $h(v) = \sum_{e \in E(\cL)}h(v,e) \leq 1$,
\item  \label{en:pk3} for every $e \in E(\cL)$ there exists a labeling of the vertices of $e = uvw$ such that \[h(u,e) = h(v,e) \geq h(w,e) \geq \frac23 h(u,e)\]
\end{enumerate}
By $h_{\min}$ we denote the smallest non-zero value of $h(v,e)$ (and we set $h_{\min}=\infty$ if $h\equiv 0$) and
 the sum over all values is the \emph{weight} $w(h)$ of $h$
  \[w(h) = \sum_{(v,e) \in V(\cL) \times E(\cL)} h(v,e)\,.\]
plain_text_def:
Let  be a 3-uniform hypergraph. 
A function h V() × E() → [0,1] is called a fractional ()-tiling of  if


  * h(v,e) ≠ 0 ⇒ v ∈ e,

  *  h(v) = ∑_e ∈ E()h(v,e) ≤ 1,

  *  for every e ∈ E() there exists a labeling of the vertices of e = uvw such that 
    h(u,e) = h(v,e) ≥ h(w,e) ≥2/3 h(u,e)


By h_min we denote the smallest non-zero value of h(v,e) (and we set h_min=∞ if h≡ 0) and
 the sum over all values is the weight w(h) of h
  
    w(h) = ∑_(v,e) ∈ V() × E() h(v,e) .

def:
The \emph{weight} of a rectangle $R$ is $\wt(R) = 2\sum_{p\in R}\rho(p,R)$,
and the weight of a spin~$s$ about $R$ is $\wt(s) = \wt(R)$.
plain_text_def:
The weight of a rectangle R is (R) = 2∑_p∈ Rρ(p,R),
and the weight of a spin s about R is (s) = (R).

def:
Given a (possibly looped) graph $H$ and a function $\la:V(H)\to (0,\infty)$, we define the \emph{weight} of a homomorphism $\phi\in \Hom(G,H)$ to be
	\[
		w^{\la}(\phi)=\prod_{v\in V(G)} \la(\phi(v)).
	\]
	The analogue of the number of homomorphisms is the total weight of all homomorphisms from $G$ to $H$.  We write
	\[
		Z^{\la}(G,H)=\sum_{\phi\in \Hom(G,H)} w^{\la}(\phi).
	\]
plain_text_def:
Given a (possibly looped) graph H and a function :V(H)→ (0,∞), we define the weight of a homomorphism ϕ∈(G,H) to be
	
    w^(ϕ)=∏_v∈ V(G)(ϕ(v)).

	The analogue of the number of homomorphisms is the total weight of all homomorphisms from G to H.  We write
	
    Z^(G,H)=∑_ϕ∈(G,H) w^(ϕ).

The weight () of a staircase tableau  is a monomial in
α, β, γ, δ, q, and u, which we obtain as follows.
Every blank box of  is assigned a q or u, based on the label of the closest
labeled box to its right in the same row and the label of the closest labeled box
below it in the same column, such that:


  * every blank box which sees a β to its right gets a u;

  * every blank box which sees a δ to its right gets  a q;

  * every blank box which sees an α or γ to its right,
  and an α or δ below it, gets  a u;

  * every blank box which sees an α or γ to its right,
  and a β or γ below it, gets a q.

After filling all blank boxes,
we define ()
to be the product of all labels in all boxes.

def:
We will say that in a generating tuple $\langle\mu, d\rangle$
\emph{weights are degree-monotone} , if for any $m, m' \in M(\mu,d)$
from $d(m) < d(m')$ it follows that $\mu(m) \le \mu(m')$, and for
any $w\in W(\mu,d)$ we have $\mu(w)>0$.
plain_text_def:
We will say that in a generating tuple ⟨μ, d⟩
weights are degree-monotone , if for any m, m' ∈ M(μ,d)
from d(m) < d(m') it follows that μ(m) ≤μ(m'), and for
any w∈ W(μ,d) we have μ(w)>0.

def:
We will say that in the generating tuple $\langle\mu, d\rangle$
\emph{weights are degree-monotone} if for any pair of internal
vertices $m, m' \in M$ from $d(m) < d(m')$ it follows that $\mu(m)
\le \mu(m')$. We also require pendent vertices to have positive
weights: $d(v)=1\Rightarrow \mu(v)>0$.
plain_text_def:
We will say that in the generating tuple ⟨μ, d⟩
weights are degree-monotone if for any pair of internal
vertices m, m' ∈ M from d(m) < d(m') it follows that μ(m)
≤μ(m'). We also require pendent vertices to have positive
weights: d(v)=1⇒μ(v)>0.

def:
We will say that in a generating tuple $\langle\mu, d\rangle$
\emph{weights are degree-monotone} , if for any $m, m' \in M(\mu,d)$
from $d(m) < d(m')$ it follows that $\mu(m) \le \mu(m')$, and, also,
$\mu(w)>0$ for any $w\in W(\mu,d)$.
plain_text_def:
We will say that in a generating tuple ⟨μ, d⟩
weights are degree-monotone , if for any m, m' ∈ M(μ,d)
from d(m) < d(m') it follows that μ(m) ≤μ(m'), and, also,
μ(w)>0 for any w∈ W(μ,d).

[Well-founded combinatorial system]
Let H be a vector of  species. The combinatorial system Y= H( Z, Y) is said to be  well founded when the iteration

    <ref>
             Y^[0]=0  and   Y^[n+1]= H( Z, Y^[n]),   n≥0

is well defined, defines a convergent sequence and the limit S of this sequence has no zero coordinate.

def:
We recall that a poset $P$ is \emph{well founded} if every nonempty
subset contains some minimal element; equivalently, $P$ contains no
infinite chain of type $\omega^*$.
plain_text_def:
We recall that a poset P is well founded if every nonempty
subset contains some minimal element; equivalently, P contains no
infinite chain of type ω^*.

def:
\label{canonical:def}
We say that a triple $(G,H,\sigma)$ is \emph{well-behaved} if $(H,\sigma)$ is a $k$-system of magnitude $d$ in a graph $G$,
such that $\sigma$ is slim and the following conditions are satisfied:
\begin{description}
 \item[\icanonical{1}] $G$ is 3-edge connected,
 \item[\icanonical{2}] vertices in $V(G)\setminus V(\sigma)$ have degree exactly $3$,
 \item[\icanonical{3}] for every $v\in R(H)$, if $K$ is an $k$-edge cut in $G$ separating $\sigma(c(H))$ from $\sigma(v)$,
    then $K$ consists of the edges incident with $\sigma(v)$,
 \item[\icanonical{4}] every edge of $E(G)\setminus E(\sigma)$ is incident with a vertex in $\sigma(R(H))$ of degree exactly $k$,
 \item[\icanonical{5}] for each vertex $v\in V(\sigma)\setminus \sigma(V(H))$, at most one edge incident with $v$
   does not belong to $E(\sigma)$.  Furthermore, if there is such an edge and $v$ belongs to the path $\sigma(e)$ for an edge $e\in E(H)$,
   then $v$ is the next-to-last vertex of $\sigma(e)$ and the last vertex of $\sigma(e)$ has degree exactly $k$.
\end{description}
plain_text_def:
We say that a triple (G,H,σ) is well-behaved if (H,σ) is a k-system of magnitude d in a graph G,
such that σ is slim and the following conditions are satisfied:

 
  1 G is 3-edge connected,
 
  2 vertices in V(G)∖ V(σ) have degree exactly 3,
 
  3 for every v∈ R(H), if K is an k-edge cut in G separating σ(c(H)) from σ(v),
    then K consists of the edges incident with σ(v),
 
  4 every edge of E(G)∖ E(σ) is incident with a vertex in σ(R(H)) of degree exactly k,
 
  5 for each vertex v∈ V(σ)∖σ(V(H)), at most one edge incident with v
   does not belong to E(σ).  Furthermore, if there is such an edge and v belongs to the path σ(e) for an edge e∈ E(H),
   then v is the next-to-last vertex of σ(e) and the last vertex of σ(e) has degree exactly k.

A σ-Bulgarian solitaire is said to be well-behaved if the following three conditions on σ are satisfied:


  * σ(1)=1,

  * σ(h) is a non-decreasing function,

  * σ̅(h):=h-σ(h) is a non-decreasing function.

def: The second neighborhood of a vertex $v$ of a planar triangulation is \emph{well-behaved} if the subgraph of $G$ induced by vertices at distance $i$ from $v$ is a circuit for $i = 1, 2$.
plain_text_def: The second neighborhood of a vertex v of a planar triangulation is well-behaved if the subgraph of G induced by vertices at distance i from v is a circuit for i = 1, 2.

def:
\label{edgedist}
Given a graph~$G$ we say that $\AA\subset \KK_r$ is \emph{well-distributed} if, for each $e\in E(G)$, there are at least $k_r/2$ sets $A\subset V(G) \setminus V(e)$ for which $|A|=r$ and, for each subset $B\subset V(e)\cup A$ with $|B|=r$, $G[B]\in \AA$.
plain_text_def: Given a graph G we say that Å⊂_r is well-distributed if, for each e∈ E(G), there are at least k_r/2 sets A⊂ V(G) ∖ V(e) for which |A|=r and, for each subset B⊂ V(e)∪ A with |B|=r, G[B]∈Å.

def:
Let $i \geq 0$ and let $\lambda \geq 0$ be a parameter.  We say that $r \in
\zed/Q_i\zed$ is $\lambda$-\emph{well-distributed} if $R_{i+1} \cap (r \bmod
Q_i)$ is non-empty, and if the fibre satisfies the uniformity property
that for each $n \in \cN_{i+1}$,
\begin{equation}\label{lambda_well_distributed} \max_{b \bmod n} \frac{|R_{i+1}
\cap
(b\bmod n) \cap
(r \bmod Q_i) \bmod Q_{i+1}| }{|R_{i+1}
\cap
(r \bmod Q_i) \bmod Q_{i+1}|} \leq \frac{e^{\lambda \omega(n)}}{n} .
\end{equation}
plain_text_def:
Let i ≥ 0 and let λ≥ 0 be a parameter.  We say that r ∈/Q_i is λ-well-distributed if R_i+1∩ (r 
Q_i) is non-empty, and if the fibre satisfies the uniformity property
that for each n ∈_i+1,

    max_b  n|R_i+1∩
    (b n) ∩
    (r  Q_i)  Q_i+1| /|R_i+1∩
    (r  Q_i)  Q_i+1|≤e^λω(n)/n .

def: Let $n$ be a positive integer larger than three. The \index{wheel graph}\emph{wheel graph} denoted by $W_{n}$ is defined by the graph join $C_{n}+K_{1}$.
plain_text_def: Let n be a positive integer larger than three. The wheel graphwheel graph denoted by W_n is defined by the graph join C_n+K_1.

def: A \emph{wheel graph} on $n$ vertices is defined by $\mathcal{W}_n=\mathcal{C}_{n-1}+K_1$. $K_1$ is called the center of the wheel.
plain_text_def: A wheel graph on n vertices is defined by 𝒲_n=𝒞_n-1+K_1. K_1 is called the center of the wheel.

def:
\rm{
\cite{FH} For $n\geq4$, a \textit{wheel graph} $W_n$ is defined to be the graph $K_1+ C_{n-1}$.}
plain_text_def: <cit.> For n≥4, a wheel graph W_n is defined to be the graph K_1+ C_n-1.

def:
[Erd\H{o}s--R\'enyi]\label{Erdos-Renyi}
Let $c$ be a constant and $n$ an arbitrarily large positive integer. Furthermore let 
$$ 
p = \frac{\log{n} + c}{n}\;
$$
and consider a random bipartite graph $G'\sim B(n,p)$.

Then the probability there is a perfect matching in $G'$ is asymptotically equal to
$$
\Pr(\mbox{There exists a perfect matching in $G'$}) = (1+o(1)) \exp(-2 e^{-c})\;.
$$
In particular if $ np-\log{n} \tends +\infty$ when $n\tends + \infty,$ then there exists a
matching in $G'$ \textit{whp} ; and if $np-\log{n} \tends -\infty$ when $n\tends
+\infty,$ then no matching exists in $G'$ \textit{whp} .
plain_text_def:
[Erdős–Rényi]
Let c be a constant and n an arbitrarily large positive integer. Furthermore let 

    p = logn + c/n

and consider a random bipartite graph G'∼ B(n,p).

Then the probability there is a perfect matching in G' is asymptotically equal to

    () = (1+o(1)) exp(-2 e^-c) .

In particular if np-logn +∞ when n + ∞, then there exists a
matching in G' whp ; and if np-logn -∞ when n
+∞, then no matching exists in G' whp .

The random geometric graph process satisfies Added “emph” to whp in the whole paper

    ρ_n(Maker wins the connectivity game) =
    ρ_n(minimum degree ≥ 2)   whp .

def:
\label{devthm}
Suppose we are given an assignment of non-negative real numbers $\lambda_{x} \in \mathbf R_+$ and coefficients $a_x \in [0,1]$ for each element $x \in \mathcal X$. (Recall that an element $x$ refers to an ordered pair $(i,j)$, where $i \in [n]$ and $j$ is a possible assignment to variable $X_i$)

Define $\mu = \sum_x a_x \lambda_x$, and for each $i \in [n]$ define $\mu_i  = \sum_{j} a_{i,j} \lambda_{i,j}$.

Suppose that there is a complex bad event $\mathcal B$ defined by $$
\mathcal B \equiv \sum_x a_k [X_i = j] \geq t
$$
where we use the Iverson notation for whether variable $i$ takes on value $j$, where $t \geq \mu$.  Let $d$ be any non-negative integer. Then, recalling Definition~\ref{defn:G}, there is a fractional hitting-set $Q$ with the property 
\[ G(Q, \lambda) \leq \frac{\mu^d} {d! \binom{t}{d}}; ~~
G_i(Q, \lambda) \leq \frac{d \mu_i}{\mu}  \cdot \frac{\mu^{d}}{d! \binom{t}{d}}. \]

We refer to the parameter $d$ as the \emph{width} of this hitting-set.
plain_text_def:
Suppose we are given an assignment of non-negative real numbers λ_x∈𝐑_+ and coefficients a_x ∈ [0,1] for each element x ∈𝒳. (Recall that an element x refers to an ordered pair (i,j), where i ∈ [n] and j is a possible assignment to variable X_i)

Define μ = ∑_x a_x λ_x, and for each i ∈ [n] define μ_i  = ∑_j a_i,jλ_i,j.

Suppose that there is a complex bad event ℬ defined by 
    ℬ≡∑_x a_k [X_i = j] ≥ t

where we use the Iverson notation for whether variable i takes on value j, where t ≥μ.  Let d be any non-negative integer. Then, recalling Definition <ref>, there is a fractional hitting-set Q with the property 

    G(Q, λ) ≤μ^d/d! td;   
    G_i(Q, λ) ≤d μ_i/μ·μ^d/d! td.


We refer to the parameter d as the width of this hitting-set.

Let M be a matroid and let (T,l) be a partial branch decomposition of M. The width of (T,l) is
  
    w(T,l) := {[ max_e ∈ E(T) w_(T,l)(e)             if  E(T) ≠∅;                       1              otherwise. ].

def:
Given a tree position $(C, \position)$ for a graph $G$, the
\emph{width} $b(f)$ of an edge $f$ in $C$ is the sum of the weights of
the edges of $G$ that pass through $f$:  
\begin{align*}
b(f) = w\left(R(f)\right) = w\left( \posfInv{\cutT{f}{g}} , \posfInv{\cutTopp{f}{g}}\right)
\end{align*}
or for some edge $g$ of $C$ with $g \neq f$.
plain_text_def:
Given a tree position (C, ) for a graph G, the
width b(f) of an edge f in C is the sum of the weights of
the edges of G that pass through f:  

    b(f) = w(R(f)) = w( fg , fg)

or for some edge g of C with g ≠ f.

For any (m,n) ∈× and any positive integer k, we have:

    e_-k^m/n· s^m/n_λ = (-1)^kn/(qt)^k(n-1)/2∑ s^m/n_μ  (-1)^width∏_i=1^k∏_j=1^n χ_j(R_i)^⌊-mj/n⌋ - ⌊-m(j-1)/n⌋

where the sum goes over all horizontal k-strips of n-ribbons of shape , and the remaining notations are as in Theorem <ref>.

def: Let $G$ be a finite abelian group, and let $A$ be a nonempty subset of $G$ not contained in any proper subgroup.  The \emph{width} of $A, w_G(A),$ is the least positive integer $k$ such that every element of $G$ can be expressed as the sum of at most $k$ elements of $A$, that is, $\bigcup_{1 \leq k^\prime \leq k} k^\prime A = G$.
plain_text_def: Let G be a finite abelian group, and let A be a nonempty subset of G not contained in any proper subgroup.  The width of A, w_G(A), is the least positive integer k such that every element of G can be expressed as the sum of at most k elements of A, that is, ⋃_1 ≤ k^'≤ k k^' A = G.

def: Let $\A$ be a partition of $[n]$ implementing the sequence $\{p_i\}_{i=1}^k$ and assume $\A$ is not equitable. We define the \emph{width} of $\A$, denoted $\omega(\A)$, as the minimal value of $y-x$ over all $x,y\in [n]$ such that $y>x$ and such that $y$ is in a high set of $\A$ and $x$ is in a low set. If there are no such $x$ and $y$ we define $\omega(\A)=\infty$.
plain_text_def: Let  be a partition of [n] implementing the sequence {p_i}_i=1^k and assume  is not equitable. We define the width of , denoted ω(), as the minimal value of y-x over all x,y∈ [n] such that y>x and such that y is in a high set of  and x is in a low set. If there are no such x and y we define ω()=∞.

def:
\label{dirpart}Let $D$ be a 2-in, 2-out digraph, and let $\mathcal{P}(D)$
denote the set of directed circuit partitions of $D$. If $C$ is a labeled,
directed Euler system of $D$ then for each $P\in\mathcal{P}(D)$, let $\phi
_{C}(P)$ and $\chi_{C}(P)$ denote the sets of vertices of $D$ where $P$
involves the transition labeled $\phi$ or $\chi$ (respectively) with respect
to $C$. The \emph{labeled directed circuit partition generating function of
}$D$ \emph{with respect to }$C$ is
\[
\pi(D,C)=\sum_{P\in\mathcal{P}(D)}\left(
%TCIMACRO{\dprod _{v\in\phi(P)}}%
%BeginExpansion
{\displaystyle\prod_{v\in\phi(P)}}
%EndExpansion
\phi_{C}(v)\right)  \left(
%TCIMACRO{\dprod _{v\in\chi(P)}}%
%BeginExpansion
{\displaystyle\prod_{v\in\chi(P)}}
%EndExpansion
\chi_{C}(v)\right)  y^{\left\vert P\right\vert -c(D)},
\]
where $c(D)$ is the number of connected components of $D$.
plain_text_def:
Let D be a 2-in, 2-out digraph, and let 𝒫(D)
denote the set of directed circuit partitions of D. If C is a labeled,
directed Euler system of D then for each P∈𝒫(D), let ϕ
_C(P) and χ_C(P) denote the sets of vertices of D where P
involves the transition labeled ϕ or χ (respectively) with respect
to C. The labeled directed circuit partition generating function of
D with respect to C is

    π(D,C)=∑_P∈𝒫(D)(
    
    
    ∏_v∈ϕ(P)
    ϕ_C(v))  (
    
    
    ∏_v∈χ(P)
    χ_C(v))  y^| P| -c(D),

where c(D) is the number of connected components of D.

def:
\label{modint}Let $C$ be an Euler system of a 4-regular graph $F$, and let $P$
be a circuit partition of $F$. Then the \emph{modified interlacement matrix of
}$C$\emph{ with respect to }$P$ is the matrix $M(C,P)$ obtained from
$\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{I}(C))$ by making the following changes:

\begin{enumerate}
\item If $P$ involves the $\phi$ transition with respect to $C$ at a vertex
$v$, then change the diagonal entry corresponding to $v$ to 1 and change every
other entry in that column to 0.

\item If $P$ involves the $\psi$ transition with respect to $C$ at a vertex
$v$, then change the diagonal entry corresponding to $v$ to 1.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let C be an Euler system of a 4-regular graph F, and let P
be a circuit partition of F. Then the modified interlacement matrix of
C with respect to P is the matrix M(C,P) obtained from
𝒜(ℐ(C)) by making the following changes:



  * If P involves the ϕ transition with respect to C at a vertex
v, then change the diagonal entry corresponding to v to 1 and change every
other entry in that column to 0.


  * If P involves the ψ transition with respect to C at a vertex
v, then change the diagonal entry corresponding to v to 1.

def:
Let $G$ be a graph and $A,B\subseteq V(G)$. We say that a vertex $v$ is a
\emph{witness} for the ordered pair $(A,B)$, if $v$ is adjacent to every vertex
in $A$, and $v$ is not adjacent to any vertex in $B$.
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and A,B⊆ V(G). We say that a vertex v is a
witness for the ordered pair (A,B), if v is adjacent to every vertex
in A, and v is not adjacent to any vertex in B.

def:
\label{witness}
A 1-\emph{witness} for a monotone function $f:\{0,1\}^\Lambda\to\{0,1\}$ is a minimal subset $W\subset \Lambda$ such that $\omega_W\equiv 1$ implies $f(\omega)=1$.
plain_text_def: A 1-witness for a monotone function f:{0,1}^Λ→{0,1} is a minimal subset W⊂Λ such that ω_W≡ 1 implies f(ω)=1.

def: A game $G$ is a \emph{zero game} if $G = 0$.
plain_text_def: A game G is a zero game if G = 0.

def:
Let $P$ be a pseudodiagram.  Then we say that $P$ is a \emph{zero game} iff $P$ is U1 and for every option
$Q$ of $P$, there is an option $R$ of $Q$, such that $Q$ is a zero game.
plain_text_def:
Let P be a pseudodiagram.  Then we say that P is a zero game iff P is U1 and for every option
Q of P, there is an option R of Q, such that Q is a zero game.

def: Given a partially labelled Dyck path, we call \emph{zero valleys} its vertical steps with label $0$ (which are necessarily preceded by an horizontal step, that is why we call them valleys).
plain_text_def: Given a partially labelled Dyck path, we call zero valleys its vertical steps with label 0 (which are necessarily preceded by an horizontal step, that is why we call them valleys).

def: Given a partially labelled square path, we call \emph{zero valleys} its vertical steps with label $0$ (which are necessarily preceded by a horizontal step, hence the name valleys).
plain_text_def: Given a partially labelled square path, we call zero valleys its vertical steps with label 0 (which are necessarily preceded by a horizontal step, hence the name valleys).

def:
A double pants decomposition $(P_a,P_b)$ is {\it admissible}  if it is possible to transform $(P_a,P_b)$ to a standard pants 
decomposition by a sequence of flips.
plain_text_def:
A double pants decomposition (P_a,P_b) is admissible  if it is possible to transform (P_a,P_b) to a standard pants 
decomposition by a sequence of flips.

def:
\label{def admiss}
A double pants decomposition $(P_a,P_b)$ is {\it admissible}  if %it is $\DP$-equivalent to some standard double pant decomposition.
there exists a standard double pants decomposition
$(P'_a,P'_b)$ such that $P'_a$ is flip-equivalent to $P_a$ and $P_b'$ is flip-equivalent to $P_b$.
plain_text_def:
A double pants decomposition (P_a,P_b) is admissible  if 
there exists a standard double pants decomposition
(P'_a,P'_b) such that P'_a is flip-equivalent to P_a and P_b' is flip-equivalent to P_b.

def:
A {\it double pants decomposition} $DP=(P_a,P_b)$ is a pair of pants decompositions $P_a$ and $P_b$ of the same surface
such that the Lagrangian planes $\L_a=\L(P_a)$ and  $\L_b=\L(P_b)$ spanned by these pants decompositions
are in general position. $P_a$ and $P_b$ are called {\it parts} of $DP$.
plain_text_def:
A double pants decomposition DP=(P_a,P_b) is a pair of pants decompositions P_a and P_b of the same surface
such that the Lagrangian planes Ł_a=Ł(P_a) and  Ł_b=Ł(P_b) spanned by these pants decompositions
are in general position. P_a and P_b are called parts of DP.

def:
A {\it double pants decomposition} $DP=(P_a,P_b)$ is a pair of pants decompositions $P_a$ and $P_b$ of the same surface
such that the Lagrangian planes $\L_a=\L(P_a)$ and  $\L_b=\L(P_b)$ spanned by these pants decompositions
are in general position.
plain_text_def:
A double pants decomposition DP=(P_a,P_b) is a pair of pants decompositions P_a and P_b of the same surface
such that the Lagrangian planes Ł_a=Ł(P_a) and  Ł_b=Ł(P_b) spanned by these pants decompositions
are in general position.

def:
Let $P=\{ c_1,\dots,c_{3g-3+2n}\}$ be a pants decomposition. A {\it Lagrangian plane}  
$\L(P)\subset H_1(S,\Z)$ is a subspace spanned by the homology classes $h(c_i)$, $i=1,\dots,3g-3+2n$ 
(here $c_i$ is taken with any orientation).

%
plain_text_def:
Let P={ c_1,…,c_3g-3+2n} be a pants decomposition. A Lagrangian plane  
Ł(P)⊂ H_1(S,) is a subspace spanned by the homology classes h(c_i), i=1,…,3g-3+2n 
(here c_i is taken with any orientation).

def:
Let $P=\{ c_1,\dots,c_{3g-3}\}$ be a pants decomposition. A Lagrangian plane  $\L(P)\subset H_1(S,\Z)$ is a sublattice 
spanned by the homology classes $h(c_i)$, $i=1,\dots,3g-3$ (here $c_i$ is taken with any orientation).
plain_text_def:
Let P={ c_1,…,c_3g-3} be a pants decomposition. A Lagrangian plane  Ł(P)⊂ H_1(S,) is a sublattice 
spanned by the homology classes h(c_i), i=1,…,3g-3 (here c_i is taken with any orientation).

def:
Two {\it  Lagrangian planes $\L_1$ and $\L_2$  are in general position} if 
% $\L_1\cap \L_2=0$ and 
$H_1(S,\Z)=\langle \L_1,\L_2\rangle$.
plain_text_def:
Two Lagrangian planes Ł_1 and Ł_2  are in general position if 

H_1(S,)=⟨Ł_1,Ł_2⟩.

def:
Two  Lagrangian planes $\L(P_1)$ and $\L(P_2)$  are {\it in general position} if 
 $\L_1\cap \L_2=0$ and $H_1(S,\Z)=\langle \L_1,\L_2\rangle$ (where $\langle \L_1,\L_2\rangle$ denotes the sublattice of
$H_1(S,\Z)$ spanned by $\L_1$ and $\L_2$).

%
plain_text_def:
Two  Lagrangian planes Ł(P_1) and Ł(P_2)  are in general position if 
 Ł_1∩Ł_2=0 and H_1(S,)=⟨Ł_1,Ł_2⟩ (where ⟨Ł_1,Ł_2⟩ denotes the sublattice of
H_1(S,) spanned by Ł_1 and Ł_2).

def:
A {\it pants decomposition} of $S$ is a set of (non-oriented) mutually disjoint curves 
$P=\{ c_1,\dots,c_{k} \}$  decomposing  $S$ into pairs of pants 
(i.e. into spheres with 3 holes).
In this paper, all boundary curves of $S$ are considered as a part of each pants decomposition of $S$.
\\
plain_text_def:
A pants decomposition of S is a set of (non-oriented) mutually disjoint curves 
P={ c_1,…,c_k}  decomposing  S into pairs of pants 
(i.e. into spheres with 3 holes).
In this paper, all boundary curves of S are considered as a part of each pants decomposition of S.

def:
A {\it pants decomposition} $P$ of $S$ is a system of nonoriented mutually disjoint curves 
$P=P_S=\{ c_1,\dots,c_k \}$  decomposing  $S$ into pairs of pants 
(i.e. into spheres with 3 holes).
plain_text_def:
A pants decomposition P of S is a system of nonoriented mutually disjoint curves 
P=P_S={ c_1,…,c_k }  decomposing  S into pairs of pants 
(i.e. into spheres with 3 holes).
